												Oh, Transistor. I went into this game assuming it was, like so many have said, a mere 6 hour jaunt. The impression often given is that that's all there is to Transistor; sure, it's visually and musically stunning, and its narrative is engaging, but ultimately many will say that 6 hours (give or take an hour) is all there is to it. I disagree, and not just because subjective, arbitrarily determined gameplay durations are generally a poor gauge of quality game content in the first place.My first playthrough took me about 11 hours, 12 if you count my various AFK'ing and tabbing out pauses. However, I didn't just play through the story from start to finish. I completed the extra challenge "tests" that introduced me to abilities I may not have realized were useful otherwise; I explored every area, read news terminals, and unlocked some of the additional "function" (ability) file details. All of these served to greatly expand my understanding of the game's setting and characters. It is this that gets me to the point of my review. There is more to Transistor than just the story that's on the surface. Just getting to the "end" of the game will not give you an explicit understanding of its story.Meticulously placed throughout the beautiful environments, the well-voiced dialogue, the amazing music -- even some of the function names -- are subtle hints, easter eggs, and pointers to details about the game's setting, story and characters that are often not addressed directly anywhere else. This game is very much about (subtly) showing you, NOT outright telling you. Days after I had first beaten the game, I was still going through my screenshots, still pondering the meaning behind some of the music's lyrics, and still reading others' interpretations. This was all in an attempt to absorb more of what the game has to offer, to gain even more insight into perhaps the best, most enjoyable and satisfying aspect of the game for me -- what was NOT said, what was NOT blatantly pointed out, and was instead left there for me to find on my own or to speculate about later. And my second playthrough... well. I don't think I've ever jumped right back into a game for a new playthrough so soon after finishing it. And then even the fact that the game's "new game+" option was instead referred to as a "recursion" turned out to have some significance.So yes, the game's art style is gorgeous. Its soundtrack is one of the best game soundtracks I've ever listened to. Its combat system is intricate and greatly rewards planning ahead and experimenting. It is all of these things, and you can go through a straight start-to-finish playthrough and enjoy every bit of that. But if you're the type of player who likes to ask a lot of questions about the specifics of a game's plot or characters, who isn't always merely satisfied with the obvious, and who appreciates a game that lets you connect some of the dots on your own, you'll very likely get even more out of Transistor than you thought you would. P.S.: Yes, the soundtrack is absolutely worth purchasing. Do it!

												You're probably aware that this is a beautiful game (nobody reads reviews before watching the trailer, right?), and it is BEAUTIFUL, the art and the songs. I see that most reviewers mention that and that the story is cool, but not so many people emphasize this enough:This is one of the best combat systems you'll find aroundDuring combat you use your skills (therein called "functions"), run around and etc... but you also have a "turn bar" that when fills up, allows you to "pause" the fight; it sort of allows you to "script" what you're going to do next. You have a certain number of "turn points" to spend on using skills and moving around. Once you're done, you "unpause" and your character will "run the script".That idea in itself is worth the game, really. But there is more.The skills are AWESOME. There are 16 "only", but they are VERY DIFFERENT. "Bounce" hits the target and ricochets around; "Breach" has a long range and pierces the target and walls. "Crash" causes little damage, but stuns the target, which increases the next damage; "Void" does not cause any damage, but increase the damage for the next few seconds. Now, these are their Active function; skills can be used in Passive mode as well - which give you some bonus or protection - or be Combined (in the game its called "upgrade") e.g. Breach + (Bounce + Crash) will pierce through targets in a straight line, but also ricochet and stun. Mind you, Bounce + (Breach + Crash) is not the same thing, nor is Crash + (Breach +  Bounce).The combinations and possibilities for combos are so overhelming that I've finished the game twice and never settled down for one single combo line, always changing. The combat system is just plain amazing.Finally, another reason to buy this game: it is a Supergiant Game. These guys are one of the best small studio I've seen around, professional products released in mature state, also customer support was great when I needed. Back these guys as much as you can, they deserve it.

												Transistor is a good game, and it is worth playing. I beat it in around ~5 hours.It is truly beautiful, both for the ears, and for the eyes. It really sucks you into a fantastic looking world, that leaves you silently thinking back on it once you've finished it. Artistically, the game is amazing.However, the combat is just average. It's interesting, and kind of unique, mixing real time combat with some turn based element (being able to freeze everything to plan a move), but it gets repetitive, as the enemies don't feel that varied, and you end up mostly running in circles while your action bar is recharging. Also, you often have to wait a few seconds extra after each fight is done just so one of your skills comes off cool down, so that you can grab the monster EXP that's shield protected. If there were more fights like the final boss, it would feel more rewarding to play it.The story is vaguely interesting, and unique - but not thrilling. I feel that if the combat and story were just a bit better, the game would be a masterpiece, instead of simply being a good game.Still, Transistor is a unique experience that is worth living :steamhappy:

Posted: January 4, 2015
												Transistor is one of those few games that feel unique. The last few years I have only got this feeling from two games, the first one was The Banner Saga, and now Transistor. This is a game that when I sit down playing it I don't wanna stop, but I dont really want to continue either, because i'm thinking: The game is probably quite short.However, for this story the amount of time was perfect, not to short and definitely not to long. This is a very interesting RPG-game with a deep love story, in a city where very weird things are going on. I must say that at first I was very confused, but the longer I played it the longer I was drawn into the story and into the world of Transistor. Together with the exellent art-style and magnificent soundtrack this game made made me more immersed than what I usually get in games, atleast since I got older. I remember that I as a kid more often got this feeling, the feeling I got from Banner saga and now Transistor. I guess that is because I get used to it, to the way games play and the way a gaming story most often adapts. Romance or more rather love is a huge part of the story, or it basically is and I don't feel many games use that as their spine. More games should, since it's a powerful tool to usurp our feelings. I want my feelings to get usurped by games, I really do. This game has two main characters, one is Red, a strong female character who are fighting to get back her voice, which was stolen from her by Camerata, which is a group you don't know much about, but their intentions were at first good, but power might have corrupted them. The other protagonist is "the" Transistor, the weapon Red uses. who throughout the game is trying to help you as much as possible. The fighting is very interesting, as you play you will find more and more moves, or attacks that you can use during these fights. You can fight as time goes, or you can enter this... "V.A.T.S" system (If you know Fallout 3 & NV) where you get to plan your moves ahead of you and then fire them all at once without the enemy having the time to respond. However that leads to a cooldown so you can't attack for a few seconds after. I found this system very usable at times, but mostly I tend to... forget it? Or maybe I just don't appriciate it enough. It has helped me sure, but I want to kill the enemy "myself" If that makes sence. Whenever you get beaten enough you'll lose some attacks, which will return later on when another cooldown has counted down to zero. The most interesting part with the attacks are that you can put them together, you can strenghen one by adding the others, that however cost a few points so at the same time you have to look at a bar that show you how much points you've spend on this. While leveling up you can choose to increase that bar, or add another support slot for your weapon, etc. I would dearly recommend this game to anyone who would like to try something different, but still very beautiful and worthwhile.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												The age-old argument as to whether games can be justly referred to as art has already been won, and any gamer would defend the industry in that respect. However, it's always nice to see games release that further enforce that ideal, and no other game released in 2014 embraces that ideal more than Transistor. Supergiant hit it out of the park with this title, and once again proved that games can be more than just pure entertainment. They can challenge us intellectually and philosophically. They can inspire spiritual debates, and even make us question our own existence as much as any other medium can, and in some cases, even more so.On its surface, Transistor is a game about survival and revenge. Surviving the coming onslaught of the Process, a mindless virus destroying the virtual world of Cloudbank, and avenging the loss of your voice, not to mention the death of your one true love. Peel back that layer however, and just like any other great work of art, there are many more layers to be discovered. The depth and careful attention to detail in this masterpiece is there for those who pay attention, and if they do, they will experience something truly spectacular that will change the way they approach video games in the future.As the name suggests, Cloudbank is a virtual city, one ruled by its citizens. Just like any other city, there are scientists, musicians, artists, and sports players. All significant decisions that affect the citizens are put to a vote at kiosks. Changes in aesthetics, buildings, weather, even the color of the sky itself, are all decided in this manner. This is an issue for a handful of usurpers scheming in the shadows however, claiming with conviction, that when everything changes, nothing changes.You play as Red, a famous musician in Cloudbank, who unfortunately for her, is also a popular voice in the social hierarchy of the city. It seems that there is a group of people who are unhappy with the current state of Cloudbank, and they want to change it, by resetting it. The Camerata, as they call themselves, seek out the popular voices to assimilate them into a Transistor so that they can give the citizens what they don't even know they want. This will be useful once the Process finishes destroying the current version of the city, and the Camerata take control of version 2.0. Of course, this brings about interesting questions concerning what the collective thinks versus the individual, and the merits of socialism.The Camerata's plans hit a snag when Red's lover sacrifices himself to protect her, which results in the terrorist group losing the Transistor. Thus, the primary weapon of the enemy becomes a tool of self expression for Red, something a mute desperately needs. With it, Red is able to collect the consciousness of citizens who have already fallen victim to the Process, and unlock Functions for her to use to protect herself from the same fate.These Functions are the foundation of the attack system. Each one has a primary attack, secondary attack, and a passive attribute to be strategically utilized in battle. Combining them in different ways provides you with an almost unlimited amount of customized attacks at your disposal. Experimenting with these Functions feels like a practice in programming, with the names mimicking those in existing development frameworks. The attacks can be triggered in real time easily enough, but the real fun is entering a Turn state, which essentially pauses the action long enough for you to plan out your moves in advance, and then ending the Turn state will allow you to watch them play out. One of my absolute favorite functions provides a passive ability that gives you a small chance to evolve into a 'Super User' when entering a Turn state. If this occurs, you can basically nuke the Process into oblivion, de-rezzing them TRON style. The developers encourage you to try out as many combinations as possible by unlocking more background information on the citizens of Cloudbank for using the Functions in different ways.You will have plenty of opportunities to research these Functions by locating a 'Back Door', which grants you access to an administrative area of Cloudbank, which is full of challenges for you to complete. I recommend you take the time to complete these, since they will improve your skills exponentially. Practice makes perfect, and you can never have too much of it. You can also listen to Transistor's soundtrack here, which is absolutely brilliant, and I cannot stress that enough.As great as the primary game mechanics are, the little details are what makes Transistor really shine. The commentary from your lover coming from the Transistor, for example. Character development is hard enough, but when the protagonist is mute, it's even harder. Supergiant did a fantastic job of pulling it off nonetheless. There's a flourish control that makes Red throw the Transistor up into the air and catch it before coming back down, which serves no purpose except for looking cool. You can also stop what you're doing at anytime and hum, which allows Red to dance with her lover's new shell and hum to the tune of the soundtrack currently playing. The backgrounds you unlock by experimenting with the Functions give you details on the lost citizens of Cloudbank, some of which are subtly implied to be LGBT is some way, which is not central to the story, and is entirely optional. It's nice that these kinds of details were considered, and every game would improve with such features.Transistor never overstays it's welcome, and if the first playthrough wasn't enough time to spend in this amazing world, a game+ mode is available as well as difficulty modifiers similar to those found in Bastion, providing plenty of excuses to return to Cloudbank.The story takes multiple turns before you reach the climax, which will hit you square in the gut to great effect. All the while exploring themes such as socialism, religion, death, love, revenge, sacrifice, and the afterlife in a postmodern cyberpunk setting. College level dissertations can be written using Transistor as a focal point, and that is an incredible accomplishment by the developers. Every time you play this game you'll discover a new layer you may have missed the last time through. Everything about this game is subtle, the story, the characters, and the themes, allowing the players to decide what to take away from their time in this world. It never feels as if Supergiant is using Transistor as a soapbox to shove their own agendas down our throats, which games this deep tend to do.Not only is Transistor one of my favorite games of all time, I would go as far as to say it is my personal pick for Independent Game of the Year, if not decade. I would have gladly paid three times what they are charging for this game without regret, so if you're on the fence about spending $20, don't be. The soundtrack is also available on Steam for $10, which is easily worth it. The tracks carry some emotional weight though, so the developers have explicitly stated that experiencing them in the game first is ideal, and I would have to agree.

												I guess I might as well make the inevitable comparisons to Bastion first. It doesn't (and couldn't) have the "amazing thing out of nowhere" quality of Bastion. But the art direction, narration, and setting of Transistor are more to my taste.The story has a cryptic in medias res presentation and requires a lot of digging to uncover and properly arrange what is actually going on, but that was OK with me.I also was happy trying out tons of different loadouts and combinations of the combat powers -- the motivation of unlocking story/background bits, and tackling the different challenge rooms, was enough to push me into that experimental approach. And I think that made for a more enjoyable playthrough. Transistor strikes me as being a little analogous to Bioshock in that way; it's tempting to just wrench and electrobolt your way through Bioshock, and you couldn't really be blamed for doing that, but you might have had more fun intentionally trying other weapons/plasmids.Transistor definitely is flawed as a combat-heavy game with nuanced but poorly tutorialized mechanics that are also hard to visually "read", so I imagine many people will bounce off of it. For various reasons I stuck with it though and ended up having a very good time. I even fired up NG+ immediately and played about halfway through it again. It's a beautiful game that attempts some interesting things, and I'm glad I played it.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												A stylish, smart, and sexy game from start to finish.The game begins by tantalizing you with a bit of it's story, and drags you in and doesn't let you go, being vague but telling you what you need to know to get you thinking. Every moment of playing Transistor I was wondering where it would take me next, and I was never disappointed by what followed my anticipation. It has a very intereting take on a futuristic politics landscape, and has very well-thought out characters and developement.The combat is fluid and tactical, while somehow having an elegance about it. It utilizes such simple mechanics, however that does't mean it won't push your understanding of these mechanics to the limit as the difficulty definitely does ramp up as the game proceeds. The game will follow exactly what you want, and it is all up to your skill and cunning to successfully defeat all foes that come your way. The game mixes many genres but with flawless results as you level up and collect new abilities and powers a la an RPG, while you switch into turn-based strategy, and then into a fast-paced action game. The game keeps you on your toes and always tries to throw something new at you, but never going overboard and bringing you a challenge that is impassible.However the show-stopping point of this game, as similar to other Supergiant success, Bastion, is the art direction. The voice over by Logan Cunningham, and the tunes sung by Ashley Lynn Barrett seal the deal of the package as they drive home the emotion, setting, and character of the game without eveer seeming forced or clunky. The look of Transistor is sleek and futuristic and as you delve deeper into the story the surroundings transition perfectly. Near the conclusion of the game you return to where you had started but the setting has changed drastically,  and the score has been remixed. This point really displayed the kind of talent the creators have, and how powerful an indie developer can be.Transistor is a marvel to look at, a blast to play, and has a story dripping in charm and intrigue. If you were a fan of Bastion, it will not disappoint you, and I highly reccomend it.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												I was looking forward to this game for a long time, and have a lot to say about it, but I'll do a super TL;DR list precursor.PROS:+Amazing artwork+Particular songs of the soundtrack+Interesting upgrade systemCONS:-Plothole laden story-Combat-Short-Repetitive-Crashes-BugsFrom this point on, spoilers will be present.Transistor is something of a tactical RPG by Supergiant Games. The player is thrust into a vague situation as the famous singer Red, whom has had her voice "stolen" from her, as she removes a sword-like object from a corpse. It's insinuated that you knew this person, Mr. Nobody, and they protected you. The sword acts as the narrator of the story and as the majority of the player's insight into the world.Red uses the sword, the titular "Transistor", to fight off mysterious white invaders known as "The Process". The sword begins with a few attacks and has the ability to stop time (called "turn) to plan attacks, and then execute the qued attacks. This can only be done once every few seconds, depending on how many actions were lined up, and this is the main method of playing. The player can attack outside of combat when they aren't regenerating their "turn" ability or when an ability is upgraded with a specific augment, but it's very slow and inaccurate. There's a multitude of skills (called "functions"- 18 in total) which can also be used to augment other skills or Red herself. Functions are multi-purpose: not only do they act as Red's skills system, but they also unlock fragments of backstory for the game while using them in one of the three different capacities (ability, ability upgrade, personal upgrade), but the backstories are focused on the person related to the ability.The skill system is very interesting and can lead to some creative builds, but ultimately the goal is still to do gross amounts of damage, and there's only a handful of skills that will help you reach those levels. While many of these functions have interesting properties and uses, Transistor's combat doesn't really lend to using some of them more than once to unlock background story. An example of this is the function "Get", which pulls an enemy toward you. Due to the nature of combat, Get often is redundant or, at worst, a detriment. When executing a turn, time isn't stopped anymore- it's slowed. Faster creatures will begin to move away from your planned abilities and Get can sometimes miss or pull the wrong one. This doesn't require faster enemies to mess up, either, as the game's readout of potential damage often is misleading. When stacking attacks, the game will caculate how much damage will occur to enemies. Often it'll drop out enemies if there's too much information on the screen, but it also poorly handles damage over time and momentum knocking enemies out of range. Some monsters, like Jerk 3.0's, are able to rotate so quickly that by the time you're done buffing and debuffing, they have rotated and you can no longer backstab. This is frustrating considering that the two most simple solutions are: A, stop time entirely for the turn function, or B, remove the damage readout.Despite being flawed on many fronts on its own, the mediocre combat isn't the only thing to blame. Enemies in Transistor focus on ten different enemies. These enemies start out basic, and get "upgrades" as the player continues through the story. These upgrades are denoted by a 2.0 or higher designation beside the name. Despite the intent that the player needs to deal with these enemies in different ways, none of these enemies force the player to think differently. The answer is always the same: use a turn and do as much damage as possible in one go, preferably by way of AoE damage. This is absolutely true for every enemy, from hulking Jerks to artillery Cluckers. There are some attempts to break this up, such as the Snapshot's obscuring effect, but many of the abilities in the game already force the player into melee combat, so they are often inconsequential. In the later stages of the game, the player merely need to wait until an enemy is no longer stealthed to unleash flurry of void debuffs and a final cull swing.The game is rather short, and it takes somewhere in between two to six hours for a playthrough, depending on if the player does everything (interacting with spots and terminals, doing challenges, etc) or not. The player is thrust into the story as soon as they start the game for the first time, and it really never becomes much clearer. Transistor takes something of a "Dark Souls" approach to telling a story by having it dispersed through strings of text on functions and difficulty increasing "limiters". The Transistor, whom is inhabited by someone Red knows that remains nameless, is the main source of off-hand information during the game, usually to excess. The problem with this story is that nothing is ever divulged, nothing is ever expanded upon, and most information presented through functions are about people that either aren't important to the story or provide nothing concurrent that puts things into context. The game is absolutely full of plot holes to an incredible degree and it's presented in a way that would be lost on a lot of people, as it expects the player to use all abilities in all capacities and sift through the text. It's terrible storytelling, which is a shame. The story is interesting, but inaccessible unless subtitles (for Sybil, Royce and Mr. Nobody) and with some extra reading and conjecture. Conjecture is not a basis for storytelling, though; you're just witnessing an event without any context. It's like if you've witnessed a UFO beaming up some farm animals in the distance. Without the rest of the story, the game focuses on Red and Mr. Nobody's extremely obvious relationship as lovers, and Mr. Nobody talks at great length in regards to this when he's not busy filling your ears full of nonsense otherwise. "Sea Monster's the only real choice here," indeed. The relationship stands somewhere around "puppy love" on the devotion spectrum until the end of the game, but there's really no development at all. There's no back story, outside of a few obscure references and some images during the credits.The majority of the game is spent trying to get to the Camerata in their tower, and then backtracking through some of the early areas to an M.C. Escher area (which contrasts to the Gustav Klimt inspired "golds and shapes" artwork through the rest of the game). The areas, while beautiful, are exceptionally similar and the game's areas bleed into each other. While there's plenty of polish, there's plenty of little things I wouldn't expect at this level of polish, like how OVC terminals are pretty much just inverted when facing the other way, including the giant "OVC" markings. These things become very apparent when the environments aren't differentiated, and when you're doing the same things over and over.Supergiant Games had a lot to live up to for their second game, and I can't really hold them to those expectations; they were just astronomical considering Bastion was their first fare, which was both refreshing, innovative, and honed in just about every category. Something about Transistor feels rushed, or hollow. It's hard not to compare Transistor to Bastion with all the similarities and outright references to it; a silent protagonist with a narrator voiced by Logan Cunningham battles to save what's left of their city using a deus ex machina device, all whilst encountering a few survivors and an eventual "betrayal" that leads the character to seek greener pastures. The only differences here are story elements, which are even more vague in this offering, and the well meaning but ultimately poor combat. I'm pressed to say that this game would be amazing for a first entry as a studio, but, it's not.Transistor is an okay game plagued with self-plagiarizing of old concepts and poor execution of new ones.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
Good, but less than the sum of its parts.Transistor could be lauded for many things. It's a beautiful game with a great soundtrack and wonderful voice acting. The vast array of combat options that open up as you progress allow for a staggering degree of customization. Unfortunately, it is also held back by several areas of weakness. The story, while featuring some interesting characters and an imaginative setting, ultimately felt small, like something that could have been condensed into just a short story or short film. The visually vibrant world you travel through feels somehow empty, devoid of life aside from the enemies you encounter. Finally, the combat never quite develops a pleasing sense of flow to it.Supergiant Games has again raised the bar on weaving a soundtrack into a game. This time it feels even more personal to the story since the main character, Red, is the singer. Just know before you choose to buy the soundtrack that only a handful of the songs have vocals, not counting the extended soundtrack which features a lot of Red humming. Numerous of the purely instrumental tracks have found their way into my music library, but they're not the main attraction.Similarly top notch is the voice acting. Fans of Bastion will recognize the way that it is utilized. It adds atmosphere and brings these characters to life. I must, however, disagree with the decision to have Red's voice "taken away" right at the start of the game. She is a fully fleshed out character, not some blank slate for players to project themselves into. Yet some of that is lost by not letting her speak. It also reduces other characters in the game to mostly talking at you in monologues where there could have been conversations. I get why it was an appealing option for the developers though. It's interesting to consider how a singer would feel and react to having one of her most valuable faculties taken away. The world surely feels more bleak and lonely this way too. You even get to hear her through the songs and occasionally in written form. However, as it is I would say more was lost than gained by muting her.While avoiding spoilers, I will say that I would have liked to have seen more out of the story. A lot of the right ingredients were there, but for the most part I would say the quantity wasn't enough or things were left too vague. I liked the characters that were there, but it could have used a couple more of them, particularly ones not affiliated with The Camerata (you're introduced to them early on). I was intrigued by the city of Cloudbank, was TOLD about some of its neat features and people, but I never SAW them. The game never fully convinced me that the place you spend most of your time in was ever lived in by everyday people. This may be a futuristic city where things like trash don't exist, but there has to have been more evidence of life left behind that could have been put into the visuals.Finally, it seems that Transistor's most divisive aspect is its combat system. I was definitely in the camp disappointed with it at first but it does get better as you unlock more options. You have several primary "Active" attack slots that can each be significantly altered by two secondary upgrade slots. You also have passive buff slots. Every ability, or Function as the game calls them, can only be used once until you are in New Game+ and begin getting multiples. You have to decide how you want to utilize each function: Active, Upgrade or Passive? You rarely are able to use all your functions at once.It is in the action of battle that things start to falter. The Active functions you bring into the fight and a unique ability to briefly stop time are the only tools ever at your disposal. There is no blocking or dodging aside from normal movement. In stopping time, you have an action bar that is depleted with each action you take. Once you unpause, all the actions you just planned play out at super speed. Obviously this is extremely powerful and it is counterbalanced by disabling all actions besides movement for a time based on how much of the action bar you depleted.The problem is that it is unsatisfying to use. It doesn't take skill to stop time and wail on an unmoving target and it's not fun to run around waiting on a timer afterward. If you forgo this superpower then you're left with, at most, four Active functions to use, and that usually breaks down to spamming one or two of them. If the game had any form of defensive maneuver, I think the developers knew you'd be far less likely to use the time stop. Yet that is the gimmick they went with. The most joy I found in combat was in frequently trying out new builds, including ones others suggested online.Transistor teeters on the edge of whether I'd recommend it or not, but ultimately a couple of its strengths are SO strong that it belongs in the thumbs up category. I will add that if you haven't played Bastion, that is the better game to start with and to get a feel for if you enjoy how Supergiant Games crafts their products.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Oh I really enjoyed Transistor. I finished the regular and NG+ playthroughs of the game across a span of about 3-4 days. One could probably rush through the story in as little as 3 hours, or take time unlocking all the lore, doing the side challenges for extra xp and game knowledge, listening to the catchy music, and stopping to smell all the roses along the way and end up taking easily triple or quadruple that.The game and combat mechanics are pretty fun, with a number of subroutines that you unlock or add to your Transistor weapon as you level up. You form actual skills with those subroutines, using a combination of active slots, support slots (that you slot subroutines into to improve active slots), and four passive slots (buffs to improve your character as a whole). Each subroutine does a different, but thematically similar, thing depending on whether it's currently in an active, passive, or support slot.There are thus many different possible and valid skill combinations and loadouts, and I found myself constantly swapping back and forth between them as I went through the game, especially once I started doing the side challenges where constraints force you to experiment and find new and efficient (or slow and steady) ways of killing things. In addition, each subroutine represents a character within the game's lore and to unlock the full lore for a character, if so desired, requires you to use their subroutine in each of the three slot types for at least one battle, each slot type unlocking about 1/3 of their character bio.Combat itself is a combination of real time and planning mode, and is split up largely into a number of self-contained encounters. Planning mode pauses the map and allows you to preview, queue, and execute in quick succession a number of attacks at once in an interface similar to Xcom or Shadowrun Returns, except that you can preview and rewind options before finally committing. There is no miss chance, or random skill damage, damage is constant but modified by variables depending on if the enemy is stunned or backstabbed, for example.Carrying out actions in the planning mode enables them all to be done in less than a game time second, so it become a power play of sorts whenever planning mode is up, but each ability used in planning mode has a cost which is subtracted from the remaining amount of action points you have in that round of planning. Once you leave planning mode, however, you cannot use most skills until the cooldown for the next planning round is up, leaving you with a few seconds of vulnerability between planning rounds. However, skills used during real time do not trigger a cooldown, and so in some cases it is very beneficial to fight things in real time (or a combination of the two) instead of always in planning mode.An interesting mechanic that I did not figure out until I was into NG+, was that while you have a certain number of action points to spend per round, not actually spending them all allows your downtime before you next skill use to be proportionally smaller, which is critical versus a certain enemy in the game. On the flip side, spending "over" what you normally have in planning mode locks your skills for that much longer before you can use them again!The story in the game was pretty neat, if a little on the short side, with a narration style similar to Bastion, but this time the narrator is also the Transistor and with you from the start. Like Bastion, you are dumped right into the plot to start off, and the story is revealed in pieces as you go along. The narration is touching in places, boring in others, but overall quite well done. That ending though. It came unexpected to me the first time, as I didn't think that was the end of the game yet, but hit harder the second time through for me when I knew what was coming. I didn't want to end the game. I did love the ambience though! A combination of the music and the dystopian steampunk background scenery. I am a sucker for night-time big city skylines, and the art in this game evoked so many wistful memories.A couple cons of the game: It's very easy to miss certain lore terminals and the game often doesn't let you back up if you went a little too far in one direction. It is often not obvious which way is "onward" and which way is a dead end with a lore piece. Your only options then are to load back from the last save (and you can only save at certain locations, though there is pretty much one before or after nearly every fight) or wait until NG+ to see what you missed. Or YouTube. The narrator is also overly talkative at times, though I guess that's a personality trait. There are also several plot holes in the story to me still, like *why* the Transistor's ownership got passed over to Red, and several other things I feel are little plot holes here and there that are not adequately explained.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												Supergiant Games have done it again. This game is as beautiful, if not even more beautiful than Bastion. However, before I go on with the rest of my review, I should say that even if you loved Bastion, you may not love this game. A lot of people fell in love with Bastion, not just because of the gameplay and music, but because of the storyline and the narrator that made you feel like you were part of the story.Now, that's not to say that Transistor doesn't have an interesting storyline, it's just that the storyline isn't as clear as it was in Bastion. That's not necessarily a bad thing either, some people like these sort of stories, I'm one of them. Transistor's story is a little more open to interpretation, whereas Bastion's was straightforward, so in this regard, some Bastion lovers may be disappointed. It's also a little hard to understand the story, even after two playthroughs, I mean, I get what's going on, but I'm left with a why at the end of the game. It's explained why in the game, but the reason just seems a bit flawed, I can't talk much more about it without spoiling things, so I'll leave it at that.As for the narrator, Logan Cunningham, I'm really glad to see that he's back in this game. The only issue I had, was that his impact on the game felt like it fell short in comparison to Bastion. The reasoning behind that, is because in Bastion, he actually played a bit more of an important role, in Transistor, however, he just seems like a big question mark the entire time. Now, while he is considered a main character, I mean, he's with you the entire time after all, it's just that they never really give much information on him. His lines in the games were mostly reactionary as well, instead of in Bastion where it felt like he was telling the story, in this game, it just feels like he's living through the story along with us.With all of that said, I still love Transistor more than Bastion.While Transistor might not be as good as Bastion on the storytelling side, the story of Transistor is still rather interesting in it's own way. Bastion was really clear cut with it's story, and that's fine, but I love the way Transistor is a lot more open with it's own story. It takes awhile to figure all of out, but I find it to be more interesting that way. The soundtrack of this game is just amazing. I don't know how Supergiant Games did it again, I usually don't keep in-game music/sounds on, unless if they're really good, and I kept mine on the entire time while playing Transistor. I'm even listening to it now while writing this review, I'll probably end up buying the soundtrack on Steam later on. The music just matches so perfectly with the game itself, it doesn't feel like a distraction, it only enhances the experience. The gameplay of Transistor is a bit more interesting than Bastion as well. Though I should warn you to look up some videos on youtube of the gameplay before buying Transistor. Personally though, I love the mix of using the turn-based system, along with just attacking without the turn system. It's a pretty interesting way to play, a good mix of both is the best way to go, in my opinion. The ability to use your functions (skills) as actives, passives or upgrades is a pretty cool concept as well. A bit limiting in some cases, but that just adds a bit more to the challenge.In terms of achievements, this is rather easy to perfect in comparison to Bastion and perhaps most games in general. There isn't much difficulty involved in many of the achievements, they're more time consuming than anything. However, since the game is rather short, it only takes like 6-7 hours for your first playthrough and then perhaps 4-5 more for your second playthrough. I finished both of my playthroughs in a little over 11 hours and got all of the achievements, so it's definitely a bit shorter than Bastion.To conclude, Transistor is a beautiful and wonderful game on it's own. If you think it'll be exactly the same as Bastion however, you may be a bit disappointed. However, Transistor is my favorite game so far this year, it did not disappoint me one bit and it only surpassed the expectations I had. I am merely warning those who think this is almost an exact copy of Bastion, it is not. Pros: + Interesting gameplay+ Beautiful art style+ Wonderful music+ Decent replay value+ Lots of different combinations for functions (skills)Cons:- A bit on the short side (6 Hours for first playthrough)- Some parts of the story could use a bit more explaining

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												A very stylish Sci-Fi Noire-ish game about a strange and somewhat utopian city, "Cloudbank", falling to an epidemic/invasion of some kind, "The Process". The protagonist, a famous musician of the city called "Red", vanishes after one of her stage acts and finds herself right in the middle of the city's demise. The game drops you into a scene with Red pulling a tool resembling an oversized sword from someone's body, which is accompanying and talking to her and which narrates many of her actions and compensates for the city having "taken" Red's voice, who herself is mostly silent. With this tool, the "Transistor", you fight your way through the declining urban environment to the source of this epidemic trying to save the city.The game is short, but very impressive. The art design feels special and there is some pretty cool music. Cloudbank is a rather mysterious city/town, the game isn't straightforward with what world, place or time you are exactly finding yourself in. The "traces" of former certain city inhabitants absorbed by the Transistor to power your abilites while handling it in combat (fitting to their stories and roles within the city) give you hints to events predating Red's disappearance and are interesting to read - but overall the game loves leaving you in a wondering position for many parts, which (in a good, engrossing way) mystifies the whole experience and leaves room for own interpretations, possibly even for pre-/sequels or novels or other things that would build on the strong lore pieces which are there (I believe I have noticed this in the devs previous title "Bastion" to some degree too, but to my knowledge it was never worked out further, whether that is good or bad I'm not sure).Like "Bastion" this is a rather "soft" strategy action RPG in the way that you need to fight with some brains but not by being confused by millions of units and possible actions. You engage enemies with selective combat options organized at check-/savepoints, either in real-time or by utilizing a limited time-stopping/slowing planning feature. There are minor leveling elements and rather trivial but curious choices planted selectively throughout the city circling around some of its former daily routines and design questions (voting on things was popular among Cloudbank's citizens, it seems). Apparently, as a neat gimmick, the choices and a few other stats of the playerbase (like the kill count for each enemy type) are woven into this (or the game at least made me believe so). Maybe this could have been something to expend more, as it is effectively working into Cloudbank's digital and scientific ambience. You see the city through various stages of decline but without the levels building themselves up just before you (which I found somewhat irritating in Bastion), and without the "hit and run" concept of Bastion where you would often have a sanctuary to return to and select new levels to start from. This makes your journey feel a bit more like a real series of events rather than a level clearing maze, the city more persistent and you to be "actually there (as much as that is possible in this mysterious world). The narrator doesn't feel as annoying as the one in Bastion sometimes does, but maybe too distant - or even lethargic - at times. But this could be the idea of his role within the story. In general I was thankful to have him as my - or Red's - companion. However I would have loved to hear Red being properly voiced too I think. I'm not exactly the biggest fan of this "silent protagonist" concept. Here it feels rather fitting though as the whole game is strange in a good kind of way, and it allows some certain love of detail to shine more for example when Red is answering to news feeds and polls on public terminals and correcting her own sentences while being in the middle of typing them to the point where she may even give up hope for the city herself - a subtle but strong way of projecting the protagonist's emotions despite her voicelessness.There is a little sandbox-like place in which you can practice combat and take part in some challenges. It's not as big as in Bastion, but I don't think it needs to be as it would probably only distract from the main experience. A new game will retain your level and abilites and ramp up the strength of the enemies accordingly. There are modifiers too - "limiters" - to make your enemies stronger and you level up faster, for an added challenge to whoever seeks it. That aside there doesn't seem any significant replay value, whether there are multiple endings I don't know yet. But the initial experience is an engaging and memoreable one, the game feels bold, thoughtful and determined and it's just impressive to see an apparent great vision turned so seemingly smoothly and confidently into a finished product that would very well deserve to be called a work of art.

												After playing and loving Bastion, I had high hopes for Transistor.  Unfortunately, several glaring issues wth the gameplay just kept me from enjoying the game.  The story seems fine, if rather tough to piece together, so I will not cover that here.Obviously Transistor will be compared to Bastion, so I will do that as well.  The pros to Bastion's gameplay are-Wide range of weapons that can be used in combinations for different playstyles-Upgrade system that adds noticable benefits to both your character and his weapons-Strong core gameplay (dodging, blocking, attacking, etc.) that rewards skill and timing and prevents overreliance on healing items-No unnecessarily punishing elements (i.e. undodgeable/unblockable attacks), so deaths are almost always your faultTransistor on the other hand, seems to go directly against what worked in Bastion for core gameplay.-No natural block or dodge ability (aside from the teleport dash and invisibility functions), so there is no way to mitigate damage-Slow-moving character that tends to get caught on obstacles, exacerbated by the lack of a natural dodge-No healing aside from a late-game function, so some fights become battles of attrition-Several enemies whose attacks are unavoidable (dogs, creeps, jerks), even with the aforementioned functions, so fights involving these enemies are unnecessarily punishing-Environments that offer little room for maneuveringAll of this combined results in a gameplay experience that is a chore to endure, particularly later on when high-health enemies with unavoidable attacks appear in numbers.  The teleport dash function can help, but even when dashing away in a straight line enemies can still catch and damage you.  And the environments' cramped design means that you end up dashing in circles trailing enemies that keep picking away at your health in between dashes.  Fights become a race to see if you can kill these enemies before you lose a critical function.It is a shame that I could not enjoy the game due to these awful design choices.  The function system is an intriguing feature with great depth that could have enabled a wide range of playstyles.  Unfortunately the poorly-designed basic  gameplay means that this system cannot be used to its full potential.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Transistor brings more of the amazing atmosphere and ongoing narration that people loved in Bastion, with an even more incredible soundtrack. The combination real-time/turn-based combat allows for deep strategy and will keep you switching up your selected functions (and the functions that modify them) to find a play style that suits you best. It is sadly quite linear: all battle encounters are static locations (though the enemies can change based on your level) and there are only one or two very small optional areas. And, unless you missed a few corners of interaction or side rooms with static art (like the opening image,) the only reason to play again is for the sake of achievements; there's not even minor alternate endings like Bastion. (And, when you see the ending, you'll probably wish there was.)That said, the positives of combat, music, and story vastly outweight the negatives of linearity and low-replay value, and I highly recommend this for anyone looking for a short, strategic brawler or just more of what they loved from Bastion. The soundtrack itself is excellent all its own, so even if you don't go for the game you should pick up the soundtrack.

												Short, yet very sweet. Everything about this game is art, from the music to the graphics to the story.Transistor is a sci-fi action adventure game with a combat system that's a mix of hack & slash and turn-based. You get about 20 "functions" which can each be used in three roles: firstly as a combat skill, secondly as an upgrade for skills, and thirdly as a passive that effects all skills and combat. You can install and uninstall these functions as much as you like, giving you lots of flexibility. As you level up you also get the choice to use limiters, which buff your enemies. These are optional, so you can challenge yourself however you see fit.The only thing this game needs is more content. However, you can replay the game retaining all your skills and level from the previous playthrough, and there are special arenas that test your skill.Definitely worth checking out.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												Short version: This art-house action-RPG comes with an unconventional/semi-turn based battle system, gorgeous music and visuals, a somewhat thin but wonderfully told narrative, and remarkable integration of gameplay and storytelling.  It's a gem of a game with a decent amount of content and is absolutely worth cherishing.--------Long version: Transistor begins gently and without a lot of explanation, giving the player just enough information to know what's going on and where to go.  In short, you're on the run from your would-be assassins, fighting enemies along the way.  You have a sword that talks (voiced by Logan Cunningham, the narrator from Supergiant Games' own Bastion), and the game doesn't bog you down with needless explanations of how a lot of the setting's pieces work.  You quickly acquire abilities as you go, and these skills make Transistor special in several ways:1) Battles in Transistor work somewhat like Diablo's where you can button-mash if you want, but you can also queue up and instantly execute a limited number of attack commands or move a certain distance without enemy reprisal.  The catch is that until your Turn() meter refills over a few seconds, you can't use most of your attacks, so you have to be careful to play conservatively.  At the same time, you'll eventually become strong enough to where you can and should try to stay in real time more often, which works out well since your time-stop ability can leave YOU vulnerable if you're not careful.You can only equip a few of your skills as hotkey actives at once, and dying restores your health but disables one of your remaining skills until either you have none left, or you win the battle and make a certain amount of forward progress in the game.  This arguably leaves you even worse off than if you'd simply been forced to restart the fight, which you can also choose to do from the pause menu.  (Note that a few areas place you in big battles right after long interactive cutscenes without giving you a save point first; since battles can sometimes be immediately repeated, try not to hit "Retry" on impulse if circumstances turn against you.)  Enemies usually don't have a lot of defensive immunities, though, which is great about keeping you from feeling penalized for using a certain play style.  They're also smart enough to be aware of one another and to know how to protect and even heal each other.More importantly, skills never feel redundant, and they're designed to play off of each other, not to exist in isolation or to be used at random.  Your abilities have their own slots where they can plug into one another and change each other's properties.  One skill fires long-ranged arrows when put on a hotkey, but it can also be plugged into other skills, which usually increases their range.  You can later do the same thing with your own character, which grants additional benefits like a deflector shield or a health recharge--one of the few you'll get, so don't take it for granted.There are no character classes in Transistor, but the wonderful skill system allows you to customize and change up your play style throughout the game.  If you want to play a stealthy assassin, a somewhat tanky gunner, or a manipulator who turns enemies against each other, you have quite a few options to choose from.  The variety of different animations and graphical effects for the huge number of potential skill combinations is simply stunning--these aren't just throwaway stat boosts here--and it makes your abilities feel almost like they physically affect one another rather than simply doing whatever the game tells them to do.  I might have overlooked a way to do this, but it would be nice to be able to simply click an upgrade slot and see my various effect options at a glance, instead of just clicking on a skill itself and seeing the various places it could go.  In other words, "I know what ability I want to augment, but not specifically how I want to do so."2) This is one of my favorite parts.  Skills are connected to different characters and their individual stories, and while I sometimes don't like when a game presents a lot of its story through text, this method is genius--your abilities' text logs are divided up into parts that must be uncovered by equipping your skills in different ways.  Use one ability in its active mode to get one piece of text, then use that ability to upgrade another and get the next piece of text, and so on.  Hence, the game rewards and demands experimentation if you want to read all of the background info.  You can't get too comfortable with a certain battle strategy you like, since you have to constantly rearrange your skills and try new things with them in order to get the most out of the story, let alone the battles and their fairly sharp challenge curve.  It feels a lot more involving than simply having info dumps thrown at you because you discovered an unfamiliar character or area.Speaking of difficulty, you can customize it to some extent by turning on various options you earn called Limiters, which increase your rate of experience gain but also help your enemies out in some way.  Have fun turning them all on at once, achievement-lovers!When you're not battling, you navigate the deserted but absolutely beautiful streets and alleys of the city of Cloudbank, and I can't tell you how refreshing it is to play an adventure that takes you by multicolored, modern-looking restaurants, residential areas, and concert halls as opposed to yet another fantasy forest/desert/cave.  The city feels lived-in and familiar while still maintaining its own distinctive touches, such as weather and sky color being up to a popular vote, which you can take part in.  You'll be taking gorgeous, probably wallpaper-quality screenshots almost constantly--I have almost as many screenshots saved from 20 hours of Transistor as I do from 150 hours of Dota 2.  Even in the few cases where the game's tendency to not always explain itself makes for some genuinely weird encounters, the journey never stops being compelling and never overstays its welcome.The main story isn't that long, and while you'll fly through it on New Game Plus (especially if you turn off all the limiters after finishing the character-level achievements like I did), the various "challenge room"-style quests will keep you up at night.  My favorites were the planning tests, where you're given a specific loadout and tasked with clearing an area in one turn, which implicitly teaches you new strategy ideas and lets you play around with skills you don't always have immediate access to.  Woe be to those who forget to take notes.The soundtrack, which Supergiant was wonderful enough to post on YouTube -- 


YouTube™ Video: Transistor Original Soundtrack - Full Album 

			Views: 2,409,293		

			Get the full OST at: http://store.supergiantgames.com/ Transistor on PS4: https://t.co/VGnF4ftlK3 Transistor on Steam: http://t.co/VvIzpwCnsk Note: We highly recommend playing through the game before...		

 -- is for the most part spectacular, even though some of the more intense songs sound better while in the context of the game, like when you're busy running from something dangerous.  Ashley Barrett's vocals are indescribably wonderful, and the game even gives you a dedicated button for humming along to the background music, which gets put to genuinely awesome use at times.------Transistor, despite perhaps having room for more detail in the main plot, crams more visual and musical identity into its small but thoroughly memorable scale than I can recall from a lot of much bigger games, and even without the wonderfully fun Turn() system, the skill combinations and the wonderful production values make the combat more special than any number of hotkey bars ever will.  As of this writing, the game is currently on sale for $7, but I'd say it's easily worth its $20 asking price if you don't mind a product that exchanges length for sheer specialness.  Pick this up right away!

												Transistor is at the same time very similiar to and very different from Bastion. Once again the game starts in a city where some kind of catastrophic event took place and the hero must fight it and maybe find a way to undo it. You'll recognize the art style and the familiar voice of Logan Cunningham guiding you through the game, this time not as the narrator but as a companion. Even with all the similarities, Transistor ia a very different experience. The setting is much more futuristic. Everything in the game is related to programming language and sometimes you wonder if the city of Cloudbank is a real city or just some kind of complex metaphor. The battle system has a unique mix of action and strategy. Every skill (called function in the game universe) can be placed in an active or passive slot. Besides that, every skill can upgrade another skill, or even itself, leading to a huge amount of possibilities to choose from. The only negative aspect of the game is that it'll take about half the time to finish it if compared to Bastion. There is a Recursion Mode that works like a NG+ where you can start the game again retaining the level and skills from the previous run but that's it. Besides that minor flaw, Transistor is still a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												From the organic ways of Bastion, from the bush and jungle, from levels created by tiles floating up beneath you, we get Transistor. Where the style has evolved into a futuristic, neon-lit, already built level. The world does no longer face the problem of falling apart, but instead it is losing it's style. “The Process”---the equivalent of “The Calamity” in Bastion---covers the creativity made from humans, with a grayscaled and blocky veneer, which seems detrimental to this particular game, where style is easily the highpoint of the experience. The music this time around leaves the closeness of acoustic guitar picking(except for the beach soundtrack) and goes for a more distant, electronic and futuristic atmosphere. Distorted electric guitars and heavy bass lines accorded with ambiance make Transistor a sonically sound experience. The story is very reminiscent of Bastion, but yet completely different. Transistors style and sound design, as with Bastion, perfectly accompanied each other. At points I felt like the levels were specifically made with the soundtrack in mind, because it was so eerily well thought out. We start of as Red, a singer that lost her voice(it found its way to the soundtrack, though). Standing above a man with a sword in his chest. This sword can talk to us, and also play the roll as narrator. Why only this man can speak through the weapon is unknown to me, since the player ingest other fallen men and women and gain powers through this procedure, but not their voices as with the first body. At this point of the game we don't know who this man is or why we should follow his advice or directions, but it's a game, so we do it anyway. We progress through the levels and gradually begin to understand the situation, “The Process” was a failed experiment from “The Camerata” and the city is conveniently told to evacuate, so we can have that barren emptiness that is so effective when it comes to atmosphere. And The Process is what haunts us throughout the game. As we try to get to the bottom of what happened. The vagueness and convolution of the story straddles the line of being annoyingly vague and mysterious and intriguing. Where at some points I feel the story would be better told if you knew some of the things you are told in the end. That would make everything feel more natural. In this mysteriousness, the story was overshadowed by the stylistic choices and obligatory gameplay sections. It's unfortunate when Transistor could have been both if they just dropped any pretensions of being deeper and having more substance than there really was. When you get to the end of this two hour game, things will be rather clear, but you will also feel like there should be more, where there are hints and ways the story could have gone that were never shut down or explored in a satisfying way. Despite it not feeling as fulfilling as it seemed to have the potential for, it was enjoyable and the game easily grabbed you and kept you interested up until the end. The gameplay seems to be a rather contentious subject. I for one, sort of liked it. You could play it like in Bastion, hack and slash, designing your “build” for this purpose. Or you could go a more tactical way, as with a controller I thought would be more suiting. And it was! Although the combat often boiled down to using your tactical slow down time mechanism, killing one foe to then run around, trying not to die until the cooldown ran out, I really enjoyed it. There was tension in that way of playing, trying to just avoid getting hit, spamming RT. While some abilities seemed useless to me, most of them were used at some point due to the fact that you lose an ability when you lose all your health. This was a clever way of making the player use all the different devices, but it's equally as dumb when you have you remake your whole build every time you “die”. The frustration of having to go in to the these access points and try to manage your attacks when half of the things you want to use are unusable somewhat breaks immersion. See Transistor tries to squeeze in a whole bunch of different attacks and combinations into, what was for me, a two hour experience. Perhaps if the game was longer and had more uses for some of the attacks, this wouldn't be so jarring and above all boring. However, when you had the attacks you wanted, with the combinations and everything, the gameplay was a lot of fun. Beautiful colors emitted from every blow, cool sound design and every attack felt more or less powerful, but alas, that didn't mean they were. All in all it's neat parcel. Well worth it for the creativity. The clumsiness of some decisions didn't come close to ruining the experience whatsoever. So it's a worthy successor to Bastion, and it will probably stay in the same place in my mind as Bastion. As a memory of a stylistically and sonically amazing experience, while the gameplay and storytelling will surely fade out of the collective memory, sooner or later.

Posted: May 29, 2014
												It's difficult but try to forget that Supergiant games made Bastion; whether you liked Bastion or not is not indicative of how you will feel about Transistor.Obvious points out of the way: sublime art and music. The aesthetics are scintillating, the backgrounds and world are meticulously detailed. The characters and enemies are well animated and designed, mirroring the world around them. There's a very strong noir vibe seeping through what often feels like cyberpunk New York as imagined by Europe. There's every chance I'm just projecting my desire for Remember Me to have been a good game, but I digress.The gameplay is solid, provided you realise that operating outside of Turn() is very rarely the best option. Transistor gives you a lot of different skills and variety of ways to combine them allowing you to play however you want, additionally the game encourages you to mix up your skills so that you can unlock character information and the "Performance Tests" force you to improvise with randomly selected skills. Unfortunately towards the end of the game encounters become quite repetitive and even with enemies evolving it is rare that whatever combo you've perfected by that point won't be just as effective as before. New Game+ is genuinely challenging but by then you are even furthered hampered in choices and will be extremely reliant on a few exceptional skills to get you through the encounters, especially with limiters on.It is unfortunate to say that the story and characters feel like the weakest aspect of Transistor. You're dropped into the world with no knowledge of anything, and as you progress you slowly uncovers scraps of information by way of skills and terminals. The game is quite short too, and ultimately it can be quite difficult to become truly invested in either the world or characters. After talking with people and going through the NG+, there are a few nuances that are illuminated and can be appreciated but the story never takes that final step.Transistor is a good game. The worst thing you could say is that it is not Bastion. Regardless of who you are you should approach with caution and pay special attention to all the little details, from the art to the written and spoken dialogue.

												Transistor, from the makers of Bastion, both games are among my favorites. Transistor and bastion have many similarities, and many differences. While bastions combat is based on weapons, and a couple upgrades for each weapon, in transistor, there is only one weapon, the transistor. Instead, combat is based around skills (functions) to use with the transistor, as well as being able to augment skills by equipping skills onto skills, and providing passive buffs by equipping skills onto yourself, that combined with the turn() function and a lack of environmental clutter made the combat feel a lot more varied and responsive. Unlike bastion, transistor doesn’t have levels with a hub, but rather has you progressing through a world with occasional visits to the ‘Sandbox’. While in Bastion, pretty much all information is centered on The Kid, in Transistor, everything is surrounding Red, but not really centered on her. The story is delivered in a similar, but different manner. Again, like Bastion, Transistor is not a particularly long game, around 8 hours. However, it’s well worth investing yourself into. P.S. gorgeous soundtrack, with or without hum tracks is subjective, personally I like them with humming, but even if you don’t plan on getting it, give the ost a listen.

												Transistor, a cyberpunk themed action RPG made by Supergiant Games is set in a futuristic city called “Cloudbank”. You take the role of “Red”, a young women who gains control of an extraordinary weapon. After a mysterious group nearly kills you, you start your journey, slowly puzzling the story. The art style, music, and narration create a gorgeous, astonishing and captivating place you want to be part of. Beautifully drawn and rich locations where every step is a pleasure to the eyes, the amazing music by Darren Korb, the fantastic voice acting by Logan Cunningham and the memorable, intriguing characters which grow to your heart are not the only aspects that the game has to offer. The combat is remarkably fun and fresh. While you only have one weapon, there are dozens of "functions" which you collect on your journey through Cloudbank. Those functions act as perks which can be  combined with each other and/or used either aggressively or passively matching your playstyle.All  in all Transistor is a masterpiece and is probably my favourite indie game. Not only I recommend on buying the game but the gorgeous soundtrack it offers which is absolutely worth it.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												*Acknowledgment*Before I delve into my review of Transistor, let me first state that I am first and foremost a tremendous fan of Supergiant Games. They released Bastion in a time I had ceased playing video games, because I found the quantity over quality insignia that most modern games paraded to be a bit much to bear. With that one release they managed to quickly overturn my decision to abstain from video games. So let me just say (to my own fault) that I have a very soft spot for the company and the diligent employees they keep.*End Acknowledgment*- With the acknowledgment in mind, I would like to begin with the good about Transistor.The strongest point for the whole game, in my opinion of course, is the soundtrack produced by Darren Korb. I could create a lengthy description for this, instead, I will just tell you “listen to the soundtrack”. The man is probably one of the best composers in video game culture, that is all.The artwork of Jen Zee is a wonderful thing to behold, and deserves to be seen. This game is no exception to that. As well, as always, Logan Cunningham's voice acting is an equal treat.The setting, world building, and most of the story are solid and deserve recognition.These things all speak strongly for themselves and no words I can put to them will do them justice.- Now with the bad.The battle system, while tremendously innovative, is irritating at best. I respect their attempt, but it clearly needed a great deal more work for creating a sense of balance. It contains all of the elements of strategy and turn-based RPGs that could be considered bad, without any of the rewards, progression, or smoothness. All in all, I feel that this aspect alone could have used at least another few months of consideration, if not a year, as it just feels hastily prepared and self-righteous.The length of the game adds to the feeling of speedy preparation without consideration. Now don't get me wrong, There are some situations where a small number of episodes, or a few hours of your time can move a piece of multimedia to create a lengthy wake of contentedness. This is not one of those cases and while replay is certainly an option, I feel completely no urge to do so. They try to expand the game with a number of puzzle based battle-challenges to unlock songs within the game, but that would bring us back to the battle system.The last of what I say rests with the story. This section contains a number of ***spoilers,*** so you should move on if you do not want this portion of the game revealed and I will post when spoilers are finished. As a majority, the story is interesting, explorative, and at many points, compelling. There are a few points within it, however, that while I understand most probably lend themselves to a particular ideology or thematic pursuit, are what I feel to be gargantuan mistakes in not only the story of the game, but in writing as a whole.With the exception of Royce, each and every confrontation with the Camerata was unfulfilling, if not completely vapid of context. The characters are introduced in a very dynamic scene where they murder Red's implied and nameless lover, which is roughly the most substance you are going to get from them. The battle with Sybil is almost confusing because it feels out of place and unexplored. We do have the before mentioned cut scene, yes, but that is all we have at that point and all we get. Then we move on to Asher, and the seemingly implied arch-nemesis, Grant. Here we receive a number of communications with Asher along the way, which seem to be imploring you to garner at least a little bit of sympathy, if not just understanding for these characters. However, finally reaching them and discovering they had committed suicide, without properly introducing these supposed antagonists was (pardon my language) a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor story decision and shows (with evidence from the fantastic story writing in Bastion) that this was either a very unconsidered, or very lazy writing decision. I must apologize for my harshness in this respect, but I feel like I can give nothing but honesty to a company who's work I am so partial of.I must say that all of the confrontation/interaction with Royce felt incredibly well developed and was by far the most interesting part of the entire tale (with a lot of good progression leading up to it).  However, the suicide of Red not only seemed entirely uncharacteristic of a protagonist who pursued the Camerata so vigorously despite her nameless lover beckoning her not to, and who also fought so desperately to prolong her life against Royce's assail to emerge to a world she can attempt to make a better place, but it also felt like an incredibly unnecessary punch to garner some strong emotional response. At pulling on heartstrings, Red's death was certainly success, but it was at the cost of abandoning all character and story development up to this point.Now if there is an alternate ending I am unaware of, I would be willing to explore further. With things as they are though, I don't see my self playing this game again at any point in the near future.***end spoilers***I had to take a lot of time to mull over how precisely I felt overall with this game, and as much as I truly desire to give this game a thumbs up, I am needing to go with the opposing thumbs down.I do wish Supergiant a great deal of success and hope that any future releases are true gems that speak for the greatness that I know they are ultimately capable of. Also, perhaps my response to Transistor may be best summed up by the Buddhist phrase “Expectation is the root of all disappointment”. Many people are really loving this game, and I will continue to have my gamer soft-spot for Supergiant Games, but in continuing with honesty, this game needed more development and consideration for gameplay and story and I'll just have to sit-back an enjoy the soundtrack and artwork while waiting for the next release.
