												WARNING: SLIGHT SPOILERS, SO IF YOU HAVE WEAK METABOLISMS, READ THE LAST PARAGRAPH!!!Supergiant Games have done it again. Transistor is a beautiful game that blends both gameplay and story so fluently that I forget that I am playing a game at times. The story begins with a mute singer who has just experienced her attempted murder, only to be saved by a bystander. The savior's voice and soul are transferred to the sword, which she carries around to find out what is happening to her city, and off you go.One thing that stood out to me was the narrator's voice this time around makes more sense to actually hear, instead of Bastion's narrator, who you just sort of, could hear all the time for no real explanation. I know this really wasn't much of an issue in Bastion, but I like to see how the writers have grown up even more than Bastion's amazing story, which leads to another improvement: terminals. We've all been there trying to collect audio logs, but this time around, it's a bit different. Since Red has no voice, these terminals provide ways to communicate with the Transistor, which gives the player more motivation to go after them, rather than just skim over the story. Personally, I think this is a genius way to integrate both the present and the past stories of the game into one.With such a great story, there has to be some glitches involved. My main problem is after the ending. And don't get me wrong, I LOVED the ending. I never thought how that would be the end, and it was a good conclusion to the arcing story between Red and her sword. But the problem is afterwards, the Recursion. In Bastion, there was a reason to play it over, as there were references to how you ended the game before, and as such have a different experience as before. But now, the game was ended with only one choice, so there really was no point to replay it, except for gameplay value. I guess the developers were going for a more linear story, which is perfectly fine, but I just expected a similar weave to the story as Bastion.Now, I mentioned gameplay before, and it is good. Not amazing, but good. It takes Bastion's hack-and-slash type and mixes a bit of turnbased action. When a Turn is activated, one can move freely across the field setting up attacks, using up your meter above to do so. Once you are done, you then watch your actions and hopefully dominate the field. The catch with using this system is that you must wait for the meter to fill up again before you may attack again, in Turn or out of. I find that is a good balance, but if you aren't able to dominate a powerful enemy in your Turn, then you are pretty much screwed. Luckily for me, I actually liked the Turn system, but if you don't, you may not have fun with the game, especially towards the end with Man enemies, and the final boss. Which brings up what happens when you die. When Red is defeated in a battle (hence the Turn meter is down and you lose all health), she loses a function that you have under the abilities bar, and you can't get it back until you reach two different function stations. This is an interesting aspect, but it can be quite annoying, as it is often random on what you lose. For example, I once lost my main attack function, and was left with my dodge and my load functions, which do nothing in battle without a good attack. I guess this is the point as it punishes you for losing rather than just spawning you to the last checkpoint, but in my eyes, it is ultimately just wasting my time as it adds not much towards my experience except annoyance.Another issue is the extensive upgrade system. There were many combinations that one could make with their functions, but the problem was the GUI. You had to go through each function one at a time to see what upgrade you could add to a function. This could've been simply fixed by the ability to compare the upgrades with each function, rather than the other lengthy way. Not much of an issue, but it can be hectic near the ending when you have ten functions you have to go through at a time.Lastly, the art style. Remember Bastion's art style? How alive the world felt? Well, magnify that by 10, and add some city elements towards the environment, and you got Transistor. The colors vibrate off the screen, and you wish that the city, maybe even the enemies, were existent. Really, there isn't much to say, but to just look at. I once just stopped playing and watched the background for a good minute. The artists know to not mess with a good formula, and luckily they didn't.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------NO MORE SPOILERS AFTER, LAST PARAGRAPH/VERDICTTransistor truly adds more to the Bastion formula, but it still latches a bit too closely towards Bastion. However, this isn't a bad thing, as Supergiant Games are playing it safe and not making a completely different game, which is what we want. We want the same feel of atmosphere from Bastion, which we got with more interactions but less replayability. We want the same gameplay feel, which we got with more options but less hack-and-slash. And we want the same story and experience, which we got with more passion but less nonlinearity. So, do I recommend Transistor? If you liked Bastion and like a bit of change, you'll love this new addition. I sure did.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Another great game by Supergiant Games, though very different from their first, Bastion.The combat in Transistor involves a highly flexible ability system that lets you mix and match your abilities to create new abilities that play out in real time combat with some turn based elements. The combat constantly makes players choose when the optimal time to use their slotted abilities are, and when to use the planning mode (a mode that freezes enemies while you queue up and then execute some abilities before the enemies get to move again) as using abilities or planning mode can put things on cool down and make you vulnerable for follow up.However the combat does start a bit slow as you only start with a couple abilities and unlock both more abilities and more upgrade slots (the slots that let you combine abilities) as you go, so it starts slow but picks up fast as you go along. Similarly enemies are very easy at the start and most players will find fights fairly easy till most of the upgraded late game enemies start showing up. If those still aren't enough for you, you can activate "Limiters" which are optional and make the game even harder (such as spawning more enemies and make them do 2x damage).The story is very good and personally I enjoyed it even more than Bastion, though it is done very differently. Where Bastion gave the player a lot of knowledge, including knowledge the players character wouldn't know, and all but held the players hand through the story, Transistor gives you story through the eyes of it's characters, and it's up to the player to gain an understanding of what is going on in the story through the information their character is given throughout the game. This gives the story greater depth and immersion, but can also make the story more difficult for some people to understand or for those who skip through a lot of the dialogue. If you want to know everything about the in-game world then you might not enjoy the story of Transistor, however if you like to see a story from the view of a character present at the time and immersion that can bring, then you will probably find the story of Transistor amazing.Finally the length of the game runs about 5-6 hours. There is NG+ (and I hear NG++, though I haven't quite gotten there yet) and you can get further upgrades for playing NG+ so if you enjoy the gameplay there is some incentive to play past the ending of the story (you can get a couple hours of gameplay just trying out different ability loadouts with the amount of combinations available), though if you only want the game for story then there isn't much incentive for multiple play throughs unless you want to revisit the story.In summary the game is simply amazing. Both the combat and the story have a lot of depth to them. Though players who want the story spelled out for them or more twitch based combat may want to consider looking elsewhere. For those coming from Bastion know that this game is great as well but it is also VERY different, so don't expect Bastion 2.0 in a sci-fi setting, both the gameplay and story are done in a very different fashion so be sure to keep that in mind if you decide to pick it up.

												Transistor is one of those artsy-fartsy games that also happen to have great mechanics. You get to mix, match, and augment abilities together in probably hundreds of different ways, so you can create your own unique fighting style or try someone else's optimized build. The art and music are top notch, as other reviews will undoubtedly remark on. Some of the songs were catchy enough that they resurfaced in my mind weeks and months later, and I couldn't recall what they were from, only that it must have been good.The character design is also worthy of praise, especially the dynamic duo of protagonists: A singer who's lost her voice, and a sword who's lost everything but his voice.The setting could be considered cyberpunk, but to me it has more of a computer programming theme as there are analogous concepts that are more easily understood by the technologically literate. Transistor's story can be confusing and a tad controversial, but I'm of the opinion that it had plenty of depth. If you like puzzling things out in your games you'll love it, if not then you might still enjoy the gameplay. It's relatively short if you're not into the whole "new game plus" thing. So why not dive into Cloudbank's pseudo-digital ocean and see if you can swim.

Posted: May 23, 2014
												The world looks amazing, the music throughout the game absolutely wonderful, and the gameplay solid, deep, varied and interesting. The amount of skills and the possible different combinations that you get are mind boggling, and most have very significant effects on the way you play the game. Combat can be done strategicaly with the Turn mode, or just plain old regular real time action, and are just equally as viable and fun!Though you are presented with a central plot, much of the lore is tied to the gameplay in an interesting manner and presented in a way that not only allows you the freedom of choosing how much of it you want to read/see/hear, but also adds to the sublime world Supergiant has created. The game has atmosphere, it has character, and it's a testament to how good Supergiant is at building a world, which in my opinion, is second to none.Despite how different this game is from Supergiant's previous game, Bastion, to compare both games is inevitable. Cloudbank is in most ways busier than the areas surrounding Caelondia, but its aethetics are darker and more muted. The music in Transistor is a bit more synthetic compared to the more instrumental nature of Bastion's music, but is no less wonderful. Gameplay wise, Transistor outperforms Bastion in every which way, offering more options and a more fleshed out combat system. Narrative wise though, it feels like Transistor falls short of Bastion by way of being just slightly less coherant and emotional. But, it is still really well done and stands on its own really well.My only complaints about the game is how short it is, because I find myself just wanting MORE. While Recursion mode (New Game+) satisfies my desire for more gameplay, I also want more of the story, more of the music, and more of the world. Also, the game sometimes fails to explains the mechanics of its skills properly, leaving you to either figure some things out for yourself or consult a guide.  Should you play this? Absolutely. Definitely do consider buying the soundtrack alongside the game, but do not hesitate to give the music a listen first by way of free streaming courtesy of Supergiant themselves. I only wish the soundtrack had the different variations of all/most of the songs, such as the BGMs with Red humming to them, or the instrumental versions of a few others.http://store.supergiantgames.com/products/transistor-original-soundtrack-digitalUPDATE: Supergiant has released an extended version of the soundtrack with the aforementioned humming and instrumental verions.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Mini Transistor review (spoiler free): I'll start out by saying a lot of love went into that game. The music, sound design, voice acting, and overall art direction are top notch, which is all the more impressive when you find out that a team of twelve built this game from the ground up. The painted world feels just as beautiful as Bastion's, even though you won't be visiting locations that are as varied.The combat can be a little confusing at first do to the sheer number of ability combinations and the amount of planning that's involved, but you definitely get the hang of it with some experimentation. You will feel kind of limited initially since you won't have enough "memory" to equip and use all your abilities with passives and upgrades. As a result you will be sitting there with a lot of your ability, upgrade and passive slots empty, even at the end of the game. The difficulty feels like it scales quite nicely. As the game progresses enemies will upgrade in parallel with you, gaining new abilities as you gain tem yourself. And if you feel like the game is still too easy you can equip "limiters" (similar to the shrines in bastion) to make the enemies more difficult, which allows you to get a bonus to experience. I did wish there was an easier way to see some of your stats. You will have to do a bit of digging in order to find out what exactly what your health, damage, ability cost, and turn() values are.I clocked the game in at around 10 hours, though I spent a lot of time tinkering and trying to figure out the best combinations of abilities, upgrades and passives, and I did all the challenges you can unlock initially. I thought the story was a little weaker than bastions in that you have to do a lot more investigating to figure out exactly what's going on and the world doesn't feel as integrated with the gameplay. After beating the game I felt like I knew the broad strokes of  what was going on, but I felt like there are definitely some gaps to fill. Hopefully with new game+  I will uncover some new information. With all that being said, its still a great bittersweet tale to experience.TLDR: Great game, decent  story, good blend of action and strategy, and awesome art direction. 8.5/10

												...This game is a work of art. From the gorgeous style, to the genre choice, to the fantastic music, to the characters who initially just seem like ghosts of what they could be, yet slowly grow on you. This is the quality of game and the determination to make a fantasy that stands out amongst other dreams real for us gamers. I highly recommend this game, and I'm not entirely sure what audience I could think of that wouldn't find something appealing here. Talking swords, sci-fi, angry hardware trying to take over the world, over-eager scientists, lasers, giant explosions, godzilla-esque monsters, and VERY frustrating hairstyles... yeah, this game has a lot of nice quirks worked in all throughout. You'll love it.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Transistor excels in so many ways, I don't even know where to start.It essentially accomplished what a game means most to me: innovative gameplay mechanics, good storytelling, and state-of-the-art visuals, design, and music. But what makes Transistor stands out so much is that it demonstrated immense strength in all of the areas.Game MechanicsAt first, it seems like a generic hack-and-slash game (that is, you simply walk around and beat things up with your "skills"). That's not how half of Transistor works. Later it will reveal a new mechanic that allows you to literally pause the game and plan out your next actions. This is the true beauty of Transistor: you get the action-packed combat mixed together with a strategic problem-solving manoeuver, allowing you to experiment on how you can chain together different moves, and knowing which combo is best used for which situation.In Transistor, you get to equip 4 "skills" at a time, known as Functions. Functions works in such a way that each function could be operated either as an Active slot, an Upgrade to enhance your Active Function, or a Passive slot that grants you certain perks in combat. Once you get a number of Functions, the possiblities of Function combinations are endless. This is where Transistor truly shines, and after finishing this game twice, I have probably yet to discover hundreds of other possible Function combinations to work on.The ArtSupergiant Games is renowned for its stunning visual art and unforgettable soundtracks, and Transistor is the best example you can get. All the background art you see in the game is hand-painted, and every music piece is woven seamlessly to the game. Besides, Supergiant Games made a really sweet move of creating the main character as a singer. Almost all the elements of the game revolved around her music — your character lost her voice and you're determined to get it back, you get to hear her humming to her own tunes, and you could unlock in-game soundtracks which you can play anytime. Basically, music is an integral part of Transistor, and Supergiant Games did an amazing job on this.Transistor's backstory may seem mediocre at first, but everything slowly unravels, and it all builds up until the last chapter (watching the end credits broke my heart into pieces). The story was presented in such a way that you have to head to different spots along the landscape and get a hint of what's going on. Even each Function actually originates from a character, so each Function has a story to tell. In order to fully appreciate the story, I suggest you inspect all the Functions and every nook and corner you find (or simply head over to the wiki, everything is there). There's also a sword that talks. Nothing is better than a talking weapon.ConclusionI believe that Transistor is the hallmark of an innovative game produced by creative minds. It's not something you get to see very often in these few years, so I fully recommend it to anyone who loves games as a means of entertainment and artistic expression.TL;DR, Transistor excels in every aspect, innovative and refreshing game mechanics, great artistical value, and nothing beats a talking sword.

												Another quality experience from SuperGiant Games.  The gameplay itself was solid.  Being able to mix and match all of the existing powers in so many ways had a great sandbox feel to it.  However, all of the enemy encounters were very scripted, limiting how long you could experiment.  It saddened me a little that the gameplay was confined to these short bursts of action.  I'm not sure if it was done this way in order to preserve the points of narration, or becuase the art was just so good, from such a small studio.  I wonder if the game may have felt longer if the presentation of the combat had been approached differently. However, the combat that was there was very enjoyable, with lots of quirks to explore.  The music, art, and story were all superb.  But, these only feel on par because of what was sacraficed to attain them - gameplay and length of the game. The new game+ is required to get all of the game's achievements, yet doesn't add anything of value except for more gameplay.  This feels lazy to me, the gameplay should have been scaled for a single playthough instead of forcing the player to loop through again.  It might have some significance to the story, but that doesn't justify forcing the player to do everything again.  But for all of the picking I'm doing, I do recommend the game.  The first time I played it through, the experience was incredibly tight, the story sucked me in, and I was equally enthralled by the gameplay and the art.  I recommend this game, but maybe wait for the steam sales.

The art and soundtrack in this game are oozing with a cyberpunk style, with the same bold, colour saturated graphics of the successful "Bastion". Posted: December 27, 2014
												Following from their smash debut hit, Bastion, Supergiant Games raises the bar with yet another incredible title.Transistor boasts uniquely hand-drawn artwork and visuals (which catches the eye with splashes of color and design), an absolutely fantastic soundtrack (which reacts and changes seamlessly according to ambience, scripted events, character progression and actions), simple yet complex mechanics (isometric viewpoint similiar to Bastion, but with an added layer of turnbased combat, as well as mergeable skills and abilities), on top of another astounding narrative and a deeply layered plotline. Transistor is a carefully crafted product, lovingly refined and polished by a dedicated, creative and passionate team of developers, as well as an exceptional performance by Darren Korb and vocalist Ashley Lynn Barrett. Transistor is unfortunately a very short game (but as was previously seen in Bastion), comes complete with specific attributes or "upgrades" resulting in a much tougher experience. Transistor also incorporates another layer of replayability - Recurse, which allows you to replay various parts of the story, or if preferred, new game plus.All in all, Transistor is an absolutely fantastic, creative and unique video game and is deservedly a masterpiece in indie development! I highly recommend Transistor and it's seperately sold soundtrack as they are both most definitely worth the money and the time.

												Transistor has seriously become one of my favourite games of all time. Supergiant were criticised as a one-hit wonders with Bastion but they have come back with the artistic tour-de force that is Transistor. Through the wonderful handpainted art of Jen Zee and the beautiful tones of Darren Korb's soundtrack, you really get sucked into the abtract city that is Cloudbank and it's atmosphere. Transistor captures that fleeting moment of Red and The Transistor trying to make it through alive and to get to the bottom of everything. The pacing is on form, some people say its quite short (at 7 hours) but I feel its enough to tell the story that it needed to tell without overstaying its welcome. The world and characters gell so well and all feel completely new, helped by the wonderful narration and chemistry between the characters.Transistor isnt just all pretty picture, the ability system is quite different and completely customisable and promotes experimentation for completely different playstyles and the punishment for dying in game is one of the most original I've seen and actually adds to the experimentaion of the abilities.In short, to me Transistor feels like a masterpiece of a painting with a wonderful story, good solid gameplay mechanics and a soundtrack ties it up into one fantastic and intelligently beautiful experience.Transistor is a game that will stick with me for years to come, and for that Supergiant, thank you.(I played this game completely offline so thats why my gametime in it is ~0 hours)

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Riding very much off the coat tails of Supergiant's previous beloved, Bastion, Transistor has at least been built with some articulation of what made the spiritual predecessor so compelling. An absolutely gorgeous hand-painted cityscape with a woozy yet full-bodied soundtrack makes it clear Supergiant knew what the first thing that came to player's minds were. Throw in another smoky voiced narrator voice to follow the antangonist through to the end of the journey, and it would seem Transitor is on to another winner.Well... it fails in a couple of fundemental ways. Yes, we can recall the lovely artstyle, music, *that* voice actor for Bastion, but part of the universal charm was the slick, smooth combat to follow up on a compelling storyline. The former is failed with Transistor, exchanging for a slightly more clunky affair, your character taking a moment to attempt most attacks, even needing to recover from the jaunt ability. The wide variety of upgrades, potions and weapon combinations are exchanged for a universal sword, the namesake of the game, with four primary abilities where you can assign your collected powers as either secondary additions, upgrading potency, number or secondary functions of your powers, and four passive slots. It seems that this could hold a lot of potential, but for the most part those combinations don't surprise or allow for in-depth theorycrafting. You just slap what you like to your abilities, make them more powerful/numerous/have an extra projectile thrown in and mash away. The "Turn()" system also does now allow for much depth, particularly end-game considering how enemies enjoy countering or simply dodging your best laid plans.The story starts off incredibly promising. I was anticipating a very Film Noir experience thrown in to a heavy sci-fi (Read: Not cyberpunk) universe. Alas, it mostly repeats the same apocalyptic overtones of Bastion with an unsatisfactory and, frankly, confusing conclusion that leaves far, far more questions than answers and no clear antagonist to despise, the "Big Bad" showing up very late and with not much moustache twiddling to be had.There are a few neat little touches that I enjoyed: The slick UI and artwork is just as gorgeous as the rendered graphics, you can see other players on their adventure via Dark Souls-esque ghosts around you, and there is even a button to hold to make the protagonist, Red, hum out a lovely counter-melody to whatever soundtrack is playing at the time. There is also, apparently, a procedurally generated post-game series of challenges to experience, but... the gameplay just didn't grab me enough to really care.I can't *not* recommend this game. The narrator, again, just about makes it, and the relationship between him and Red's conclusion enough was sweet enough. It *is* satisfying to watch said best laid plans work out just as you expect and watch a screen full of baddies die in one little turn, and the world, despite confusing and mysterious, is at least dazzling to explore. £15 though? Wait for a sale. Even taking my sweet time I easily steamrolled through this bite-sized treat in six hours.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Transistor, SuperGiant's follow up to the incredible Bastion, somehow manages to improve on their previous offering in every conceivable way.  I'm going to avoid spoilers in this, so I'll be mindfully vague at points.The music is amazing.  I mean, if you just set it out on its own and listened to it, it is brilliant.  However, more than just that, the music is integral to the plot.  They use the music to tell the story via lyrics.  At times plot and music is blended so well it leads you to question whether they are diegetic or non-diegetic, not unlike brilliant pieces of film such as Trois Couleurs.  The graphics are aesthetically wonderful.  Myself, I've never been a big proponent of attemps to use realism in gaming, I far prefer a well done art style that fits the world we're playing in, and style is something that simply oozes out of Transistor.  From the usage of vibrant colours juxtaposed against stark white landscapes in later games to the deco styling prevalent throughout, you will drool over this game if you have any love of comics, art, or cartooning.  Absolutely wonderful.The story is a strong narrative told in an unorthodox way.  I'll be honest, this won't be for everyone.  The story isn't spoonfed to you, you need to work for it a bit.  You have to unlock all 3 facets of all your functions, read between the lines of conversations between characters, listen to all the terminal reports and only then, at end game, do you really start to pull everything together into a functional whole.  If you take the time, however, it does make it worth your while.  The game paints a stark portrait of Orwell mixed with Huxley to create a world of immediate and meaningful gratification that overwhelms the populace's drive for freedom and the ability to stand against a tyranny, whether purposeful or merely incidental, from the people who control it.  Hardly new or different in terms of a story, but told very well and in an interesting way.This game easily creeped into my top 5 of all time, can't recommend it heavily enough.

												This game is a thing of beauty. Like, seriously. If anyone ever tells you that vidyagames aren't art, just show them this lovely.Enough sweet talk, here are the pros 'n' cons:Pros - Gameplay is awesome and appeals to two kinds of players: Strategic ones and the Tanky ones. I loved the planning mode.- Beautiful visuals. The colours fit every scene nicely.- Gorgeous soundtrack that compliments Ashley Barret's voice. While it can be listened on its own, which i do often, the soundtrack reaches its full potential in-game.- Well made story that leaves the user with questions and room to speculate.- The narrative is even better in this one than in Bastion. (Not to say Bastion wasn't great, i loved it to bits) All the one-sided small talk The Transistor does is cute, hilarious, but still melancholic. I can't imagine being in a sword is fun after all.- The secrets you can discover and all the additional info about the residents of Cloudbank is intriguing and the unlocking of them forces the player to switch their playstyle from the usual set.- Great variety in enemies. Whew! That was a lot of pros, here are the cons.Cons - The loss of abilities and attacks or "functions" became frustrating to me. I get it, it makes you switch up your playstyle (which i complimented above), but i hated having to wait to get my favourite attacks back and it crippled me. Interesting gimmick, but not for me.- Many functions seem useless.-The game was unbearably short. Sure, there's always the replay mode that lets you keep your stats and functions, but resets the story. I don't like replaying a story, so not for me. I feel like they rushed the story.- Price is too high, in my opinion. It might be worth it to just get this in a sale. Unfortunately i missed my opportunity, so i decided to slap my wallet at GabeN, since i couldn't wait.  All in all, this game is fantastic. I'd recommend it to everyone and anyone. Just keep the cons i listed in mind.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Transistor is a beautiful game, from the art, world and music. It shows what it would feel like if you were inside the most fancients and most elegant of computer architecture. The is really cute with using computer jargon in it's gameplay and story elements. Such as not having enough memory to load all your functions. The story seems good, but is easily missable, the game emplores you to look for the story via reading the terminals and listening to your transistor blade. Where Transistor really shines is it's combat and difficulty. The combat is very unique while it is in real time there is a turn based element where you can unload a series of attacks simultaneous but doing so will leave you vulnerable to attack. So juggling between the turn based and real time combat is challenging and fun. The side missions which are the speed/perfomance/planning test are optional and quite fun. The planning tests I found the most fun, where you must defeat all the enemies in one turn. I would have like to see more tests and test variety. The games difficulty is dictated by limiters. Which are positive buffs to the enemies or negative buffs on you, you can decide how many are activate. The more that are active the more harder the game is. There is just enough different types of enemies to keep things fresh. I would have liked to see more creative boss battles as well as more of them. The game is quite short clocking around 4 - 5 hours if you're just doing the main story only. But it has a lot of replay value in it's combat and difficulty. Highly recommend if you are looking for a neo noir futuristic RPG which tries something new.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
 If The Great Gatsby were a video game I really don't write a lot of reviews, like, at all. But I enjoyed this game so much; it physically compelled me to do so. Rarely has a video game caused me to spout praises about it to millions of strangers on the interwebs. This one did, big time.  Artistic direction, plot development (no spoilers) It's hard to talk about this game without mentioning the stylized presentation. Transistor shows influences from Supergiant's previous game, Bastion. Whereas Bastion's toon-like presentation contrasted with the somber themes the game explored, in Transistor, the developers made the game feel almost impressionistic. Cutscenes and plot elements are introduced in parts and pieces on a background palette of neon lights and gilded society. Much like how Bioshock gives you the choice of picking up optional voxaphones, the clarifying parts of Transistor's story are introduced via optional newscasts and recordings. The female protagonist looks like she stepped out from the Roaring Twenties, and the game feels and plays like a jaunt through The Great Gatsby if the book also featured murderous enemies at every turn. The protagonist's accomplice will narrate and banter with her throughout the game. Plot elements are introduced organically, and it's almost too easy to feel the emotions behind choices and actions the protagonist takes despite her being pretty much mute for the entire game. I found myself satisfied in almost every artistic aspect.  Music and voice acting The original soundtrack. Is. Awesome. The writter and producer of the soundtrack, Darren Korb, describes the music as "old-world electronic post-rock." Ashley Barrett, who sings many of the lyrical songs in the game, is suberb at giving the protagonist's (past) voice. The music strikes that rare balance where if you stop to appreciate it, it may just steal your breath away, but it's never intrusive when you're getting mauled by enemies in the heat of battle. Narration by the protagonist's accomplice is sassy, hilarious, conversational, and at times heartwrenching. It gives a sense of how the two interacted with one another in the past. Other characters who make appearances are memorable and unique; each character has their own linguistic quirks that differentiate their speakers. Nothing cookie cutter here.   Gameplay Combat is tight, clean, and rewarding. Gameplay happens in real-time, but the protagonist has the ability to pause time and lay out a series of combat moves reminiscent of KOTOR or X-Com. Battle abilities are acquired sequentially through plot and with every level the protagonist gains, and they can be mixed and matched to create endless variability, damage potential, and combat philosophies. Each ability is linked with character backstory that is unlocked through use, which encourages you to try novel combinations of skills. Enemies scale in difficulty reasonably and foes behave logically. They will heal damaged allies. They will buff their tank as he smashes your face in. And they will cause headaches for you if you aren't careful. For added challenge, the game features handicaps that make gameplay much harder but will reward the protagonist bonus experience. There is also a built-in, plot appropriate haven of sorts that the protagonist can access for scenario battles and a sandbox practice mode. After the first playthrough, you have the option of starting over again with a game-plus mode, retaining all progress with enemies starting out much stronger. It is one of the few games where I didn't think twice about playing the game again right after I beat it. And I played it until I got every single achievement and searched every single corner. It made me neglect basic necessities like eating. And sleep. And personal hygiene. And I didn't mind. Overall While writing this review, it was actually quite difficult for me to separate discrete pieces of this game into music, gameplay, etc. It is such a well integrated package that one aspect is in complete alignment with another. Gameplay introduces plot. Narrative augments gameplay. And the art pulls you into the gameplay. And the feels. Oh, does this game have the feels. The only other game that I can remember that has left me feeling like this is Portal. They are both a bit on the shorter side in terms of gameplay length, but the density of gameplay is tremendous. The white dwarf star of games really. Every moment feels meaningful, nothing is drawn out. There are no ♥♥♥♥♥♥ parts to this game. It is pure, concentrated fun with a shot of the feels right where it hurts. But it hurts so good.10/10 would (and did) play this game again (and again). And I honestly think this game is worth its full retail price.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Transistor left me spechless. At the time it came out I didn't even had a chance to put my hands on Supergiant Games Bastion, so I had to play it first, so I could feel the style of its developer. And now that I played both I can say that the game feel was surely saved (if not enhanced). The graphics are just fascinating. Bastion also has great visuals, but the setting here is different and comparing these two is kind of stupid. Can say the same about the music. As a Kid, you had to put up a new home for yourself and the others, you were the only hope, the person that felt kind of sad and scared of the burden, but on the other hand brave and ready for the unexpected. And so is the music. Transistor puts you in a sci-fi city, and the situation Red is in is really tough - her voice is stolen, the man that is close to her heart is stabbed with a somewhat electronic sword, and there is a group of people that are chasing her. Most songs have that post-rock feel to them, which made me melancholic and sad, and relaxed at the same time. But there is one thing I'm sure about - the soundtrack to Transistor is something else.Since it's hard to not to compare it to Bastion, I need to say one thing - it really is a great enchanting game, but Bastion is a bit better, imo. There are not much games that give you goosebumps, but both of the games did that to me. !!Bastion Spoilers!! The part where you're carrying Zulf back to the Bastion, accompanied by the Setting Sale, Coming Home song was much more impressive than the Transistor ending. Maybe the culmination part of Transistor should have the ending song being played during it, but anyway, that's just my opinion. Transistor is still a great game, and it's definitely 10/10. I recommend it to everyone who played Bastion, and to everyone who likes the game's plot to make you slightly sad, but satisfied.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Nota completa en Liberen al Geek (Supergiant Games: Bastion & Transistor): http://liberenalgeek.com/2015/09/01/supergiant-games-bastion-transistor/En el 2013 apareció un pequeño trailer mostrando el nuevo proyecto en desarrollo, Transistor, el cuál nos dejó con muchas ansias hasta su salida un año después. ¿Contexto? Universo Cyberpunk. ¿Protagonista? Red, una famosa cantante a quien le quitaron su voz. ¿Historia? Despertamos al lado de nuestro novio, quien ha sido a♥♥♥♥♥♥ado por una espada, Transistor. ¿Llega al nivel del Bastion? Totalmente pero a pesar de asemejarse en muchos aspectos, también se diferencia en muchos otros.   La ciudad de Cloudbank está siendo atacada por el Proceso, un ejército de inteligencia robótica que está acabando con distintas personas de influencia, como Red. Los responsables de estos ataques son The Camerata, un grupo integrado por cuatro personas interesadas por recuperar la espada y a los cuales perseguiremos en busca de respuestas. El trasfondo de los mismos es muy interesante, cuentan con una personalidad y motivos muy definidos.  La  protagonista no estará sola, ya que el hombre que encontramos a nuestro lado y fue “capturado” por Transistor nos hablará (al estilo de Rucks) y guiará para que descubramos de a poco quién es. O quién era.   El estilo del juego puede parecer similar a simple vista, pero acá se ve un combate mucho más profundo, con la novedad de poder pausar el combate y planear nuestros ataques. En este estado utilizaremos puntos de acción (dependiendo la habilidad nuestros movimientos serán mayores o menores) y tendremos bonificaciones de experiencia si encadenamos combos correctamente.    En esta oportunidad tenemos a nuestra disposición 4 ataques para elegir que iremos encontrando a lo largo del juego y podremos disponer muchas combinaciones entre ellas- ya sea utilizándolas para atacar o para mejorar otro poder-.  En ciertos lugares de la ciudad, podemos acceder a una sala llamada Sandbox, un segmento de playa donde podremos descansar, escuchar canciones del juego mientras disfrutamos una vista increíble (me he quedado horas utilizando este lugar como reproductor de música) y nuevamente aparecen Challenges bastante difíciles, que nos darán experiencia y nuevos tracks para disfrutar.Visualmente es hermoso, no hay otra palabra para describirlo. Cada rincón, personaje, enemigo y detalle brilla por si solo.  Mención especial al soundtrack que nuevamente es un placer para nuestros oídos, con un estilo muy acorde a la atmósfera del juego. Tenemos la posibilidad de hacer que Red tararee la canción que está sonando en ese momento cosa que hará también automáticamente cuando pausemos el combate. Luego de finalizar la historia, desbloquearemos el modo New Game +, en el cuál podemos comenzar de nuevo manteniendo nuestros upgrades e items, pero también sucederán cosas nuevas y aparecen ciertos guiños, lo que resulta en una experiencia distinta y no tan forzosa. El juego en sí no es muy largo y seguro se queden con ganas de más (aunque tiene un final más que satisfactorio),  en todo caso si no están seguros pueden esperar a una oferta y conseguirlo a menor precio  (en mi opinión, vale su full price).

Posted: May 25, 2014
												Wow! What a game! Thrusting you right into the action, Transistor begins with Red and her companion the Transistor; a hybrid magical and technological omnipotent sword. With the Transistor by your side and acting as the narrator, you make your may through CloudBank, a futuristic utopia where everyone has a voice, whether that be what the weather will be, to what food your favorite restaurant will serve that day. But underneath it all something is brewing, and it is up to you to unstir the great storyline that this game has to offer.The game contains very engaging combat that can either be done on the fly, or via a tactical planning phase where the user is allowed a certain amount of actions per turn. Each mode has their own strengths and weaknesses, but while the planning mode may leave you vulerable for a few seconds after you have had your turn to act, it definitely seems to be better in almost all cases over the on the fly version. Although the combat in this game is great, Supergiant Games once again proves that they are king when it comes to art direction. The music in the game is a masterpiece, constantly setting the mood of the game as you progress throughout the many streets of CloudBank. This combined with the stellar hand drawn backgrounds and beautiful 2.5D art style makes it pure audio and visual bliss.Though some may disagree that Supergiant Games have not created a game as good as Bastion, I wholeheartedly disagree. Transistor is something different. Something that cannot be compared to Bastion, and something special that must be experienced by everyone. Get this game, you will NOT regret it.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Better than Bastion?  Maybe.  Like the previous offering from Supergiant Games, Transistor delivers on multiple fronts:1. Visuals: Transistor is aesthetically beautiful in a way that few other games are and if Supergiant continues down this particular road, all of its games will be instantly recognizable.2. Sound: The same awesome narration with a new voice follows us into Transistor.  It's topped off by another beautiful soundtrack from the Supergiant team that you'll want to listen to many times after completing the game.3. Gameplay: Where some might have found the gameplay in Bastion a little simplified, Transistor kicks it up with a hybrid turn-based/real-time combat system, numerous weapon combinations and enemies with unique abilities that make battlefield strategizing more of a priority.4. Story: Perhaps the only place where I could knock this game, Transistor follows in the footsteps of Bastion with a couple interesting twists and a really solid story backed up by bits of in-game lore, but leaves some of the world-building up to player theorizing.  This can be a positive or negative depending on what you're looking for in a game.  Regardless, Transistor still manages to craft a compelling narrative that outstrips a lot of games on the market today.In short: I can't think of any remotely good reason not to buy or recommend this game.  It's a great example of what happens when a group of developers and artists come together with a solid and unique vision and pull it off.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Supergiant's second game has much to live up to. Their first game, Bastion, was a fantastic gem with great storytelling and good, if sometimes frustrating, gameplay. So how's Transistor?It's actually quite different than Bastion, and yet is also similar. The gameplay is no longer a hack and slash spamfest, but a very thoughtful combat system that rewards planning rather than button mashing. Naturally, I prefer this to Bastion and its damned challenges, since i'm not very good at that frantic sort of stuff. You also choose from a variety of abilities for combat, and you can attach other abilities to your "main" ones to make those ones do cool stuff. A favorite example of mine being adding an ability that pulls enemies in and attaching it to a large AoE effect that makes enemies take more damage, giving me this lovely black hole... thing that puts enemies in one place where I can proceed to blast em. Good stuff. :DSo combat is, in my opinion, improved. How about story? Here there is still great quality and that lovely narration, in a different form, like there was in Bastion. It does take some time to unfold however, and until that point you are basically running about killing stuff because... I don't know. Fun? Also the game is rather short, with the main storyline lasting about 6 hours. There are lots of challenges and other stuff, but I cleaned everything out in 16 hours - or about half of my still-unfinished Bastion playthrough. Lastly, the ending was, well, something I have mixed feelings about.Transistor is a good game that improves upon Bastion in some areas (combat, art), maintaing the previous high quality (soundtrack), while weakening slightly in others (story and length). The sum of all the parts however is certainly something worth looking at. If you liked Bastion (and if you didn't you are strange), then go ahead and pick this one up too.Enjoy! :D

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												There is love in this game. Love in the design, the story, the music. The essence of what was great in Bastion has been refurbished to fit the environment of Transistor. They are noticeably similar, but all-together different. Bastion is more of a hack and slash, while Transistor relies on tactics and positioning to make combat the most effective. A familiar aspect, Logan Cunningham, the narrator of Bastion has returned to voice the narrator of Transistor. While the voice is the same, the tone and style of it is noticeably different. "Rucks" of Bastion speaks like a storyteller, full of authoritative power and wisdom. In Transistor, the narrator is a large sword that holds great technological power. This narrator speaks in the constant present, holding conversations, granting advice, but there is a totally different feel to it as it seems like the narrator is more of a changing character than Rucks was. The point that I am attempting to make is that this is not Bastion 2, but still very similar to an experience that was obviously Bastion-esque. It is slower going at the beginning in my opinion than Bastion was, learning the new combat and leveling mechanics, but it is certainly worth the initial learning process. Supergiant Games has made two of the most wonderfully designed games with Transistor and Bastion. It will be worth following their future developments, as they have made unique experiences that are worth supporting. Also, press Tab when you're in the game. It's just that little extra aspect that makes me love this game.

Posted: January 7
												This is one of the best examples that videogames can be art, without sacrifizing gameplay mechanics.The gameplay is pretty tight, you have 4 actions that can be assigned as you see fit, you gain different abilities as you progress, each one with unique properties, like longer range, stun effect, slowing, health leeching, debilitate and more; all of these can be combined with each other in groups of 3 to make a huge tree of combat styles, also you can either move and fight in real time or stop time and plan your next move at the cost of a cooldown period which doesn't allow you to attack so you have to avoid incoming enemies for a while, this gives a tactical aspect that makes you think your moves instead of mindlessly hacking and slashing all over the place.The art style of this game is superb, you could take a screenshot of any frame, whether at combat or a cutscene, and make a wonderful wallpaper; if you liked Bastion's art style, you'll love Transistor's. All the characters have their own unique style at clothing and hairdress, they all have that unique vibe that SuperGiant Games has succesfully trademarked.The soundrack of this game could hold it's own on any music chart, it's beautiful, the game reserves a keybinding to simply make the protagonist stop and hum to the background music, which is amazing. the music has a ciberpunk vibe that suits the whole concept of the game, it's calmed enough to be relaxing even in the middle of a fight. Just like with most aspects of the game, if you liked Bastion's Soundtrack, you'll love Transistor's.On the technical side, I must inform that it has a couple issues, there's only one graphical option: change resolution, meaning if you can't run this game on optimal settings, you can't run it at all. Also I suffered of a couple random crashes after long sessions, and there's some people that can't even get it to launch, but to me these issues haven't ruined the experience the game offersOverall this game is worth every pennie, it's not a long story, but it can be replayed over and over with all the combat posibilities it has, Supergiant Games has earned an honorable spot in the comunity, they are capable of making beautiful works of art and play,

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Just beat Transistor, and I think it's safe to say that yes, it does live up to Bastion in every way.But that's not to say it's just a reskin of bastion as the trailers would have you believe at first glance, because it isn't. It plays very differently; while Bastion tested your reflexes, Transistor will test your pre-planning ability.Transistor has a V.A.T.S.-like core gameplay element that allows you to plan your attacks ahead, but unlike V.A.T.S. from Fallout, using this will leave you very open to attack. Using this function will disallow any offensive action until it recharges; so you must use it effectively because the enemies are much faster than you are. Especially the "Fetch" enemies which are basically like dogs that love to follow you around faster than your evade speed and chomp the ever loving ♥♥♥♥ out of you repeatedly.The soundtrack is very different to bastion. I wouldn't say it doesn't live up to Bastion's, it's just very different in it's genres presented, and that is totally okay because it's still as great as you would expect from Supergiant Games and fits the cyberpunk setting very well. Speaking of the setting, it's beautiful. I love how you get the sense that the creators had this whole other rich, lore filled world planned out in their head but could only make "Just a video game" about it. It's not expositioned to you as most games would do, it's just there, which is exactly what the secret to making a setting like this is supposed to be like, because it means that you get the feeling that even without the main character and their plight, it would still exist. I give this game a "Buy this right now"/10, even despite it's minor hiccups, which I will now list.Every now and again, the game locks up for a few seconds. This is guesswork at best so take it with a grain of salt, but I believe it may be caused by an unoptimized sound cache reset because the dynamic soundtrack is played in chunks of audio that change and layer as you do certain things. It could also be an enemy spawning issue, but again, I don't know for sure. It's so minor and infrequent that it's just worth noting, although not really a bother, since it seems like something that can be patched out. This has only happened in the challenge rooms so far, but some of the enemy capabilities are at odds with good gameplay design when their strengths are combined together. This one time, I accidentally knocked a "Cheerleader" (Basically a radar that makes enemies invincible) next to a vine, which heals other enemies. So the vine was healing the cheerleader, the cheerleader was shielding the vine, and the remaining fetch would go back to the vine to heal itself and be shielded every time I got it's health really low, and transistor time or whatever it's called wouldn't load fast enough to let me finish off the fetch before it did so. I'd show a screenshot of what happened, but there's currently an error with steam that won't let me upload it. Anyway, I had to restart the challenge map, but it never happened again thoughout the entire game.Another thing is that this game, while very enjoyable, should be played in short bursts. I beat it in one 9 hour sitting, and it began to feel repetitive by the end, as any game would. Just when it started to change the enemy variety up by adding in the "Men" which are basically these enemies with special abilities that throw pretty much tracking explosives at you, the game ends. They're fun to fight, but they show up so late game that you barely have time to enjoy their presence, though I'm sure I'll see more of them on my New Game+ playthrough. This one is a nitpick and not really necessary so disregard it if you wish, but: At the end there is a part where you fight an enemy who also has transistor time and can preplan attacks against you. The multiplayer potential for that is amazing, because the fight was actually very enjoyable. I would have loved a 2 player mode for that sequence that you unlock after beating the game, even if it was just local pvp on one PC/Console instead of over the internet, but I understand that there are probably engine limitations and whatnot so it's just a fleeting pipe dream.The story, while very gripping and entertaining, didn't have any characters I could personally relate to or connect with, so when certain things happen throughout the game, I found it hard to really, truly care. But that's probably just because I'm a cynical♥♥♥♥♥hole, the writers told the story they wanted to and they did it effectively, even if some of the characters didn't really get much development outside of the biographies that add to themselves by the end of the game.Aside from these issues though, I fully and wholeheartedly recommend this game. At $19.99 as a brand new price for this memorable experience of a game, you can't go wrong.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												I was surprised how different the gameplay is from Bastion. The combat is mostly turn based and there's no environment hazards other than enemies. The system for selecting skills and upgrades is very unique and really encourages trying different combinations. I like how the complexity grows over time, but never feels overwhelming. It has the same clever system as Bastion for customizing the difficulty with debuffs for rewards.The story is bat♥♥♥♥♥♥insane, even more so than Bastion. It turns out to be a similar sort of apocalypse, but it feels like most of the collapsing is happening offscreen. I don’t really follow how all the character including your own fits into it. At the same time this makes the world feel very massive.I miss the destructible and animating environments of Bastion, but these are incredibly beautiful. All the character an enemy design is wonderful. The music is amazingly good, but is much harder to describe than Bastion’s mix of Indian and Western.It’s tough to live in the shadow of Bastion. This isn’t my favorite game this year and didn’t meet my very high expectations, but I still like almost everything about it and was left wanting more. It probably the most stylish turn-based combat games I’ve ever played. It’s pretty different from almost anything else I’ve ever played including Bastion, so it’s worth experiencing for that.

Posted: May 24, 2014
												Transistor is probably an afterthought to many gamers out there, but to anyone who has played Bastion, this game is a must buy. To those of you who do not know the majesty of Supergiant games, Bastion and Transistor both share epic qualities that seem to be missing from most games today.In the simplest way to define Transistor: this is art, truly inspired art. I'm literally at a loss when it comes to reviewing this game. Supergiant manages to pull you into their story and make you feel like you are a part of it. Each character has some unique facet about them that can intrigue the player. Abilities are explained through some fabrication of a character's life. Everything has its mark in Transistor's world. The story is simply magnificent and a main driving point to the game. As a player, your eyes are met with a glorious palette of colors uniquely blended across the canvas of the game world. Every building, every character, and even every enemy, meshes together in loving unison. Nothing seems out of place and it all looks beautiful. Also, without fail, Supergiant delivers another amazing soundtrack for their game -- to compliment the beautiful scenery and character design, the background music is just as eloquent and wonderous. And to add to the soundtrack even more, the in-game music can be interacted with with the main character. Have you no will to play the game,  the soundtrack alone is worth the price. As short of a review as this may be, Supergiant did not disappoint -- not even in the slightest. I would highly recommend playing Transistor AND Bastion, if you haven't already. Thanks for your time.*Disclaimer: This is an opinion, obviously. You do not need to agree :p

content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												MUSIC AND ARTWORK:Absolutely fantastic.  They do a wonderful job together of drawing you into this surreal world.10/10UI:Flawless.  UI's in games are usually pretty bad, and I'm a UI-stickler.  However, this game's UI was clearly carefully thought-out by a professional.  It always contained all the information I needed, yet was never in the way.  There was never a time I wanted to do something and thought to myself "Crap, how do I do that again?"10/10GAMEPLAY:The fighting in this game looks artificially similar to Bastion, but the ability to pause the action and execute multiple attacks in succession makes it feel completely different.  The battles end up being much more about turn-based tactics than quick reflexes.Different powers are unlocked throughout the course of the game.  Each power can be used as an attack, an upgrade to a different attack, or a passive boost.  This mixing-and-matching opens up a wide variety of strategies for each fight; if one matchup of powers doesn't work well for a fight, you can try again with a *completely* different strategy.  This keeps the game fresh and interesting, even on subsequent playthroughs.On the forums, many people complained about the battles being repetative, but I completely disagree; due to your ability to completely change your lineup of powers, every battle felt fresh and interesting.My one complaint is that you only start out with three (I think?) powers, so you have to wait a short while before you can make the more interesting matchups.  And since the game is so short, "a short while" ends up being half of the game.8/10STORY:This is where things turn sour.  The story in this game is very open-ended, to the point of being lazy.  It's (obviously) difficult to critique the story without giving any spoilers, but suffice it to say there are a LOT of story-elements that are never explained or even hinted at.**Minor spoilers ahead** (but I'll keep things vague to avoid ruining the story)All of the characters are hilariously under-developed, even (or *especially*) the main two.  It's to the point where, when you fight one of the bosses, you not only don't feel anything when they die, you don't even know why you're fighting them to begin with.  Also, one very obvious lead-up to a boss-fight ends in a very contrived, almost non-sensical Deus Ex Machina.As for the the main two characters, you end up not caring what happens to them, because you barely know anything about them.  On top of that, the ending feels incredibly forced and out-of-place.The whole thing reeks of lazy writing.**End of minor spoilers**2/10GAME LENGTH:The game is pretty short - only about 5 hours long, and that's *if* you complete all the side-challenges you can.  The game feels like the creators had planned on there being more content, since all of the side quest-y stuff (unlocking all the character-stories, finishing the side-challenges, the majority of the optional achievements) are impossible to complete in a single playthrough - you don't meet enough enemies or enter the "Backdoor" enough times to complete them.It feels like at some point the developers said "I think we've worked hard enough, let's just polish and release it already," so they did.  This is corroborated by how incomplete the storyline is.5/10OVERALLI don't regret my purchase, but I was expecting more.  Some people will think the gameplay and wonderful atmosphere make the game worth $20, even if it's so short and lacking on story (or, if you're the artsy type, maybe you enjoy open-ended stories).  Others will feel betrayed by the lack of content.  Depending on which type of person you are, I'd either recommend buying it now, or waiting for a sale, respectively.  But either way, I think it's worth playing.8/10

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
 Bastion  was my favourite game of 2011. So you could say I was highly anticipating  Supergiant Games  next release -- which was revealed to be  Transistor  in 2013. After a long and patient wait, I've completed Transistor and I would like to share some of my thoughts and perhaps answer how it stacks up to Bastion.The story revolves around a character called  Red , who seems to be a singer superstar in the city of Cloudbank. After Red wakes up from an assassination attempt by a sinister group of high ranking public figures known as  The Camerata  and realising her voice was also stolen... Red pulls The Transistor out of a mysterious body next to her, and attempts to unravel what exactly happened to her. Little does she know though, that The Transistor can talk, and actually seems to know her. As Red starts to make her way out of the district, she is attacked by an army of robotic intelligences known as  The Process , who seem to be controlled by The Camerata.The story is more abstract, subtle and darker this time. I would say the story is not as immediatetely likeable as Bastion's story -- as the narrator for Bastion basically narrated and spelled everything out for you in a clearer way. In Transistor, the narrator is also your companion,  (voiced by Logan Cunningham once again, though with a much less gravelly and cool sounding tone) . You are more encouraged to explore the world this time to find out more about Cloudbank's lore instead of relying on the narrator.What is amazing is how the story also mechanically ties into the gameplay . You come across various slain characters in the story that you absorb into The Transistor, gaining new abilities. Abilities are multifaceted, so each ability can be used as an active/upgrade/passive and can be mixed and matched for some cool possibilities. You unlock character lore by using each ability in one of the 3 types of slots. It's quite a brilliant and elegant way of doing lore if I must say so myself.You have 4 ability slots which can be upgraded (via leveling up) to have 2 upgrade slots each and you can also unlock 4 passive slots. As you can imagine, this gives Transistor much more depth and customisability this time around compared to Bastion. You can play the game in real time like any normal ARPG... but Transistor also adds a layer of strategic depth with it's new feature called the planning stage -- letting you pause, queue and plan your attacks (with a short global cooldown for all your abilities as a penalty).There is no overworld hub this time like in Bastion, but you do come across back doors -- taking you to a mini oasis of sorts. Here is where you can access all of the challenges known as  tests . Beating each test unlocks a track for you to listen to. Supergiant also added a feature where if you press tab, Red can hum to every track in the game. I love and appreciate this small attention to detail. You can also gaze up at the stars on your hammock and listen to what the Transistor has to say on your current situation and also play with your process dog named Luna (Dota reference?).The idol system from Bastion also makes its return, but in the form of limiters in Transistor. Limiters can be toggled on and off making the game harder but also granting more experience with each limiter you enable (up to 10 limiters). Limiters also have their own lore to be unlocked by using them at least once. The game becomes VERY CHALLENGING with 10 limiters enabled and is not for the feint of heart.The music for Transistor is also incredible once again. It has a bit more of a jazzy and eery sci-fi vibe this time compared to the more upbeat tunes of Bastion. In only 2 games, Darren Korb has cermented himself as one of my favourite game composers of all time. Instant classics, and I can't wait to hear more from this very talented man.Now, I'm praising this game to the high heavens, but what are some of my  dislikes ? Every time you are taken to 0 health, one of your abilities will be overloaded, and can't be used until you reach the next checkpoint. It is a unique way of handling failure, but I didn't really like the idea of having your skills being stripped from you as it can basically ruin the idea of your build if you make a mistake. It also seems random on what skill you will lose -- which is  severely  punishing -- especially when you are trying to complete some of the later performance tests where if you lose 1 crucial skill, you basically have no hope of finishing the test without restarting the whole test and playing flawlessly. The developers also forgot to add a restart test option to the menu which was frustrating when you are attempting them over and over. Frankly, I also didn't think the tests/challenges were as well designed as they were in Bastion.Transistor is another monumental achievement by Supergiant Games. It shows they are maturing as a developer. Some people probably thought Bastion's narrator was a bit of a gimmick, and that the story was all it had going for it. Transistor shows that Supergiant also understand how to craft a more mechanically deep and subtle game this time, while still sticking to their strengths of unique story-telling via narration and music.

Posted: May 22, 2014
												As a preface, I would like to state that SuperGiant's previous game, 'Bastion,' is one of my favourite games of all time. If I present an obvious bias or compare the two games on unfair grounds, then I appologise in advance.   First let us discuss what Transistor does right. The gameplay presented is the same isometric world navigation that was apparant in Bastion, the major difference being its approach to combat. It abandons the hectic run-and-gun/hammer skirmishes of the former and instead takes a far more intelligent plan and execute method. The player can temporarily pause time and plan out their battle strategy before hitting the pause button again and watching it play out at lightning speeds. The numerous variaties of enemies and the layouts of the battlefields provide ample chances to scratch that 'General Chessmaster' itch. The massive amount of weapons (called 'functions()') alsoadd to the tactical depth of this game. Each weapon can be equiped in one of four wepon slots, where it functions normally, firing lasers, dropping bombs etc. Each weapon may also be assigned to either a passive slot, providing you a powerful, perk-like bonus, or to an upgrade slot, in which one weapon buffs the other (LASERS THAT ALSO DROP BOMBS!?). The amount of combinations is truely staggering and will be greatly apprieciated by gamers who like a more intelligent approach to their combat (myself included).   Next the art style. Although the more charming cartoon-like character proportions from Bastion are gone in favor of a more realistic-(ish) art style, the vibrant colours and tones make a glorious return. The mood and the tone of various scenes are masterfully enchanced by use of reccuring temperatures and unique art assets. The forboding height of Coudbank City, as presented soon after the beggining of the game, is alleviated by the cool yellow and blue lighting, giving it a more distant, lonesome feeling, to give one example.   And the soundtrack, oh my, the soundtrack. I was so thrilled to hear that Darren Korb would be returning and boy does he deliver in the audio department. Echoing guitar riffs and droning synthesizers, alongside beautifully melancholic vocals do wonders to nail the sad, lonely cyberpunk feel that is so greatly apprieciated by big nerds such as myself. Particular standouts for me are 'In Circles,' 'Forecast' and 'The Spine.'  And now to cover what I personally was let down by. The story. WAIT! Allow me to expand. (No spoilers don't fret!) The characters themselves are very nicely portrayed, with excellent moments of individual characterisation, but I took issue with the game's plot, its over-arching story. You are dropped right into the world with zero idea of who these characters are, where you are, or what the hell is going on in general. 'But that happened in Bastion too!' I hear you shout. Yes you woke up in a floating bed in Bastion with zero understanding of what was happening, but this created a sense of wonder as the game's  plot was quickly given to you, (The world blew up, but the Bastion can fix it) and as you progressed the world, characters and other various story flavor was gradually revealed to you in satisfying amounts from level to level. And most importantly by the game's end all questions had been answered. This is not the case with Transistor. Although it does a good job with the aforementioned characterisation and also with the same story flavor being drip fed to you, major components of the the plot are flat out not explained, which frustrated me greatly as it gave me difficulty in understanding vital things such as character motivations. These questions are also not addressed, or at least not in any way a near satisfactory level, by the games end. The final boss in particular was very confusing for me, the fight itself comes out of nowhere and takes place in a very strange location and I found myself thinking 'WHAT THE HELL IS HAPPENING? WHY ARE WE FIGHTING NOW? WHERE-WHA-BUT I DIDN'T.........' and soon after the fight the game ends. The ending itself is rather emotional, but I couldn't get into the mood the game wanted me to due to my extreme frustration and confusuion owing to the fact that the credits were rolling and my questions had not been answered. Now I'm not some fool who only enjoys simple by-the-numbers stories, I understand that not all questions need to be answered, but jesus christ SOME would have been nice. Thematically , the game is not as strong as Bastion. It is clearly attempting to make commentary on topics such as the irrelevance of an individual in a system, and the fickleness of the general public but it falls flat if suitable context is not provided.   To summerise: Wonderfully cereberal combat with powerfull art and sound direction that is only let down by its adequately explained story. Or maybe I'm just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.
