Posted: May 21, 2014
												Well, that was playthrough #1. After doing all challenges, listening to and reading everything I possibly could and only once having to use the "Retry" function, Steam tells me I have 7 hours under my belt.The following is my critique of the game, ignoring the New Game+ mode (for now). While I do reference Supergiant Games' first title, Bastion, quite heavily, the points I make should also be accessible to players who have yet to play Bastion (seriously, get that game). While I try to be objective, some sections of this review are highly subjective; the game suffers from virtually no technical (and thus "objectively objective") faults and what I point out as bad may appear as "creative" or "challenging" or just "different" to others.Please refer to additional reviews and critiques before you decide whether or not you want to buy Transistor.THIS CRITIQUE CONTAINS VERY MINOR SPOILERS!If you want to avoid even those, skip to the conclusion section at the end.Transistor is an isometric tactical Action-RPG with a linear story.First of all, the things I was happy with - THE GOOD:- The MUSIC, obviously. Darren Korb and Ashley Barret did an amazing job and the music leaves little to be desired. It's a different style than Bastion's soundtrack, so, of course, whether you like it more or less than Bastion's is a matter of taste, but it is very atmospheric and carries the game together with- LOGAN CUNNINGHAM'S NARRATION. No surprises there. The music may be the soul of the game but the expert narration (and fantastic voice acting) are its heart.- The DESIGN. The world of Transistor is original and colorful; the "feel" is the same as in Bastion but it has a distinctly different theme; the result is stellar.- CUSTOMIZATION. The ability to collect a variety of skills, all of them with different effects, depending on whether they are active, passive or modifying an active skill, makes for some interesting (and tough) choices as to how you want to play. Not everything works well but you can try everything.Now to the things that I was less impressed with - THE MEH:- The COMBAT SYSTEM. Sadly, it is nowhere near as great as (I) expected. Precision is not its strong point and those who were hoping for Frozen Synapse levels of refined tactical combat will be disappointed, as will be those that expected a slick Hack&Slash. Some sections are almost impossible to beat with only one of the modes but intelligent use of both does not help in all situations and more often than not (especially later on), you can find yourself cheesing the game in less-than-fun ways when you encounter fights that are frustrating enough that you'd like to skip them, due to issues with- The BALANCING. Few enemies are balls-to-the-wall hard, but many are insanely annoying. Having to deal with enemies who have the ability to cloak themselves (which, somehow, also makes them invulnerable) without the player having any way to disrupt this cloak (other than waiting for them to deal damage to you) or to damage them in cloak makes several mid- and endgame sections downright infuriating. Especially if said enemies are rapidly regenerating health. Several enemy attacks cannot be avoided and the player's ability to heal himself is extremely limited, making the whole combat system less a matter of skill and more one of a proper choice of abilities (which is where the combat system is at odds with its RPG elements); due to this, some fights (especially boss fights) and victories are anything but satisfying and can leave a bitter aftertaste.- The CHARACTERS. While Bastion had only a few characters with little depth but strong-enough features to make them relatable and carry the story, Transistor has almost none. "The voice" is the strongest one by far but remains a lot more blank than Bastion's narrator. The female lead, Red, has even less than that (or Bastion's Kid). The human antagonists are hardly characterized at all and what remains is a faceless menace that changes the world around you and attacks you constantly... and yet fails to really make you feel threatened.- The STORY. Where Bastion's story was about a simple goal for most of the game (restoring the Bastion), Transistor lacks direction. You feel like a tourist who is being guided from one landmark to the other without any drive or ultimate goal behind it, which becomes even more apparent at the game's conclusion. The plot works with local tension only (i.e. short-term obstacles and goals). The lack of strong characters makes it hard to build-up a bad guy and the pace at which the city changes and the threat swallows it leaves no time to make you care about it or its inhabitants. Unlike the Bastion, you didn't build it with your own two hands and, despite being in a city, you never get a chance to interact with anybody. This leaves the romance as its only redeeming factor... except it isn't either, because the main characters' interaction is very one-sided. The sad truth is: Transistor's story is forgetable.And finally - THE BAD:- WORLD DESIGN (SCOPE AND DEPTH). While the design is great, you hardly see anything of the city (or the rest of the world). Vistas are few and far between and the game doesn't feature any maps or background information that allows you to see the "big picture". Sadly, this devaluates most of the ingame biographies and what lore there is because it becomes that much harder to relate to for their lack of context.- The ENDING. It certainly isn't Mass Effect 3 levels of terrible but, frankly, it makes no sense. The game's conclusion renders pretty much the entire hero's journey pointless and I have to ask what motivation Red had in the first place. That isn't to say that it isn't beautiful in several ways but nonetheless highly disappointing if you were hoping for a well-written story.- The LENGTH. From what I have heard from several people, 7 hours is not a good time. It is quite possible to beat the game in under 5 hours. New Game+ may add replay value here, if you truly enjoyed the combat system and don't share my gripes with it, but if you don't, it leaves the question of value for your money. And, regardless of New Game+, my impression is that the game tries to do too much in too little time - Introducing you to a world, threatening this world and making you its involuntary savior has worked before... but it doesn't work for Transistor.MY VERDICT: (Or: tl;dr)Transistor is a good attempt to solve a task that was almost unsolvable - To create the next "Bastion". Design-wise, it is every bit as strong and a true treat for the eyes and ears, with some great ideas on how to keep progression interesting and your game experience unique. But a closer look reveals a system that tries to combine real-time and tactical combat and, as a result, is the master of neither. The beautiful world that seems so full and interesting is a facade, a mere stage decoration with too little behind it to keep it from falling over when leaned on, leaving a lot of the ingame lore without sufficient context. And while music and narration are great, they cannot hide the fact that the play itself is boring and the characters forgotten as soon as they leave the stage.Supergiant Games gave their game and its world too little time to introduce themselves and captivate you and the result is all the more disappointing for it.Nevertheless, I recommend Transistor for the interesting experience it is; you may find the combat system and story, despite their flaws, more satisfying than I did and, either way, you do not want to miss out on the soundtrack and Logan Cunningham's sexy voice. Supergiant Games deserves the money for a brave attempt, even if this attempt falls short. If you aren't dying to play Transistor right now, pick it up once it goes on sale.

												Alright, I'm going to say this first: A year ago, when the first trailer of this game was revealed, I cried so much. Not only was this going to be another game from SuperGiantGames, the creators of one of my favorite games, Bastion, but the trailer was excellent, blending in beautiful music with awesome gameplay and cutscenes. I forgot about the game over time, with college and projects distracting me, and it was only until a month ago that my love for the game returned. Just like many fans of the game, I was "riding the hype train" as the release date got nearer and nearer. As soon as it was on Steam I preordered it and the soundtrack, which was $30 out of my wallet.Was it worth it? Very much so. I might be still riding the hype train some, but I can still recognize the positive and negative aspects this game has.Story------------------------------------------------I was rather surprised on how the story went. Instead of focusing on Red as the character who advances the story, I found that the Transistor, the sword-like weapon she wields, did most of that job for her. It talks and knows her in some way, but also Red is somewhat of a silent protagonist. She's not like Gordon Freeman from the Half-Life series or Chell from Portal, as you can make her hum by holding the tab button (when I learned I could do that I squeed loudly), but is mostly silent throughout the game. Players will understand why this is early on in the game. Still though, Red and the Transistor work well together and make an amazing duo.The Transistor, being both a main character and the main tool of the player, is not some ethereal being with all the answers. It acts more like a regular person, one that feels love and courage and a sense of honor. This personality, plus Red, can make the player feel attached to both characters as they bond throughout the game. During my playthrough, I got to a scene where the pair finds a bath house and Red proceeds to wash herself. Of course the actually washing isn't shown, but the way the Transistor reacted to this made me laugh. That's what really showed me the Transistor's regular personality.I did enjoy the story as a whole and the ending is a must-see. However, I was disappointed that not much was explained about the setting of the game. If one is to save a city/ town/ country/ etc they should know the importance of it. Yes there are a lot of people in Cloudbank, some very good people, but I would have like to know more about the actual. "How did it come to be?" "What was in the city that made it so grand?" "What was the economic structure before everything went to hell?" "Who was in charge?" Those questions, and some others, were some that I felt should have been answered because they would have helped the plot make sense.Gameplay------------------------------------------------The gameplay in Transistor is different from Bastion. It's more strategic because your main ability, Turn(), freezes time and allows you to set up a number of combos and positions in order to maul your enemies to dust. Though you can also use your abilities on their own, a chain of attacks with the Transistor (the sword-like weapon our heroine, Red, wields) can clear a battlefield in seconds. Plus, if you make a mistake with your planning and have yet to initialize it, you can always go back, redo it, then unleash your power.As always though, there's a catch: After using Turn(), there is a recharge period where most of your abilities are unavailable to you and your more often defenseless. The results of what you can do though definitely outweigh the risk. Turn() to me made the game strategic, but also fast-paced at times. You have to analyze your situation and really think instead of just rushing into battle. Planning and is a major part of the game and it's what makes it so fun.You have four skills at your disposal, but you also have an upgrade slot to each (plus another upgrade slot that you can unlock later on), and passive skills that are always constant (a total of four you can unlock). Each of these three types slots give different effects to each skill and that, plus the the number of combinations you can set for upgrades, gives you a wide arrange of possibilities. For example, one of my favorite skills was "flash-stepping", with added bonuses of releasing balls of damaging energy along my path and a parasite that chewed away at an enemy that it homed in on. A harmless flash-step because a deadly barrage.The difficulty of the game goes up as you go through the game and it became quite tough at times and sometimes repetative. However, I find it to be not too hardcore, but good middle ground, with easy bits at the beginning and angering parts at the end (though I'm also a fast learner and have experience in video games so it might be different for other people).Other------------------------------------------------The art style of Transistor is very similar to Bastion's. It's very well done, with great effects and cutscenes through the story. Not only that, but the music fits well throughout the game. Both of these combined create a beautiful canvas as you set up your attacks.Oh yeah, there isn't really a menu. You just get thrown into the game.Overall------------------------------------------------To wrap up all this review said, Transistor has:+ Great main characters+ Great gameplay+ A wide variety of play styles+ Game mode plus+ Graphics/ art style+ Awesome music/ soundtrack- Lack of info on Cloudbank/ main setting- Short playthrough (if that's a bother)- Sometimes repetive fight scenesThis was definitely a fun game to play. It was just how I expected it to be and thrilled it was like that. Though somewhat short (I beat it in about 9 hours as I collected stuff and enjoyed the story), it does have a New Game Plus mode similar to Bastion's where you have all the progress from the previous game and start from the very beginning. Only thing different is that all the enemies are tougher, so you still have challenge as you fight once more through Cloudbank. I'll be definitely going through it soon.If you're a fan of Bastion, I highly recommend that you get this game. If you like RPGs, strategy, and some fast-paced fighting, I also recommend you buy this game. Twenty bucks was definitely worth it for me and many others who preordered it as well.

												I am an enormous fan of Bastion - and have been following the development of Transistor with hesitant optimism ... Posted: May 20, 2014
I feel like I should actually write a serious review of this game.I'll start by saying: If you didn't like Bastion, you won't like this at all. The storytelling is very similar. The game is also pretty short, I finished clocking in at 5 hours (did not 100% obviously, you need NG+ to unlock all the different powers and such). But during NG+, I don't see the story changing much. It will be something for only completionists.But, outside of that I found Transistor to be a great experience. Supergiant delivers again with a chillingly beautiful soundtrack, Darren Korb proving his skills at composing. As a person who loved the art style of Bastion, Transistor does not differ a lot from it with the exception of having more "3d" models as compared to the mostly 2D Bastion, this is most easily seen on your protagonist. The voice acting in the game is top notch, Logan Cunningham giving another near perfect preformance on his character and as the narrator. The enviroments are always beautiful to look at, if a little confusing to navigate at times. The story kept me hooked all the way through the game, with the characters being fleshed out along the way, never feeling generic and always very enthralling.The combat in the game was a very interesting idea executed well, but not to perfection. It can feel tedious at times and frustrating at others when something just doesn't lineup perfectly. Endgame, you will probably have a combo that will be able to instagib the strongest enemies, you only obstacle being the cooldown bar on your Turn(), which is the main form of combat in Transistor. It's a strategic pause that allows you to set up a bunch of moves that enemies can not react to for the most part. With the backstab mechaninc and the variety of Functions (moves), it has more uses than just being a "VATS" like way of fighting ala Fallout. While recharging, its a game of dodging attacks before you can go back in on the enemies.Where the combat really shines is how varried you can make your moveset. Each unlockable function is very different than the last, and aren't just moves: they can be infused to combine with other functions (Example: combine the knockup and the pull functions to create an AOE pull) or can be used as passive traits, all taking up some of your power bar, limiting how many functions you can have going.The stories included with each function are a very nice touch that fit the asthetic very well, but unlocking all 3 pieces can be a pain sometimes, since each one will need to occupy each of the 3 uses (passive, upgrade or move) to unlock the full story. Luckily, you only need one battle in each use to unlock each part and with an upgrade station seemingly after every battle you should unlock them all quickly and be able to go back to a more comfortable moveset. There was only a few spots in the game I would consider "hard", for the most part your average player should be able to blow through their first NG with relative ease. The enemies aren't the brightest, not to say that they are bad, but sometimes they will just stare at you as you recharge behind a wall, not even bothering to try and pressure you to move. Death is also really hard to achieve, after reaching 0 HP you will get a "free turn()" where you can try and save yourself or win the fight with your what you have left. If you fail and get hit again, you will lose one of your functions socketed. But, since you will usually have 4, chances are you will most likely never lose them all. I have never lost one, so I could not say if they are gone forever, but seeing the difficulty of the game I assume you recover them at the next station. The only time dying will really matter is in the training & challenge areas, where if you die once or twice you may just restart a challenge.Is it worth playing through? Absolutely, it's a beautiful experiece. Is it worth the current $20? That's a bit more debatable, due to it's shorter length. I wouldn't say not to buy it, but the second it goes on sale it is a must grab.

												Before anything, I will preface this and say if you have any interest in ARPG's and are looking for a wonderful and short experience, you SHOULD pick this game up. Well worth the $20 in my opinion.  If you want a detailed explanation, feel free to read and a TLDR is at the bottom.PROS:◘Visually pleasing to the eyes, absolutly gorgeous presentation in both animation and the enviornment.◘Sound design is top notch.◘Narration done throughout the game is fun to listen to.◘Can play with either mouse or keyboard.◘Fairly intriguing theme and story get you interested◘Should run fairly well on most machines.◘Fairly challenging as you can easily be "killed" multiple times during any battle.     ○When you "die" in combat, 2 things can happen: The first is on the brink of death you engage a emergency Turn mode (Turn is explained later below) and can fight to kill a few more enemies. The second possibility is that you "break" a function from combat for a while, and after visiting 2 (or more) Function Kiosks you can reactive them. If you break them, you are then forced to play around with your kit to experiment with new loadouts.◘Variety of combat with many different enemies with various different upgrade versions of them.◘Absolutely STELLAR combat system along with the configurations along with it (Which are detalied below)     ○As you play the game, you obtain various skills and upgrades through leveling up or finding them around the world and they are called Functions.     ○You can use these Functions in 3 ways: The first is the Active Function which you use for combat that does its base effect. The second is the Upgrade Function, where you take one of your Functions and use it to augment another Active Function, giving it special or different effect. And lastly is the Passive Function, in which you take a Function and put it into a passive state where it will always give a effect, or activate at specific under different conditions. EVERY Function in the game connects together in one way or another.     ○As you play the game, you are allowed to fight in either real time where you cast your abilities against the enemies movements and actions with no cooldown penalty, engage the Turn system to pause the game and tactically decide how you want to approach the situation. In Turn you can move almost instantly anywhere and manually aim your shots and action which are limited by a action bar. You then execute the procedure and watch your plan unfold rapidly. However, the downside to this is that once you are done with your Turn actions, you cannot use your abilities until your Turn meter has recharged. Because of these 2 systems you have a choice as to how you want to fight your battles.◘You can use "limiters" to further increase the difficulty of the game and gain a small amount of bonus EXP for leveling.◘New game plus mode with all of your stuff you unlocked. CONS:◘The UI can be just a little bit wonky with assigning Functions to various roles.◘Because the story is not made apparently clear at first, you can easily get lost.◘Turn actions that detail the effects may not always be accurate, as enemies may dodge and it doesn't tell you that information.◘May be just a bit short for some, as I and other have managed to beat the game at around 6 hours.◘Because there is new game plus and not much more, some people may not find a lot of replayability from this, resulting a 6 hour experience for $20 dollars.◘The only real set of graphics options are just resolutions.TLDR: Great combat, visuals and fun for ARPG fans. Can be beaten in about 6 hours, and depending on the user the new game plus can offer replayability.Can be of a bumpy ride for the first hour for people to get used to, but you get over it quickly.Overall, I feel that just about everyone should buy this beauty. The devs that made this deserve every dollar they earn and then some for the amount of effort and love that was poured into this game.

												I just beat this game and here is why you should buy it.Good:- Very good engaging story- Superb music- Beautiful artstyle, especially during the cutscenes.- Combat system is like nothing you've seen before, with the choice of switching between real-time and a planning mode, without either feeling superior.- Very deep upgrade system that let's you play like you want to play.- Has a New Game+ mode called Recursion that randomizes enemy encounters, so you can replay it with added difficulty if you feel like it.- Has a 'limiter'-system that allows you to change the difficulty on the fly with various different debuffs/buffs to you and the enemies respectively. Adding difficulty this way gives bonus exp.- Has checkpoints that allow you to change your loadout almost every 2-3 minutes.Bad/not as good:- Took me 4 hours to beat, could have been a little longer, but wasn't needed. It provided the necessary closure.- The gameplay is mostly just moving from fight to fight. You walk a (mostly) pre-determined path and once every 2 or 3 minutes you fight something. Not sure what they could have done to make this better though, since I found the combat system really enjoyable.- Some of the lore is locked behind your combat abilities, and this lore is unlocked by using the abilities as just a normal ability, as an upgrade to an existing ability, or as a passive bonus. I understand that this is done to make you explore different ability-combinations and to try out all of the different combinations, but I found it annoying that I had to change away from my favorite loadout if I wanted the complete story.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Transistor is an RPG by the creators of Bastion. Similarly to their previous game, the art, story, and sound design are all fantastic. The combat is a weird hybrid between real-time and turn-based that will probably be hit-or-miss with most people. The robust skill system was incredible and is probably one of Transistor's best features.The combat is different than most other games. You can move and attack in real time, but you'll find it difficult to survive without using the Turn() feature. Turn() pauses the game and allows you to plan out your next few movements and attacks. The planned actions will then be executed very quickly, without the enemies being able to attack or move. Turn() then goes on cooldown for a few seconds and most of your skill won't be usable. This creates a turn-like tempo in the the fights where you attack with Turn() and then play defensively when it's on cooldown.  The combat takes a little getting used to and won't be for everyone, but it really works well with the skill system.The skill system is one of the games best features. I didn't unlock all of the skill on the first playthough, but there are at least 16 of them. Each skill can be used in 3 ways.1. Active Skill: The skills you use in combat. You get 4 active skill slots.2. Augementation: Each active slot has two augmentation slots which alter the effect of the active skill.3. Passive Skill: Each skill has a different passive effect when placed in one of the 4 passive slots.Although this seems to be overly complex, you only start with a couple skills, the 4 active slots, and an augmentation slot for each of them. You gain additional skills and slots when you level up so the game does a good job of easing you into the skill system. Furthermore, the game does an excellent job of pushing you to experiement and try new skill combinations. I had a lot of fun experimenting with the skills and trying to find effective combinations.In conclusion, Transistor is a great game. If you liked Bastion, or are a fan of turn based RPGs, you should get this game. If you're unsure that you'll like the combat, you should look at a couple gameplay videos, but try not to spoil the story for yourself.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												I really like Bastion and was really excited for SuperGiant's next game.  Transistor did not disapoint.  The fighting style was unique and interesting because you had to combine moves together to make them more powerful and give unique secondary abilities based on which ones you combined.  I was also surprised to find that I didn't stick with one set of moves the whole time. Transistor did a good job of making abilities good in some situations and bad in others.  It became very strategic once you got more moves and it was a lot of fun. But by far the BEST part about Transistor was the music and art.  Bastion was one of my favorite games not because the gameplay was the something I had never seen before, but that game was a paradise for your eyes and ears.  I always thought Bastion had the best soundtrack in a videogame but after playing Transistor I was blown away. The vocals for the songs are by the same person who sang "Build that Wall", (Ashley Barrett) except in this game you get to hear the full potential of her voice, and let me tell you, it is the best voice I have ever heard.  It fits the tone of the game really well.  The art in this game is also amazing. Particularly the colors and overall style was what really looked great.  This game also does a great job of making the story interesting by making you figure out what it is based on clues it gives you throughout the game.  In fact one of my favorite aspects was reading through character files looking for clues on what was going on.My only complaints about this game kind of negate each other.  What I mean is, I took the game quite slow, and I still finished it in 7 hours, which with how much I enjoyed it seemed short.  On the other hand, the combat system was starting to get a little repetative so I don't know that I would have wanted it to go much longer.  Overall I loved this game, and with the very interesting story, amazing music, and incredible art, I felt like it almost should have been a movie instead of a videogame for how beautiful it was. 9/10

												Game Name: TransistorOriginal Release: 2014Personal Rating: AEstimated Playtime:18 HoursMultiplayer/Coop?: NonePlayed on: Steam ControllerTransistor is an indie game created from the same makers of Bastion. It is a unique rpg that has an interesting balance between turn-based gameplay and real time gameplay.Controls: When I played this, I used the Steam Controller. It wasn’t hard to use at all, and it seemed rather natural to use a controller with the game. Joystick seemed prime for the movement option, and the four buttons on the face of the controller worked really well with the four skills that you have to use in-game.Graphics: This isn’t a Crysis level of graphics. Coming straight out of an indie studio, it seems unique and more like art. Cut-scenes mix in well with the 2.5D gameplay, and it’s easy to figure out what is happening as time goes on.Music: Much like Bastion, Supergiant Games (the creators) release excellent soundtracks and this is no exception. Between the songs that you unlock and Red’s (the Main Character) humming, you find yourself playing the game for the music instead of the gameplay.Overall: Transistor has a unique and potent combination of great music, easy controls and compelling gameplay, all within a fun game with an interesting plot. No super strategy is needed as you will eventually figure out the game throughout time. I would recommend it at any price, but it does drop down during the sales.

Posted: April 28, 2016
												In Transistor, you play as the silent starlet and singer Red, traversing the eerily empty yet colourful city of Cloudbank. The city is slowly being overtaken by a mysterious force known only as the Process, and Cloudbank's leaders have something to do with it. Desperate to put a stop to whatever's happening, Red goes out to hunt -- but not alone. She carries a sword-like contraption with her known as the Transistor, whose dulcet and heartfelt tones guide her (and you) through a decaying world...Pros+ Beautiful, mesmerizing art & visuals+ The Transistor's narration of the game+ The dreamy, cyber-like soundtrack+ Combining functions for cool attack abilities+ The overall emotional impactCons- Combat can get a bit repetitive- The main story could have been longer & more in-depth- Some story elements are left deliberately vagueThis one of the most beautiful & artful games I've ever played! The overall cyberpunkish atmosphere, the gorgeous artwork, the hauntingly loving voice of the Transistor... The game has story elements that are quite familiar in the sci-fi sphere, but its execution is just so good. I fell in love with Red, the Transistor, and their world in a little over five hours already, and bawled my eyes out at certain points during the story. The emotional pacing, aided by the superb soundtrack, was fantastic. The upsides of this game far outweigh any downsides -- which for me personally, were the slightly repetitive combat (mostly due to lots of the same enemy types, I think) and the fact that the first run-through of the story was not longer, meatier & more in-depth.Like sci-fi, strategical planning in combat (on pause), and a deeply emotional story? Then this one's for you. This game is a perfect little jewel, with my compliments to Logan Cunningham's excellent voice acting as the Transistor.

												I usually trudge through a game's actual gameplay to get it over with, but Transistor's gameplay was so enjoyable and solid that I found myself playing through the entire game again the very next day. The deep customization of your abilities with the various Functions(), the blend of real time frantic play with the powerful frozen planning of Turn(), and difficulty scaling done right make all the game extremely enjoyable to play. There are unbelievably powerful ability combos in the game, but you're always facing enemies that can meet the challenge. If you're not, then there's still the combat modifiers and restrictions you can add. Story-wise, the world is significantly more sparse and spare than Supergiant's previous title, Bastion, but it seems to be an intentional choice: a bit of mystery allows for varied interpretations and a long narrative shelf life, which is what I think they were going for in this game. I think they leaned a little too far in the direction of limiting information, but the game doesn't suffer for it too much. I think the endgame buildup and final fight were excellently executed and they are going to be a favorite among the games I've played.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Transistor is an RPG by the creators of Bastion. Similarly to their previous game, the art, story, and sound design are all fantastic. The combat is a weird hybrid between real-time and turn-based that will probably be hit-or-miss with most people. The robust skill system was incredible and is probably one of Transistor's best features.The combat is different than most other games. You can move and attack in real time, but you'll find it difficult to survive without using the Turn() feature. Turn() pauses the game and allows you to plan out your next few movements and attacks. The planned actions will then be executed very quickly, without the enemies being able to attack or move. Turn() then goes on cooldown for a few seconds and most of your skill won't be usable. This creates a turn-like tempo in the the fights where you attack with Turn() and then play defensively when it's on cooldown.  The combat takes a little getting used to and won't be for everyone, but it really works well with the skill system.The skill system is one of the games best features. I didn't unlock all of the skill on the first playthough, but there are at least 16 of them. Each skill can be used in 3 ways.1. Active Skill: The skills you use in combat. You get 4 active skill slots.2. Augementation: Each active slot has two augmentation slots which alter the effect of the active skill.3. Passive Skill: Each skill has a different passive effect when placed in one of the 4 passive slots.Although this seems to be overly complex, you only start with a couple skills, the 4 active slots, and an augmentation slot for each of them. You gain additional skills and slots when you level up so the game does a good job of easing you into the skill system. Furthermore, the game does an excellent job of pushing you to experiement and try new skill combinations. I had a lot of fun experimenting with the skills and trying to find effective combinations.In conclusion, Transistor is a great game. If you liked Bastion, or are a fan of turn based RPGs, you should get this game. If you're unsure that you'll like the combat, you should look at a couple gameplay videos, but try not to spoil the story for yourself.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Just a great game all-around.Most everybody that's interested in this game will be comparing it to Bastion, so we'll go with that metric.In terms of gameplay, Transistor is quite different than Bastion.  Yes, they're both top-down hack-and-slashes at heart, but while Bastion's beating heart lies squarely in twitch/dodge/attack mechanics, Transistor is a more contemplative experience with its Turn() system.  In fact, the grand majority of Transistor ends up playing much more like a tactics game than a hack-and-slash game; use of skills outside of Turn() is limited and you'll spend most of your time outside of Turn() playing keep-away.  Some people may find this a downgrade, but if you're the sort of person that enjoyed Bastion and also logged hundered-hour files in tactical RPG games (myself included) you'll find yourself comfortable in the world of Transistor.In terms of style, Transistor is very much cut from the same cloth as Bastion.  That's to be expected when Bastion was such a beautiful and lovingly crafted game.  Painterly visuals abound, and Darren Korb (music) and Logan Cunningham (primary voice actor) are both back in top form, as I'm sure everyone not living in a cave is aware.  Come for the audio-visual niravana, stay for the gameplay.As far as criticisms are concerned, stability of the game is still a bit lower than could be desired at this point; I had to play around with the files of the game to overcome the dreaded startup crash bug that many people have been complaining of.  A minor criticisim:  If you're the sort of person that doesn't play around with the dynamic difficulty system (Bastion's Pantheon : Transistor's Limiters) you may find the game easy once you've unlocked some of the more powerful functions (I found it a bit trivial even with half the limiters on).  A New Game + feature and use of all the limiters is an easy remedy for those wanting more gameplay and more challenge.Three things that are fab:# Turn() system and executing sets that make you feel like a genius# Wonderfully detailed world and story# Extra story exposition linked to use of Functions for that extra bit of OCD fodderThree things that are butt:# May not work immediately on some computers# No Steamplay support as of yet# A bit easy for those seeking a teeth-grinding experienceAll in all, Transistor is a wonderful nugget of a game that you shouldn't hesistate to pick up, even at its introductory price-point.  If you liked Bastion for its artistic elements, you'll love Transistor, and if you enjoy tactical games you may end up liking Transistor even more than Bastion.  I know I did!  The main story lasted me roughly nine hours when doing everything available, and I have a bit of a completionist bent.  I have just started a New Game+ session.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Transistor, Supergiant Games' second release, is an enthralling, unique experience that meets and shatters any expectation one may have about it. If you've played Bastion, and are wondering how Transistor fares in comparison with it, know that this game pulls all the right inspiration from SPG's previous release, but maintains its own identity to set it apart as something truly original.Like Bastion, Transistor is a narrative-driven game with emphasis on configurable gameplay, i.e. loadouts. There's optional difficulty modifiers and the game plays in standard psuedo-isometric fashion. But the similarities end there. Unlike Bastion, Transistor's fighting system is much more diverse and complex; more RPG, less action-adventure. A core component of that system is something called 'Turn()' mode, which essentially shifts the game from real-time to turn-based action. I find Transistor's combat system to be incredibly unique, and something that enables multiple play styles to shine through.The story of the game, while similar to Bastion, in that it's a linear, narrative-driven plot, is again, just superficially similar. While the narrator in Bastion is more so telling a story, the narrator in Transistor isn't really a narrator at all. He's another character, with his own perspective and reactions on what's going on around him. He doesn't really tell the story so much as he does experience it. The real meat of lore is actually acquired through using abilities you've gathered in various ways. This is a vastly different take on storytelling because one may not have even uncovered the whole thing through one playthrough. I believe though, that the game meant to be played like that; it's meant to be played through more than once. And it's obvious, as the New Game+ mode is called a 'Recursion'. For some, this may be a turn off, which is understandable. After my first playthrough, I was left with more questions than answers. It left a slightly sour taste in mouth, but after playing more and uncovering all that there was to be uncovered, I enjoyed the story much more than I initially did. It's a very different way to tell a story, but I think fans will appreciate it.Overall, I highly recommend Transistor. It has creative, unique gameplay with a story that is equally as intriguing. Not to mention the beautiful art and soundtrack, which is worth buying in its own right!

												Another great game from the makers of Bastion. Excellent gameplay coupled with a one of a kind narrative makes this mysterious story both quite memorable and replayable. The soundtrack alone makes this game worth at least one play through if not more. Transistor has a very neat way of introducing challenges as well as altering modes of difficulty through "limiters," these are sort of down-grades that can create a challenge, but reward you with greater experience. The higheryour level, the greater number of "Functions," or abilities you have at your disposal. While some abilities may not seem very useful directly, they usually have a benefit ifused passively. Utilizing different combinations of abilities allows for a wide range of play-styles and tactics. Transistor has such a great take on gameplay mechanics that it is entirely refreshing and a lot of fun. Considering the above, the one minor drawback, to me, is how vague the world is. However, I can't really consider that a negative, because the world of Transistor and everything in it can be open to interpretation. GIven this I think Supergiant has accomplished a pretty awesome feat, making the player use their imagination in both the gameplay/strategy as well as the story they've told. I highly recommend Transistor to just about anyone.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												If you liked Bastion and would play it again, then Transistor is well worth it.If you found it to be somewhat lacking, then I don't honestly feel that the reworked combat alone will be ultimately satisfying.Before I dive into the other parts of the game, I feel it is worth mentioning that the PC version suffers a few hiccups here and there, especially with KB+M controls. Being able to aim your attacks in Turn() is nice, but the game will often snap your attacks to enemies you're mousing over instead of the tile you're aiming for. Almost every attack is (or can have) AoE, so this is kind of a big deal. The game used to stutter hard on my rig, but no longer does so with the first update. However, that very update broke camera controls in Turn(), making it difficult to aim or move off of the screen. The game is definitely playable with a controller, and I recommend trying that.Now, the game's individual parts are not bad-- the art direction is gorgeous, and you really couldn't ask for more from the music or Logan Cunningham. The combat system is at first pretty deep, and allows for the player to flesh out their own arsenal and playstyle, but provides little incentive for the player to actually experiment once they've unlocked all the attached lore (executed pretty neatly) and discovered their winning combos.But there is ultimately something missing both from Bastion and Transistor. I've found that they both leave you wanting more-- not necessarily in a good way. There is little exploration or risk/reward beyond the critical path, and perhaps the addition of one or two extra mechanics might have tightened it up a bit; made it feel more substantial. I acknowledge that it sounds superfluous, and hopefully it won't bother you as much as it did me. I really want to appreciate the sentiment of elegant game design, because the game does feel like it's pretty clean of unnecessary or tacked-on bits (aside from NG+). I think the real flaw is that you aren't really introduced to any new gameplay mechanics outside of combat, and the combat does not stay fresh forever. Again, maybe it is unnecessary and it won't bother you, but them's my two pickles.Regarding NG+: don't bother recursing through the game for the story. All that's new is one or two lines at the start, different enemy setups, a second pair of every function (you can power up a function with a second instance of itself) and of course the achievement.

Posted: August 14, 2014
												It was initally the track "Old Friends" from the trailer that drew me in so it was very much a case of came for the music, stayed for the experience. Storyline is an inbetween lines tale of love admist revenge.Gameplay is a fusion of real time hack and slash similar to Bastion but at a slower pace with the "Turn Mode" being like a tactical mode similar to V.A.T.S via the recent Fallout games (3 and New Vegas). Overall gameplay is not complicated and encourages experimentation with rewarding results. Also there are options via "Limiters" to increase the difficulty and affect consequntly how you utilize many of the protagonist's abilites as you level up.  Battles can be long and enduring, but this is very much true to life itself.The music and art style is what gives this game it's atmosphere. The soundtrack is an eclectic fusion of dissonance and consonance with genres such as eletronica, rock,  downbeat, jazz and vocal. There are quite a few notable tracks that are awesome to listen to for pure audial pleasure. Art style is very reminiscent of the late 19th century styles with Art Nouveau, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec and Gustav Klimt. Transistor is a wonderful game for its subtle poetic atmosphere and storyline that verges into the territory of Romanticism with Heinrich von Kleist.A beautiful game!

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Just a great game all-around.Most everybody that's interested in this game will be comparing it to Bastion, so we'll go with that metric.In terms of gameplay, Transistor is quite different than Bastion.  Yes, they're both top-down hack-and-slashes at heart, but while Bastion's beating heart lies squarely in twitch/dodge/attack mechanics, Transistor is a more contemplative experience with its Turn() system.  In fact, the grand majority of Transistor ends up playing much more like a tactics game than a hack-and-slash game; use of skills outside of Turn() is limited and you'll spend most of your time outside of Turn() playing keep-away.  Some people may find this a downgrade, but if you're the sort of person that enjoyed Bastion and also logged hundered-hour files in tactical RPG games (myself included) you'll find yourself comfortable in the world of Transistor.In terms of style, Transistor is very much cut from the same cloth as Bastion.  That's to be expected when Bastion was such a beautiful and lovingly crafted game.  Painterly visuals abound, and Darren Korb (music) and Logan Cunningham (primary voice actor) are both back in top form, as I'm sure everyone not living in a cave is aware.  Come for the audio-visual niravana, stay for the gameplay.As far as criticisms are concerned, stability of the game is still a bit lower than could be desired at this point; I had to play around with the files of the game to overcome the dreaded startup crash bug that many people have been complaining of.  A minor criticisim:  If you're the sort of person that doesn't play around with the dynamic difficulty system (Bastion's Pantheon : Transistor's Limiters) you may find the game easy once you've unlocked some of the more powerful functions (I found it a bit trivial even with half the limiters on).  A New Game + feature and use of all the limiters is an easy remedy for those wanting more gameplay and more challenge.Three things that are fab:# Turn() system and executing sets that make you feel like a genius# Wonderfully detailed world and story# Extra story exposition linked to use of Functions for that extra bit of OCD fodderThree things that are butt:# May not work immediately on some computers# No Steamplay support as of yet# A bit easy for those seeking a teeth-grinding experienceAll in all, Transistor is a wonderful nugget of a game that you shouldn't hesistate to pick up, even at its introductory price-point.  If you liked Bastion for its artistic elements, you'll love Transistor, and if you enjoy tactical games you may end up liking Transistor even more than Bastion.  I know I did!  The main story lasted me roughly nine hours when doing everything available, and I have a bit of a completionist bent.  I have just started a New Game+ session.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												It's hard to describe this game without using the word "beautiful" at least several hundred times, along with other adjectives, such as "amazing", "addicting", and "magnificent". I'm shocked how some people don't realize its true intentions as rather a story you are thrown into to experience first hand. I'll try to explain this further with no spoilers:The beginning throws you straight into the game; no main menu, no background story, nothing. I had to YouTube the game just to make sure I hadn't accidently skipped an intro cutscene, but sure enough, what I was seeing was the way it was intended to begin. Already, I was impressed.Gameplay felt comfortable. No stretching my tiny, feminine fingers out to reach oddly specific keys. Mouse controls were smooth and responsive. I never had a problem getting stuck on anything or walking into walls. My first time playing through I obviously relied on the Turn() aspect of the combat quite a bit, but towards the end and on my second time around, I realized the benefits of using both styles of combat, using the real time more for specific enemies that either evaded the effects of Turn() or were not of importance to waste it on. The key feature of applying Functions as a normal active function, an upgrade, or a passive stat was genius and allows for any person's unique fighting strategies. With how flexible the combat is, I'm surprised people have complaints about it.The characters and dialogue of the entire game were enthralling and immersive. I felt highly connected with Red's character, and knew so much about her despite her ailment. That never stopped her character from shining through. Her sassy yet proper attitude was visible in her actions, not to mention how weak and afraid she truly was. She didn't have the amazing super strength to lift such a giant sword all the time. It would constantly dragged behind her, but she would gather her little strength to unleash amazing attacks, usually having to lift herself and the sword back up off the ground afterwards. She was constantly playing with her hair and adjusting herself, but obviously was not too absorbed in her looks, seeing that she tore such a beautiful ball gown to shreds for the sake of being able to run. Mr. Nobody, as he titles himself at an early point and what I prefer to call him since, no, he is not the Transistor itself, still shines through despite not even having a body. His voice acting is absolutely amazing. Every word meant something. Some lines made tears well up in my eyes. He had attitude as well, much more sarcastic and joking, but he was just as believable as Red.The story, while I won't say much, was just beautiful. It's never what you expect, but not hard to follow along with. I will say the trailer gives false ideas and practically lies about the true story. Playing this blind is an amazing experience. Do me a favor and when Mr. Nobody starts talking, don't cut him off. Let him speak. All the dialogue means something in the story and if you cut him off, you could lose so much of the true story and not understand things in the future. A lot of playthroughs on YouTube do this. Don't cut off the experience for yourself. Take the extra time to sit there and just listen.The music is just fantastic, and the little hum you can play for each track gives it a new spin and practically makes it a different song. All the music is addicting and plays perfectly along side the gameplay. The music is mellow and slow, so you never feel rushed in a battle, making the combat feel smooth and relaxed rather than frantic. The music is meant to calm you in the fray of battle and does so quite well. The art speaks for itself. Even if you hate the game, you can't deny its beauty. Everything looks hand painted. The 3D models are high definition, to the point where Red's facial expressions are visible. I'm simply obsessed with the artistic style they chose.Final boss and ending sequence brought me to tears. I sobbed like a little girl, but for good reason, so don't judge. I had been near tears for most of the game due to its music and voice acting and the end pulled the final strings to my heart. It has been a very long time since a game has done this for me. I will ask you all again something here; if you beat it, when it asks you to play the recursion, at least watch the intro again. If the slight secret difference in the intro does not compel you to play more, than I'm not sure what will.To be blunt, I'm kind of an expert on this game. I've been tracking it since its announcement at E3, watched all the demos and trailers, received it on the release day, have the soundtrack on my phone, and at the time of posting this I have racked up about 14 hours on the game. I will say if you're expecting a casual game of the typical demographic of 13-17 year old boys, this has no time for you. This game requires patience, attention, and heart. It is not the game's fault if you do not feel the need to provide it with these then seek to trash it for "not being good enough". Before you judge it, follow my suggestion of listening to all the dialogue and at least attempt to finish it. The game should take someone who is not rushed about 10 hours; not long at all. This game is a story and an experience, not something you can mindlessly blow through.My final rating is 10/10, simply because it brought me to tears not once, not twice, but three times, and I'll happily cry again just to play through it once more to immerse myself in its beautiful story.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Before anything, I will preface this and say if you have any interest in ARPG's and are looking for a wonderful and short experience, you SHOULD pick this game up. Well worth the $20 in my opinion.  If you want a detailed explanation, feel free to read and a TLDR is at the bottom.PROS:◘Visually pleasing to the eyes, absolutly gorgeous presentation in both animation and the enviornment.◘Sound design is top notch.◘Narration done throughout the game is fun to listen to.◘Can play with either mouse or keyboard.◘Fairly intriguing theme and story get you interested◘Should run fairly well on most machines.◘Fairly challenging as you can easily be "killed" multiple times during any battle.     ○When you "die" in combat, 2 things can happen: The first is on the brink of death you engage a emergency Turn mode (Turn is explained later below) and can fight to kill a few more enemies. The second possibility is that you "break" a function from combat for a while, and after visiting 2 (or more) Function Kiosks you can reactive them. If you break them, you are then forced to play around with your kit to experiment with new loadouts.◘Variety of combat with many different enemies with various different upgrade versions of them.◘Absolutely STELLAR combat system along with the configurations along with it (Which are detalied below)     ○As you play the game, you obtain various skills and upgrades through leveling up or finding them around the world and they are called Functions.     ○You can use these Functions in 3 ways: The first is the Active Function which you use for combat that does its base effect. The second is the Upgrade Function, where you take one of your Functions and use it to augment another Active Function, giving it special or different effect. And lastly is the Passive Function, in which you take a Function and put it into a passive state where it will always give a effect, or activate at specific under different conditions. EVERY Function in the game connects together in one way or another.     ○As you play the game, you are allowed to fight in either real time where you cast your abilities against the enemies movements and actions with no cooldown penalty, engage the Turn system to pause the game and tactically decide how you want to approach the situation. In Turn you can move almost instantly anywhere and manually aim your shots and action which are limited by a action bar. You then execute the procedure and watch your plan unfold rapidly. However, the downside to this is that once you are done with your Turn actions, you cannot use your abilities until your Turn meter has recharged. Because of these 2 systems you have a choice as to how you want to fight your battles.◘You can use "limiters" to further increase the difficulty of the game and gain a small amount of bonus EXP for leveling.◘New game plus mode with all of your stuff you unlocked. CONS:◘The UI can be just a little bit wonky with assigning Functions to various roles.◘Because the story is not made apparently clear at first, you can easily get lost.◘Turn actions that detail the effects may not always be accurate, as enemies may dodge and it doesn't tell you that information.◘May be just a bit short for some, as I and other have managed to beat the game at around 6 hours.◘Because there is new game plus and not much more, some people may not find a lot of replayability from this, resulting a 6 hour experience for $20 dollars.◘The only real set of graphics options are just resolutions.TLDR: Great combat, visuals and fun for ARPG fans. Can be beaten in about 6 hours, and depending on the user the new game plus can offer replayability.Can be of a bumpy ride for the first hour for people to get used to, but you get over it quickly.Overall, I feel that just about everyone should buy this beauty. The devs that made this deserve every dollar they earn and then some for the amount of effort and love that was poured into this game.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Transistor is an RPG by the creators of Bastion. Similarly to their previous game, the art, story, and sound design are all fantastic. The combat is a weird hybrid between real-time and turn-based that will probably be hit-or-miss with most people. The robust skill system was incredible and is probably one of Transistor's best features.The combat is different than most other games. You can move and attack in real time, but you'll find it difficult to survive without using the Turn() feature. Turn() pauses the game and allows you to plan out your next few movements and attacks. The planned actions will then be executed very quickly, without the enemies being able to attack or move. Turn() then goes on cooldown for a few seconds and most of your skill won't be usable. This creates a turn-like tempo in the the fights where you attack with Turn() and then play defensively when it's on cooldown.  The combat takes a little getting used to and won't be for everyone, but it really works well with the skill system.The skill system is one of the games best features. I didn't unlock all of the skill on the first playthough, but there are at least 16 of them. Each skill can be used in 3 ways.1. Active Skill: The skills you use in combat. You get 4 active skill slots.2. Augementation: Each active slot has two augmentation slots which alter the effect of the active skill.3. Passive Skill: Each skill has a different passive effect when placed in one of the 4 passive slots.Although this seems to be overly complex, you only start with a couple skills, the 4 active slots, and an augmentation slot for each of them. You gain additional skills and slots when you level up so the game does a good job of easing you into the skill system. Furthermore, the game does an excellent job of pushing you to experiement and try new skill combinations. I had a lot of fun experimenting with the skills and trying to find effective combinations.In conclusion, Transistor is a great game. If you liked Bastion, or are a fan of turn based RPGs, you should get this game. If you're unsure that you'll like the combat, you should look at a couple gameplay videos, but try not to spoil the story for yourself.

A minor criticisim:  If you're the sort of person that doesn't play around with the dynamic difficulty system (Bastion's Pantheon : Transistor's Limiters) you may find the game easy once you've unlocked some of the more powerful functions (I found it a bit trivial even with half the limiters on).  A New Game + feature and use of all the limiters is an easy remedy for those wanting more gameplay and more challenge.Three things that are fab:# Turn() system and executing sets that make you feel like a genius# Wonderfully detailed world and story# Extra story exposition linked to use of Functions for that extra bit of OCD fodderThree things that are butt:# May not work immediately on some computers# No Steamplay support as of yet# A bit easy for those seeking a teeth-grinding experienceAll in all, Transistor is a wonderful nugget of a game that you shouldn't hesistate to pick up, even at its introductory price-point.  If you liked Bastion for its artistic elements, you'll love Transistor, and if you enjoy tactical games you may end up liking Transistor even more than Bastion.  I know I did!  The main story lasted me roughly nine hours when doing everything available, and I have a bit of a completionist bent.  I have just started a New Game+ session.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Transistor - the followup game to Supergiant's Bastion - does exactly what it's pedecessor does. Delivering a polished top down action-RPG with a narrative driven storyline. The game has a pronounced "interactive storybook" feeling resulting from the games total linearity but to be fair the book is pretty damn good.Logan Cunningham's narration of Bastion was one of the most prominent features of Bastion and in Transistor he fulfills much the same role. Being your ever present companion he lends the game a magical yet melancholy feel. He exposes you to the concept of the world, the story and the characters without overexplaining anything and leaving you to fill in the blanks.The combat is no slouch either. 16 different moves can be combined or used as passive improvements and tested in the many encounters scattered throughout the storyline. How about firing a blast that scatters into bombs which scatter into more bombs when they explode...and then scatter into even more bombs afterwards - yeah.The music is really awesome as well and supplements the feel of the whole game perfectly. I'm just in love with the song "The Spine".A highly imaginitive game, an adult fairy tale, emotionally and intellectually stimulating - the full package. A really enjoyable experience. It just leaves me wondering what Supergiant Games' next storybook is going to be like.10/10 - Showing that not every game has to be a sandbox!(If combat is too hard: try Spark()+Mask()+Purge() and the Bounce() Passive and just spam it)

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												Transistor is a game with many, many great aspects, but one inherent flaw that will completely kill the game for many (particularly those who are less gaming-inclined). Let me start with the good bits:- The soundtrack is superb. It's just a small notch below Bastion's. The vocal pieces are great as well.- The art style is clear and concise. It suits the game, and the full-screen images and between-area cutscenes are nice.- The difficulty curve was implemented solidly, and the game includes a "Limiter" system (identical to the Idols in Bastion) which allows you to tweak the difficulty as you see fit by adding various new strengths to the enemies.- Combat is a bit clunky, but it makes sense within the game's premise. The Turn() system rectifies this by turning Transistor from an action game into a strategy game -- you have a "freeze time" ability which allows you to plan out your next moves and execute them afterwards.- All of your abilities (called Functions) can be equipped as active abilities (4), upgrades for active abilities (2 each), and passive abilities (4). It can get a bit convoluted and for some reason the menus didn't play well with my XBox controller's analog stick, but other than that it was fine.The humongous downside to this game is in death. When you die, your most powerful active ability will "overload", rendering it unusable until you have passed enough checkpoints. Essentially, this means that when you die, your character gets significantly less powerful -- and not just for the current encounter, either. Numerous Limiters cause your character to have less MEM (to equip Functions with) and cause those Functions to overload for longer. You could equip a very powerful ability that you don't plan to use to offset this -- but Functions cost MEM to equip, and your MEM is very limited until you approach the maximum value (which won't be until your second playthrough). Even with max MEM, I did not have enough to equip 4 decent actives, 4 passives and all upgrades for each active.This can be an incredibly frustrating process, and I often found myself dying repeatedly on purpose after the first death just to restart so I wouldn't lose everything for so long -- particularly with 10 Limiters on. If you are not very good at video games in general you will get very frustrated very fast, as the game is horribly unforgiving when it comes to death. I consider myself to be pretty OK at games but I still found this a bit irriating -- tolerable during the normal game but downright ridiculous with 10 Limiters.This game could easily be a 9/10, but I feel that dying completely soils an otherwise-wonderful experience. I'd be perfectly ok with flat-out dying and having to restart, or any other penalty really -- but not the one they chose. Not sure what they were thinking.So, all in all,"6/10 it was ok" - Foffy

content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												In Transistor, you play as the silent starlet and singer Red, traversing the eerily empty yet colourful city of Cloudbank. The city is slowly being overtaken by a mysterious force known only as the Process, and Cloudbank's leaders have something to do with it. Desperate to put a stop to whatever's happening, Red goes out to hunt -- but not alone. She carries a sword-like contraption with her known as the Transistor, whose dulcet and heartfelt tones guide her (and you) through a decaying world...Pros+ Beautiful, mesmerizing art & visuals+ The Transistor's narration of the game+ The dreamy, cyber-like soundtrack+ Combining functions for cool attack abilities+ The overall emotional impactCons- Combat can get a bit repetitive- The main story could have been longer & more in-depth- Some story elements are left deliberately vagueThis one of the most beautiful & artful games I've ever played! The overall cyberpunkish atmosphere, the gorgeous artwork, the hauntingly loving voice of the Transistor... The game has story elements that are quite familiar in the sci-fi sphere, but its execution is just so good. I fell in love with Red, the Transistor, and their world in a little over five hours already, and bawled my eyes out at certain points during the story. The emotional pacing, aided by the superb soundtrack, was fantastic. The upsides of this game far outweigh any downsides -- which for me personally, were the slightly repetitive combat (mostly due to lots of the same enemy types, I think) and the fact that the first run-through of the story was not longer, meatier & more in-depth.Like sci-fi, strategical planning in combat (on pause), and a deeply emotional story? Then this one's for you. This game is a perfect little jewel, with my compliments to Logan Cunningham's excellent voice acting as the Transistor.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												I usually trudge through a game's actual gameplay to get it over with, but Transistor's gameplay was so enjoyable and solid that I found myself playing through the entire game again the very next day. The deep customization of your abilities with the various Functions(), the blend of real time frantic play with the powerful frozen planning of Turn(), and difficulty scaling done right make all the game extremely enjoyable to play. There are unbelievably powerful ability combos in the game, but you're always facing enemies that can meet the challenge. If you're not, then there's still the combat modifiers and restrictions you can add. Story-wise, the world is significantly more sparse and spare than Supergiant's previous title, Bastion, but it seems to be an intentional choice: a bit of mystery allows for varied interpretations and a long narrative shelf life, which is what I think they were going for in this game. I think they leaned a little too far in the direction of limiting information, but the game doesn't suffer for it too much. I think the endgame buildup and final fight were excellently executed and they are going to be a favorite among the games I've played.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Transistor and the Studio's previous title Bastion, have some similarities. I may refer to Bastion for some notes, however to avoid confusing those who haven't played Bastion, I will refrain from mentioning it if possible.For the short version of this review:+ Absolutely fantastic art style, which can be seen in the environments, as well as enemy designs and your own character.+ Beautiful soundtrack, still listening to it now. Most of the songs (if not all of them) have been uploaded to Supergiant's official youtube page to listen to.+ Narration has plenty of dialogue for optional parts of the game, as well as lines during combat.+ Planning takes the center stage in combat. Transistor mode allows you to stop time, to set out some orders and execute them.+ 10+ abilities you can select from, all with interesting combinations to try out.+ NG+ brings stronger enemies and some new lines of dialogue to your second playthrough- The game is pretty short, I only got about 8 hours from the first playthrough.- Not the most challenging game, but it can become difficult if you add in 'limiters' in the form of extra difficulty options.- Frequent freezing if you've been playing for a few hours at a time, including during combat. I've heard of crashes, but haven't experienced them myself yet.+/- PC controls are pretty good, but may require you to get adjusted.+/- Story leaves a lot to personal interpretation, while some solid conclusion is given, some may not be content with what is there.Now for the details.StoryThis is a bit touchy, as I feel most of the story is really revealed in the second half of the game, or at the end, so I won't go into to much detail. At the start of the game, you're introduced as, Red a famous singer who has lost her voice and her friend to a strange group of individuals. Your friend's mind is thrown into a sword, the Transistor, which is the only weapon you'll use through the entire Journey. You begin following the only trail you have, seeking answers. Why you? What is their end goal? What is happening to the city? As your progress, you'll get your answers, and you'll watch as the world around you changes. Will you be truly satisfied with these answers though?Enivornments and Art StyleThis is mostly subjective I suppose. However the art style present feels unique, or at least like a mix of other influencing styles. The blend of realistic environments with this strange cyber-esque world creates a very surreal feeling to the world, which is only further added to by the art style. Enemies encountered called 'processes' are very machine like in nature.SoundtrackThe soundtrack is an interesting mix of genres, with Darren Korb's personal spin on all of them. Individual songs vary quite a bit. Some songs are very dramatic vocal heavy pieces, that will have you just gushing over the singer's fantastic voice. Other's will get you deeply rooted into the atmosphere, providing a great backdrop for walking around the interesting enviroments. There is of course, good combat music as well. I'm still listening to the sound track, as I write this review actually.NarrationThis is where the mention of Bastion has to come in. Bastion (as most of you likely know) had a great narration system, which had an interesting personality narrate your actions throughout the game, highlighting key moments. Transistor uses the same voice actor, for a slightly different system. Instead the narrator, is an actual character, or rather your sword. That's right your sword talks to you throughout the game. He will comment on specific spots and regions, his thoughts and opinions. Sarcastic remarks are thrown around as well occasionally. In combat he will make comments based on your actions, such as when you execute a turn, or if you lose too much health.While this is personal taste, I find this style of 'narration' much more interesting than Bastion's narration. In Bastion, it seemed as if he was just telling the story of the protagonist, maybe even to someone else. In Transistor, he plays a character, he frequently talks to Red, not some ambiguous audience. This adds some personality to both Red and the Transistor. As he spoke throughout the game I grew an attachment to him, and a level of appreciation. Red and the Transistor also seem to grow together throughout the game, even if they are only small subtle ques. I suppose this is a bit hard to convey though, as Red can't speak.GameplayThe gameplay is relatively simple at first, you have four abilities at your disposal, that can be activated with the right click and aimed with the mouse. You move with ASWD or left mouse click. It gets a little more interesting when the Transistor mode is brought in. Transistor mode allows you to stop time to move and use your abilites to plan your attack, and then execute it. Then of course, there's a cooldown between turns. This is probably the meat of the combat, more options besides your four abilites will open up to be used in interesting ways.Your four abilities have one initial modifier slot. These modifier slots obviously modify the ability, using other abilites. For example, Crash can be modified with Jaunt to be usable inbetween turns. Or you can combine Ping with Crash to proc mini-stuns on your target. Eventually you can unlock two modifier slots for your abilities which will introduce more options. Such as a Crash that splits into three projectiles and explodes on impact. Keep in mind there are about 10 abilities, so the combinations can get a bit crazy. This however, makes it all the more fun.Overall:It's a fantastic game with plenty to offer in terms of execution and style, but it feels lacking in the amount of content it has to deliver. It may be a normal length singleplayer game (by today's standards), it still doesn't offer a large quantity. However the quality debatably makes up for the short length. For some, this will leave a lasting impression, an experience you won't forget. One that has such a unique combat system, combined with a beautiful soundtrack, art style, and presentation. If you don't care for that stuff however, this game might not be your sort of thing. Don't expect an open world sandbox experience.Final Rating: 7.5 / 10

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												From the creative geniuses at Supergiant Games comes Transistor, a birds-eye sci-fi RPG with a strategic twist in its gameplay functions that creates a gaming experience that is both refreshing and unique in today's video game market. The first thing the player will notice in the game is the art-style and narrative reminiscent of Bastion; stylized environments, characters and enemies that can be instantly recognized and a story that is unveiled in little pieces through the smooth tones of the games narrator, who is actually the talking sword you're using throughout the game. Which creates a much more atmospheric effect than Bastion as the narrator is sharing in your experience instead of outlining what happens as you play. Transistor's story is difficult to percieve at the beginning, but as the player progresses and pays attention to the narrative and ques from the world one can piece it together over time. For the gameplay, Transistor is similar to Bastion in the birds-eye view controls and sporadic groups of enemies that have different strengths and weaknesses that you must approach in a careful manner or else you risk exposing yourself to more damage than needed. However, that is where the similarities between the two games end. Transistor uses a "Turn()" function that allows the player to pause combat in order to plan out their movements and attacks, then executing them in rapid succession, Turn() is mildly similar to the VATS system in Fallout 3, but much more unique and reactive than simply "clik on whurr u wanna shewt and hope u dunt miss". Turn() is useful for allowing yourself to punch a hole through enemy defences or to allow yourself some breathing room. However the drawback that must be taken into consideration is the short cooldown after Turn() ends, during which you are completely vulnerable as you cannot attack until the cooldown duration ends. Turn() gives players endless possibilities when combined with the notable selection of specific attacks that you are given access to, which can range from a simple energy blast to a quick dash, and even summoning a friendly unit to help you in combat (which can also be controlled during Turn()). One thing that makes the combat fast-paced and reactive are the "cells" dropped by all enemies when killed. Cells have a roughly 10 second cooldown timer when dropped, and if aren't picked up before the duration ends the enemy you just killed will respawn with full health, which in my opinion makes the combat much more dynamic and fast paced. Another point of interest in the combat system is the power selection and upgrade system. The player gathers a good selection of abilities throughout the game, but you can only equip four at a time. Never fear, because you can take the other abilities you gathered and use them to upgrade the abilities you currently have equipped to create powerful combinations. The only thing keeping you from upgrading yourself to over-powered proportions and keeping the gameplay balanced is the memory, which will require consideration while upgrading.Finally, instead of chugging down health regenerating items in combat like in Bastion, the player instead needs to be absolutely mindful of their current health. When your health is depleted you will automatically enter an "Emergency Turn()" that gives you the chance to eliminate the immediate threat. But once you execute the Turn() you still only have one hitpoint left, and if you get hit again during the cooldown you will return to full health but one of your abilites will be "overloaded" and cannot be used until you reach an "access point" (which not only act as save points but also are the only places where you can equip and upgrade your abilities). Esentially your abilities act as your lives, and the more you "die" at a certain area, the more difficult that area will become.To summarize, Transistor is in my opinion much more fun than Bastion and a game I thoroughly enjoy playing. I honestly recommend Transistor to all who are reading this review.
