												Gorgeous Artwork, amazing soundtrack, intriguing combat system and good use of isometric perspective, if the game was only about that it would have been a undoubtedly masterpiece. But when it comes to the plot it is far too vague.Don't get me wrong, I like being thrown in medias res and struggling to understand the situation piece by piece but on this game they got a bit too far: you don't know where you are and more importantly which are your world "rules" (more or less like in physics rules). Not knowing the "limits" of your surroundings you can't empathize with the main characters and their story, you don't know who they are and what is their role in the world either (again, because you don't know what is the world you're playing your part in).So, well, with a little bit more knowledge about the world (not the "politics" that you can read on the terminals) I'd have been able to empathize with the main characters and understand the plot completely.I also like to spend a few words on the combat system itself. I don't know if something like that already existed, but, well, the hybrid turn/real-time combat system was amazing. You have to both plan your turn() and the time before the next turn(). Seldom being off-turn is better for strategic reasons and you have to take in considerations that too.Finally, there are no ninja-spawns you cannot react to (hello Valkyria Chronicles and partly XCOM: Enemy Unknown) meaning that you never feel like the game is not fair.So, in my opinion, if you approach this game as a multimedia artbook you will enjoy it from start, far, far more than expecting something from the plot or trying to understand the cyberpunk-art-deco world you're thrown in.Recommended to art-lovers and romantics.

Posted: December 2, 2014
												Following on from Bastion, Transistor is yet another brilliant piece of gameplay and art, and is just a truly great experience. However, there are a few things that make it different from Bastion.First of all, the perspective is the same. The gameplay, however, is different. Instead of running in and hitting everything, your approach should be more careful because enemies tend to be a lot more deadly than they are in Bastion. You don't really have any form of instant healing (other than a few lifesteal upgrades you can find for your weapon) so you have to be much more careful. What allows you to do that while still destroying all these aggressive and powerful enemies is the turn-based system that you can switch to at any time. Time is paused while you plan your moves, and each step you take and attack you set up spends a bit of the bar at the top, which signifies how much you can do in one turn. Stronger moves generally take up more of the bar. You then end the turn and watch it all unfold as you quickly decimate your enemies... that is, if you set it up right.The challenge of the game is trying to kill your enemies as quickly and efficiently as possible, because if you finish your planning phase and you're out of energy for another turn, you may die very quickly as enemies rush to kill you. There is far more strategy than hacking and/or slashing to be found in Transistor. If you wanted to do the whole game without the  planning system, it's probably possible except for maybe the final boss fight. It will be very difficult though.Of course, the music in this game is even more spectacular than that of Bastion. You play as Red, a singer who has lost her voice completely. Although she can no longer sing, she can hum, and there is in fact a button that lets you start humming along to the current music playing in the background. Each track fits each level and the situation you're in, and each track is also expertly well done. I LOVE all the aspects of the music in this game. Without it the atmosphere wouldn't be quite the same.Speaking of atmosphere, art style is comparable to Bastion but has its own unique elements. The attention to detail is still there, however, which makes it beautiful to look at. The level design is similar throughout the whole game. However, it's not boring, just consistent. The world is very unique and futuristic, providing a strong contrast to Bastion. Supergiant Games are clearly trying to cover more than just one theme of games which is always interesting to see a developer do. In this case it works spectacularly. The enemies are also varied and you are introduced to more as the game goes on, each with their own special behaviours and attacks. The enemies fit very well with their environment as they are all robotic-looking. The boss fights are also very different from each other, which was something Bastion generally lacked. The game manages to give you plenty of action to keep yourself entertained. There are also small training rooms that you can progress through to get rewards.The story is told similarly to Bastion; a narrator guides you through the whole game, but this time the narrator is actually with you the entire time. In a way you feel less lonely, but in another way, you feel more lonely. You and the narrator are in this together, but you are alone together. The world is full of nothing but danger and despair, but there is the glitter of hope that you may somehow fix this in the end. The voice acting is fairly good, but not totally on par with Bastion's. However, the story is compelling and well written, keeping you playing and listening the whole way through.The game is amazing. I am going to be keeping a close eye on Supergiant Games in the coming years, and I hope to more excellent entertainment from them. If you like art in all forms, as well as gameplay that provides a perfect mix of action and basic strategy, then this is for you. Buy this game, support these developers, have a lovely time humming the soundtrack in the shower after you beat Transistor.

Posted: August 2, 2014
												Transistor is staggeringly beautiful. All of the art, the setting, the music, the writing, all of it. It's also a pretty big departure from Bastion, which was made by the same developers. Yes, it's the same perspective, and there's an ever-present narrator, and the protagonist is mute, and you can increase the difficulty in a piecemeal fashion. The similarities end there. While you can play Transistor like an action game, it really requires more strategy than that. It has an active-pause system, where you can pause the action, plot out a set number of attacks or movements, and then unpause to see the results. The main loop ends up being pause, attack, run, which leads to a lot of guerilla tactics, more than straight out blasting enemies.The ability system is also super interesting. Every ability, whether it's a straight attack, or a cloak, or a bomb, can be used as-is, attached to another ability to lend it different qualities, or set as a passive bonus to yourself. This leads to a ton of combinations of attacks. Some work better than others, but they all feel unique. The limits to the system is that each ability has a memory requirement, and you have a memory limit. So you can stack up on a couple heavy hitters, but you limit yourself to a small number of attacks or bonuses. Likewise, you can have a full complement of attacks and bonuses, but you'll be lacking the most powerful of them. The one complaint I have is that the story is less straight forward than most video games. That doesn't mean it has a bad story, or that it's incomprehensible. It just takes more attention to the details than most. By the end, you'll probably get the gist of it, but expect to be a little disoriented.

												So, first review for Transistor:The game is pretty, both to the eyes and the ears. Music is solid (beyond solid, it's ♥♥♥♥ing amazing), the art style is gorgeous (sort of what would happen if you took the cel-shaded style of Bastion and crossed it with Art Deco), and the detail is good, but not overdone or too busy.The gameplay certainly won't be for everyone, but I like it. 												6/10This game was made by the makers of Bastion, so I had my hopes up. Sadly, while the graphic style and music is gorgeous, the story and gameplay are lacking cohesion. Similar to Bastion the action is controlled from isometric view and has lots of action rpg elements. There is real time combat and a turn mode, which stops the action and allows you to plan moves, which are then executed. Combat in real time is clunky, as the enemies move much to fast to evade, which forces the player into the turn mode. Consequently the game forces hit and run tactics. Stop the action, move close to the enemy, hit him with a few spells and run out of range. Rinse and repeat.One of the few good things about combat is the endless combinations of skills you can use. Each of the skills can be used as primary or enhancer of another skill. Sadly, you will end up using the 1-3 heavy hitting spells, without ever experimenting too much.All in all the developers did not succeed making this a cohesive game. Graphics and sound are great, gameplay and story telling are lacking. So you find yourself walking down pretty hallways without ever caring about the enemies you kill or knowing what exactly happened in this dystopian world.

Posted: August 1, 2014
												Transistor is an original, intelligent and lucid action RPG. The game revolves around Red, a singer whose voice was stolen by the Camerata, a group of individuals determined to Process a city that serves its people. Without formally identifying or constructing her as so, Red is presented as a strong female protagonist; this means she is without any of the clichés that so often inhibit this archetype. Supergiant masterfully pulls off a plot that gives her agency and the ability to sculpt a world inhabited by a cast of colourful characters whom the player learns about through the Functions() of the Transistor. The diversity of the characters, in particular, is to be commended: there are black and mixed-race, gay, lesbian and transgender characters.The Function() system is at the heart of the game; it allows the player to combine different attacks and abilities in either primary, upgrade, or passive slots, resulting in a unique experience with approximately 22bn different combinations to be had. The system encourages experimentation, and so leads the player in to a kind of exasperating perfectionism: you want to get your loudout exactly right. The mix of frantic, fast-paced real time action and the suspended realm that Turn() provides to plan a sequence of moves is something quite unique and, surprisingly, it doesn't get tiresome. The enemies are varied enough to keep the battles interesting; they regularly upgrade themselves to match your own increasing prowess and there are enough different kinds to always provide a challenge.The soundtrack is both touching and transcendental; it encapsulates the changing pace of the game, from the arid mystery of a deserted Cloudbank at the beginning to the decaying ruins of a Processed world at the end. The mixture of electronica-esque synths, ambient Portal-like sounds and well-timed guitar riffs give suitable gravitas at just the correct moments. The music feels alive; it actively changes as you switch between states and the Turn() mode.It's the little things in Transistor that really complete it. Flavour text is what drives the realism and the allusions to software and programming are delightful to see. The different chapters of the plot and the scenes are strung together well enough so the entire game flows. Romanticised additions like the motorbike and the posters add a sense of fun  to the game and an importance to the role that Red has.The most striking element of the game is probably the artwork; the visuals are stunning and utilise different hues, colours, art styles and changes in lighting to illuminate Cloudbank. Cloudbank is a city inside a computer, but it feels very much real. The nuanced dichotomy of an organic, breathing world that is seen through the window of Red and the basic binary foundation that underlies the entire premise is linked delicately with endless, gorgeous pieces of artwork and cutscenes and this is remarkable.What makes Transistor a gem is the seamless integration of the idiosyncratic creativity of these elements -- music, artwork, plot and mechanics -- that would only be expected to find in the most successful of indie games, with the overall polish that usually only blockbuster games can pull off. The entire game has a glistening shine that suceeds in being both immersive and compelling, pulling the player into the digital utopia of Cloudbank and refusing to let them go. Certainly a niche game, but it can't be recommended enough.

												I don't review many games, but Transistor, much like SuperGiant's previous title, Bastion, exceeded my expectations on all fronts.This game is a tremendously soulful piece of work, and from the very start to the very end, is first and foremost a work of art. The music, narration, artistic style and presentation flow together in a way that I would probably say outclasses almost any other game i've played. Anyone with a quibble of curiousity and a penchant for great games, or even works of art, should immediately purchase Transistor (AND Bastion) and enjoy the ride.To touch on the gameplay itself, the combat is inventive and blends several previously done elements (pseudo-turn based combat, action queues, tactical-execution-based combat) into a pretty seamless and enjoyable experience. It is two parts arcade, one part strategic pause-and-think game. It remains fresh and has a lot of room for player creativity due to the openly configurable nature of abilities acquired throughout the game.What follows are some brief pros/cons:Pros:+Incredible Art. From music to artwork, this entire game is a masterpiece.+Gameplay. The combat remains fresh, enjoyable, and creative all the way through.+Difficulty.  Like bastion, difficulty is born of modifiers you can apply to enemies, which give you bonuses for being brave.+Storyline.  Again, this is a work of art and the storyline is rich, heartfelt, and incredibly immersive.+Soundtrack.  Incredible, as usual.Cons:-Length.   The game itself isn't that long, although there are excuses to re-play the game with new conditions and toy around with the combat some more.That's really all I can see anyone really griping about with this game.In total, I'd give Transistor a 9.5/10, as one of the most absolutely awesome pieces of work i've seen in terms of gaming. It isn't a triple-A 40 hour experience... but it's an incredibly rich, artistic romp through an engaging and incredibly envisioned city of Cloudbank.9.5/10-Colt

												Bastion is an easy and accurate point of comparison for Transistor; if you like one, you'll probably like the other. But the gameplay here is a lot deeper and richer, so it's worth a look even if you didn't care for Supergiant's previous effort.Similar to Bastion, the story is simple but beautifully presented. The futuristic/maybe-computerized city of Cloudbank is a visually lush setting for monster bashing, and the snippets you find and decipher throughout the game paint a unique portrait of the city's history and the villain's motivations. It's easy to get drawn in, even if, from a player's perspective, you're just running around murdering everything in your path.It probably helps that your rampaging is so enjoyable. Combat is real-time, but you can periodically freeze time to cue up a string of commands as if it were turn-based. That combined with the incredibly flexible system of combining your power-ups into increasingly elaborate attacks opens up a tremendous number of options, both on-the-fly and in terms of your overall playstyle. Want to kite around and chip away at range? You can spec for that. Want to play fully real-time as a bruiser? Sure. Want to mind control everyone into killing each other? Go for it. Run around unleashing monster turn-based combos whenever you can? Yessir.If anything, the biggest problem is that the mechanics are SO flexible that it gets daunting. Thankfully, there are a handful of mechanics that guide you towards new combinations (avoiding the Diablo 3 "here is a new option that you have no reason to care about" issue) and, like Bastion, the game's difficulty is rather forgiving but has options for you to increase it on the fly.But bottom line, this is beautiful, enjoyable, and distinct experience that doesn't overstay its welcome. Highly recommended.

Full disclosure:This review was written pretty much hot off the presses of finishing the game, and as such everything below is expressive of my raw impressions of the game after completion. Let that say what it will of the quality of my review.--------------------------------------------Supergiant Games has hit the ball out of the park yet again with their second game. As I've made apparent, I liked Bastion, but this game is substantially different from Bastion in many ways. So if you didn't like Bastion (I hope you at least liked the music and narration), don't let that put you off of Transistor. How is Transistor different from Bastion, you might ask? The combat is entirely different, replacing a weapon-based combat system with an ability-based system with impressive depth. As you proceed through the game, you gain new abilities either through leveling up or encountering certain points, and each of these abilities is equipped in one of four slots (1-4 are their hotkeys). However, each of these slots has one open subslot and an additional unlockable subslot, and beside the four base slots, are two slots on each side that are passive slots. As I said, very impressive depth, because each ability operates differently based on whether it's equipped primarily (in the four slots), complementarily (in one of the eight subslots), or supplementarily (in one of four passive slots). The world is likewise in its differences. You're no longer in a fantasy-esque setting in Transistor, and you don't have to worry about falling off floating platforms anymore. You're grounded, but in a world as far out there as Bastion's. It's a fascinating modern, sci-fi styled world full of mysteries to try to grapple with, not unlike Bastion. Yet, these mysteries aren't resolved like Bastion's, not laid out for you by anyone. If you want to understand Cloudbank, you're gonna have to get digging for yourself. Fortunately, you'll probably want to after exploring the place and its characters.The cast is as dynamic as Bastion's, if not more so. There's more detailed background on the much larger casting this time around, and there's more chatter occurring. This isn't to say you're frequently stopped for conversations and the like, you're definitely not, and all the background is entirely optional to look into. You can play the game ignoring the characters as much as you like, and still enjoy it as much as if you were to pay attention, much as in Supergiant's previous title.The music is as vibrant as ever in this game. It's also as vital to the atmosphere as in Bastion, and while there are equally energetic tracks in Transistor's soundtrack as in Bastion, it's of a very different styling. It's softer, of an electronic jazz vibe, compared to some of Bastion's harder, folksy tunes. If you didn't enjoy Bastion's soundtrack, don't worry, Darren Korb has outdone himself in making Transistor's soundtrack distinct from Bastion's, something you can't necessarily say for many musicians.The story is fantastic...If you don't mind a story that won't hold your hand. The plot will keep you moving forward to figure out what happened to Red, as well as who acted against her and why, but perhaps even more compelling than that is understanding the world she lives in. Every part of the story from the characters to the setting to what led up to your adventure is a mystery for you to solve, and personally, I loved that. Even after having finished the game, I have questions, and I doubt there are answers, but I like being left with room to imagine on top of their world.If you don't like that, you may not enjoy it, but there's so much more to the game than that to enjoy if you can look past your discomfort with it. The gameplay and music and art are all lovely to experience and behold.The artwork is of a different stripe than Bastion's. It's a mixture of darkness and brightness, in a bit of contrast to Bastion's primarily bright, varied color palette. Transistor has a harsher, darker color scheme, seemingly set mostly at night, but is broken up by bright lights throughout and a transition into a lighter color scheme as the game proceeds. This isn't dark grays accompanied by muddy browns as seen in other games by any stretch of the imagination, but it is something of a darker color scheme if you're coming from Bastion. Not to mention it's also in an urban setting with more futuristic and interestingly styled buildings. That also serves to differentiate the artwork drastically in its own right, having you ascending stairs along the edge of towering structures and taking elevators here and there amidst buildings serves as a different experience than Bastion would have you expecting.Conclusion: If you're looking for a unique scifi styled game with a complex cast of characters with splendid voice acting, music, gameplay,  and artwork, you can't find much better than Transistor right now. Frankly, if you have to decide between this and Watch Dogs, coming out tomorrow as of this writing, I'd say save your money and buy this. While I have nothing against Watch Dogs and intend to get it myself, I think you'll find a far more compelling experience in Transistor, in essentially every way.Thanks for reading! I hope this helped inform you of the game, and led you to pick it up. It's absolutely worth it.

												Gorgeous Artwork, amazing soundtrack, intriguing combat system and good use of isometric perspective, if the game was only about that it would have been a undoubtedly masterpiece. But when it comes to the plot it is far too vague.Don't get me wrong, I like being thrown in medias res and struggling to understand the situation piece by piece but on this game they got a bit too far: you don't know where you are and more importantly which are your world "rules" (more or less like in physics rules). Not knowing the "limits" of your surroundings you can't empathize with the main characters and their story, you don't know who they are and what is their role in the world either (again, because you don't know what is the world you're playing your part in).So, well, with a little bit more knowledge about the world (not the "politics" that you can read on the terminals) I'd have been able to empathize with the main characters and understand the plot completely.I also like to spend a few words on the combat system itself. I don't know if something like that already existed, but, well, the hybrid turn/real-time combat system was amazing. You have to both plan your turn() and the time before the next turn(). Seldom being off-turn is better for strategic reasons and you have to take in considerations that too.Finally, there are no ninja-spawns you cannot react to (hello Valkyria Chronicles and partly XCOM: Enemy Unknown) meaning that you never feel like the game is not fair.So, in my opinion, if you approach this game as a multimedia artbook you will enjoy it from start, far, far more than expecting something from the plot or trying to understand the cyberpunk-art-deco world you're thrown in.Recommended to art-lovers and romantics.

Posted: December 30, 2015
												TL;DR: Transistor is a good game, and it will make you feel good.Transistor is a narrative-driven turn-based game that always seemed to be reminding me of the Tron universe. It's in the middle of an apocalypse, yet it has an eerie peacefulness about it. As you go about the world and destroy the monsters that are transforming the world, you can't help but take a step back and listen to the protaganist Red hum along to the background music, or look out over a pier for a few seconds and think about the history of a town you never knew. Something about this game calms you down. All of the mechanics seem to cater to a casual playstyle, although some moments can be very intense. Even the fast and reflexive combat system seems to be designed to make you breathe. You can take as much time as you want to plan out your moves, take a breather, take a break from the loud fighting music and explosions that are happening around you. It's calming.Of course, there's the narrator. The more I play games with great narrators like The Stanley Parable or Bastion (the latter of which was the same creator of Transistor). The narrator of Transistor is more personal than the two, though. It addresses the character, not the player. You are simply an observer to this story, and the narrator is unaware of your existence. This game is between Red and her love. You are granted the gift of watching. It's very touching and emotional at some points to realize that this story has to end somehow, and the few moments where the narrator leaves you feel so void and wrong. I'm not really sure what to say about the narration in this game, other than it's not really narration at all. There's just only one character with dialogue.As I said, everything in this game seems to be designed to make you feel calm and content. As evil and chaotic as some parts of this game are, all of it makes you feel reflective, nostalgiac almost. It's a good feeling. This game will make you feel good. It's a pity that I can't think of eloquent enough words to describe this game. Maybe it's because there's a woman screaming nonsense in the other room and I can't process thoughts (sorry if parts of this review don't make sense, but I honestly can't hear myself think), but I think mostly it's because when you find something that is truly beautiful, it doesn't take well to words, and although I wouldn't say this game is pure beauty and art, it is beautiful, and it is deliberate in its design. That's all I ask from a game.

The combat is a unique blend of strategy and an action game where the player can freeze time and plan out their attack on the "Process". As with Bastion, there are game modifiers that make this game tougher, making the need for this planning mode essential. I cannot praise this game enough. A run through of the story may be a brief 6 hours but it does not over stay its welcome and feels complete in almost every way. The game does not hold your hand and expects you as a player to dig into the world to get the most out of it.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Simply put, Transistor is beautiful. The soundtrack composed by Darren Korb buzzes with electric, jazzy energy. The painted artstyle, courtesy of Jen Zee, drenches protagonist Red's world of Cloudbank in a gorgeous Art Nouveau - meets - cyberpunk atmosphere. If you played Supergiant Games's spiritual predecessor Bastion, you'll recognize Rucks's silky-smooth narration as the voice within Red's attendant sword, the titular Transistor. If nothing else, the game has an irreversible sense of style - from the way the Transistor, the titular weapon, trails along the ground, to the novel option to hum in time with the background music. Mute though she may be, Red - and the player - leave their voices imprinted upon the Processed world.Gameplay is innovative, and expands upon the isometric action style that Bastion perfected. The core of Transistor's mechanics are various Functions that represent an in-game concept - breaching, crashing, even calling for help. These translate into active abilities - a damaging linear attack, a single-target disable, and the ability to summon a robotic helper, respectively - as well as traits used to modify functions- the ability to extend range of functions, addition of a disable utility to functions, and modifying the trait to spawn weak allies when an enemy is killed - and passive abilities that can be used to modify yourself, which, for the sake of length, will not be mentioned. Combat is also made more strategic by the Turn() ability, which, when activated, allows the player to go into a pseudo-"planning mode," halting battle and allowing the player to input a certain number of Functions and movements. Upon deactivation of the Turn(), Red activates all of the moves near-instantaneously, but is vulnerable and has most Functions disabled until the Turn() meter passively regenerates. Players can choose to either maximize their Turn() potential, packing their moveset with tons of burst and evasion Functions, choose to play it real-time using sustain and distraction Functions, or a mixture of the two.Story is intimately tied to gameplay, as leveling up, using Functions, and empowering the enemy Process with certain upgrades allow for greater fleshing out of the world - a storytelling device that encourages the player to experiment with different approaches to the game. It does, however, mean that the story suffers somewhat in terms of actual content - a speedrunning player will find the plot threads to be confusing and sparse. Once one unravels all the various story threads though, , a greater plot does begin to emerge from the tangled network of Cloudbank's world.  If any real criticism can exist for Transistor, it may be that it does not quite live up to Bastion, in terms of sheer narrative clarity. The characters, perhaps, never feel as fully realized as the Kid, Zia, or Zulf (though perhaps the incredible ending sequence will object.) But Transistor is its own subroutine, and to contradict a certain quote, when nothing changes, well - nothing changes.

Posted: December 30, 2015
												TL;DR: Transistor is a good game, and it will make you feel good.Transistor is a narrative-driven turn-based game that always seemed to be reminding me of the Tron universe. It's in the middle of an apocalypse, yet it has an eerie peacefulness about it. As you go about the world and destroy the monsters that are transforming the world, you can't help but take a step back and listen to the protaganist Red hum along to the background music, or look out over a pier for a few seconds and think about the history of a town you never knew. Something about this game calms you down. All of the mechanics seem to cater to a casual playstyle, although some moments can be very intense. Even the fast and reflexive combat system seems to be designed to make you breathe. You can take as much time as you want to plan out your moves, take a breather, take a break from the loud fighting music and explosions that are happening around you. It's calming.Of course, there's the narrator. The more I play games with great narrators like The Stanley Parable or Bastion (the latter of which was the same creator of Transistor). The narrator of Transistor is more personal than the two, though. It addresses the character, not the player. You are simply an observer to this story, and the narrator is unaware of your existence. This game is between Red and her love. You are granted the gift of watching. It's very touching and emotional at some points to realize that this story has to end somehow, and the few moments where the narrator leaves you feel so void and wrong. I'm not really sure what to say about the narration in this game, other than it's not really narration at all. There's just only one character with dialogue.As I said, everything in this game seems to be designed to make you feel calm and content. As evil and chaotic as some parts of this game are, all of it makes you feel reflective, nostalgiac almost. It's a good feeling. This game will make you feel good. It's a pity that I can't think of eloquent enough words to describe this game. Maybe it's because there's a woman screaming nonsense in the other room and I can't process thoughts (sorry if parts of this review don't make sense, but I honestly can't hear myself think), but I think mostly it's because when you find something that is truly beautiful, it doesn't take well to words, and although I wouldn't say this game is pure beauty and art, it is beautiful, and it is deliberate in its design. That's all I ask from a game.

Posted: January 10, 2016
												It took a while for Transistor to really hook me (about 2/3 of the way through my first playthrough), but at that point I went from mildly disappointed (I really loved Supergiant's previous game, Bastion), to entirely satisfied.  I think the reason for all this is that the combat system is really quite deep, and it took a lot of experimentation before I really started understanding the potential there.  I'm playing it through a second time now and really enjoying it.Aside from the mechanics, the game is beautiful and the soundtrack is excellent.  The story is really intriguing and told in a very minimal way.   A lot of it is told through short voice clips, but if you want to learn more about what is happening, you can also get snipets of story through interacting with the environment, from experimenting with the combat system or from reading message boards :)  Even the way the soundtrack is done complements the story.  I didn't play Bastion on new game+ because I felt like I experienced the whole thing and was satisfied at the end.  I think Transistor essentially requires a second playthrough because there's so much subtle detail packed in that you are bound to miss a lot of it the first time through.  Transistor is a really excellent game, but it is especially rewarding if you are willing to put some effort in.

Posted: September 3, 2015
												Transistor is a top-down, turn-based adventure game that takes place in a utopian society. The gameplay is very different from Bastion; in this game, all attacks are planned beforehand during each turn. This game is beautiful to look at and holds a beautiful story within.Pros:+From the music, to the voice acting, to the writing, to the art, this game is beautifully executed. I like the gameplay, but this is definitely a game you buy for the music, story and artwork.+The romance in this game felt genuine and believable to me.+The gameplay is entertaining; different "functions" (attacks) can be combined in a multitude of combinations, and there are multiple ways to win each battle.+Like Bastion, there is a new game plus mode where you can restart the game at a higher difficulty and continue levelling.+For those who like the battles, there are bonus challenges, similar to Bastion.Cons:-While planning your turn, you can't pan the screen to look at far away enemies. This is a minimal problem, as you can usually see far enough anyways, and you can also simply walk where you want to see and then cancel the move.This game took me ten hours to complete, but my girlfriend completed it in four hours, which I find amazing. I think most people will take at least six if not 7-8 hours.I really loved this game. While they don't have the big budget of a AAA company, Supergiant has managed to craft something that is both more unique and more impressive than most AAA games.

												This game. Reader, let me tell you about this game. This game captures... that something. It also captures your heart. From the very first moment, the moment the game thrusts you into its beautiful clutches, I couldn't help but melt in the embrace of the beauty that is this game. Visually, the game is striking, and captures all the little nuances. The way Red moves with the Transistor wrapped in her arms, the world slowly becoming different. Some say the game is a bit short, and yes, it doesn't give quite the same play time as you would expect out of a game such as a Bethesdian RPG. But that's okay. The game finishes itself before it overstays its welcome. The one true problem I had with this game was it felt like it fell just... just a bit short. Posted: July 20, 2016
												Transistor.I honestly can't tell which one, Bastion or Transistor were more to my liking. Both have their awesome unique mechanics and stunning music.When you start the game, you don't have a main menu, instead you are put right into the game. This really took my by surprise. I think you'll understand what I mean once you launch the game.So, lets get on with it.The Plot: 10/10Just like in Bastion, you are thrown right into the game without any introduction. Just a gal with a sword-like object which apparently talks. First I had no idea what was talking to me. The further you go into the story, the more is revealed, along with the backstory of Red (the main character, the musician). Soon it appears that 4 villans, the Camerata, those who basically own the city Cloudbank. Not only that, they are mostly scientists who care for the city, but made a mistake, and... well, you'll find out.Gameplay: 9/10Bastion had a right-left-midbutton gameplay, while here you get abilities that you use. Not only that, it is also followed with Turn() feature, a planning feature that allows you to stop time and make actions like walking and using abilities for the price of Turn() potential (lets call it that). For instance, a Breach() ability (your very first ability you have access to) uses 20 Turn().Not only that, you get some introduction to different characters who these abilities belonged to. For example, Red's ability is Breach(), an ability that stuns the target and makes it more vulnerable for 1.6 secs. Another one was a racer, when you used the transistor to "absorb" his essence, you retrieved an ability that allows you to blink. Furthermore, you can read info on these abilities that reveal about the character.Each ability can also be used as a passive or an upgrade to a different abilities. They can be swapped at any time when you get to an access point.And of course, remember the Shrine in Bastion? Here you have so called "Limiters", they work exactly the same as those things in the Shrine, except they also reveal info on the "Process" if used.Music: 10/10I won't comment on this. No point.Visuals: 10/10Seriously, the visuals are just amazing. Some may complain tho, that they don't like cyberpunk stuff, but to me, the art in this is majestic. The lights, the sketches, everything deserves a 10 in my opinion.Duration: 7/10Sadly, its rather short, but if you play with limiters you may get a longer enjoyment from this. That's exactly what I did with Bastion. Yet Transistor is still shorter than Bastion. I really wish it either had a continuation or just a longer gameplay. That may ruin the plot however.Replayable? Yes, definitely. Its worth replaying. Unlike Bastion, you don't have to grind here to get levels (because you can't, lol).Overall:I really want to give it 10/10, but I can't. I honestly just can't. I want it to be a bit longer, I want to get more enjoyment, maybe have a reality where Process comes from, where I can destroy its core, where I can have some sort of a choice like in Half-Life at the very end, or... I don't know. I just feel the urge for this to be longer.So any way.9/10, I can't wait for Supergiant games to release a new game. Maybe soon, maybe later, maybe next year (I actually heard they are working on a new game to be released in 2017).TL;DR Transistor is awesome, has great music, gameplay mechanics and great plot. If you feel like you need a game that would allow you to relax and feel some enjoyment, then this is it. I am a Dota 2 player myself, and nothing relaxed me more than Bastion and Transistor (especially transistor, tbh). Go buy it.

Posted: January 7, 2016
												Super Giant Games had improved themselves after Bastion and created this outstanding piece of art. The artwork is stunningly beautiful, everything is flourished with colours. Moreover, they've changed the artstyle for the characters: from chibi-ish Bastion into a more realistic style. The soundtrack music blends perfectly with the game, it gives that futuristic cyberpunk atmosphere. Even in the song 'Sandbox', you can still here bleeps of machine, indicating it's some sort of an artificial environment. Super Giant Games is consistently giving the function to raise the difficulty level (Limiters) and also a wide range of play style just like Bastion.  The game is more of a tactical approach, but it also gives the option to go hack 'n slash/ beat'em up mode. The game is also more punishing by destroying a random Function everytime your health is depleted. Although the destroyed Function is recoverable, it might be a crucial one during that encounter. The storyline is a bit vague. Even if you listen closely to everyone, there are still questions remain. However, each of the side characters have been given surprisingly detailed  back stories, although they are not directly linked with the main storyline. Overall, this game is very much enjoyable: audibly, visually, and gameplay-wise. The only downside I had was the challenges and bosses, which I felt  are not as difficult as Bastion's.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Bastion was a massive success for Super Giant Games. Most people have played it and numerous gamers own it on at least two different machines. With that in mind it would have been easy for the studio to release a sequel or spiritual successor to it. We’d all have played it, loved it, and raved about it. Transistor is not like Bastion.Starting in a beautifully depicted futuristic city scape you pull an electronic sword from a body and you’re on your way. No explanation is given and no background about the world or yourself is forthcoming. The player, like the character you control is thrown in, as if awakening from some strange dream and this gives a wonderful sense of mystery and discovery as you progress.From the outside this may look to share some similarities with Bastion. The perspective is the same and there is also a narrator of sorts, although he is talking to the female protagonist as you go. Right at the start you begin to think this is going to be another hack and slash but then about five minutes in it asks you to hit the freeze button and everything changes.Here, you suddenly realise you are actually in a real time/turn based cross over style RPG. You can execute attacks in real time (and even boost them to activate almost instantly), but the real trick is mastering the freeze system. Hitting the button stops everything and you then have an action bar you can use up before the enemy moves again. It’s kind of like the V.A.T.S system in Fallout 3 or the system at work in Vagrant Story.During this time you can move around and stack up attacks. Pressing the button again sends you into action like a blur across the screen. The downside is that you then can’t use any attacks or special moves until the bar has regenerated in full. The more attacks you use, the longer the bar takes to recharge. This means you have to be extremely careful about what you are doing as you are often slower than the enemy robots sent to stop you. It’s essential to get in, attack and get back out to a place you can safely recharge as avoiding damage otherwise is almost impossible and you’ll be downed in no time.If your health bar depletes while you have charge time you’ll get a chance to move away from danger. If not, one of your powers will be damaged and unusable until you make it to two save points. This severely limits your attacking options and often leads to a daisy chain effect of you losing all your powers and flat lining. On the off chance you are finding things too easy you can also add a number of handicaps as you go which increase difficulty and the amount of experience you gain.The options you have to play around with are numerous and can be set up in a ton of different ways. This is one of Transistors strengths but we can see it easily overwhelming some players. When you gain a power you can do one of three things with it. Equipping it in an active slot will allow the player to use it via a button press. This could be a long range attack, a fast dodge, an area effect attack or something like summoning a creature to assist you. All attacks have different speeds in real time combat and few of them work fast enough to run through the game hacking away without the freeze system. Each active power can also be boosted by equipping powers as support. For instance, you could take the bouncing bomb power and add it to your long range attack, thus making the attack ricochet off enemies and into others.  You can add two boosters to each active attack which opens up all sorts of crazy possibilities. Finally, you can add powers to your passive support slots. This means they normally do things like boost player speed or increase resistance. Any power can be assigned to any slot on any other power so finding the perfect combination will require some thought and the possibilities are just about endless. The only limit on what you can do is that each power takes up a certain number of points and once that hits maximum nothing else can be equipped.While you are getting used to the combat you’ll be experiencing some absolutely beautiful visuals. The Neo Noir tone of the game is offset by stunning, neon tinged environments full of small details and snippets of information about the world you’re exploring. It reminded us of an isometric Deus Ex or the SNES version of Shadowrun if the rundown world had been replaced with some kind of semi-utopian society. There are also a few pretty big nods to Final fantasy VII in there as well. It’s gorgeous and the musical score and sound effects also help to build a picture of a once perfect, now lonely world where something seems to have gone wrong very quickly.Overall, Transistor is a triumph of both style and design. It takes some getting used to and you’ll need a PC running comfortably above the minimum specs to get a smooth experience but Super Giant Games have tried something a little different here and it works. There’s the odd pacing issue and players will need to spend some time getting used to how the combat works but it’s a rich and rewarding experience and something that you’ll likely return to long in the future.Overall 9/10

Posted: December 28, 2014
OverviewTransistor is, the best way I can put it, an isometric, linear brawler with a heavy emphasis on story. It's much in the vein of Bastion, and, considering that the same company made Bastion, this is easy to see. One can skip this entire review by just realizing that if you enjoyed Bastion you would enjoy this; the narrator from Bastion even voices the Transistor.In the story, you play as Red, a well-known singer in the city of Cloudbank. You use a weapon, aptly named the Transistor, as the method of combat. The city is being overrun by a strange, robotic-seeming organism called the Process that overtake whatever they touch. In search of answers, the now-mute Red goes back into the city to search for answers (sound familiar?).The game is fought in real-time but also utilizes a unique combat system called Turn(). Essentially, time freezes and you have an opportunity to plan your moves. Every action you take reduces your opportunity to do additional attacks in Turn(), and when you execute it, you cannot attack (except if certain moves are upgraded) while it recharges.Around Cloudbank are two things: access stations and terminals. Terminals are optional and for additional insight into story, and access stations can be used to upgrade the Transistor and modify it. You have a set amount of "memory", and each different move takes up a certain amount. You can upgrade moves using other moves to give it different abilities, like area-of-affect or a temporary switch-sides mechanic. Finally, you can have passive effects. You start with 16 memory and can increase it as time goes on.But this review is getting lengthy, so I'll just cut it down a bit.ProsSimilar to Bastion, which is one of my favorite games of all timeSatisfying combatCaptivating storyEngrossing world that feels realConsCombat is limited by memoryGame is very short; only took four hours to finish on my first sitting (this is somewhat put off by the fact that I did no challenges)Gameplay does not match up to the standard that Bastion set (Transistor is considered Bastion's spiritual successor)No weapon variety; only the Transistor is usedUI can be hard to figure outEnemy mechanics must be learned, as they are not explained wellInconsistent difficulty; hard in some places, easy in othersDisappointing ending; though sentimental, it was lacking and felt rushedA bit too similar to Bastion; generic-named mute protagonist, same narrator, same style, and though it imitates Bastion it doesn't do so very wellSomewhat confusing story; in order to even understand it, I had to look up an external guideFinal VerdictTransistor is an okay game. Not as good as Bastion, but a good game. However, at $20, it simply isn't worth the price. If you want to buy Transistor, wait until it's on sale.I rate Transistor 6/10.

												The art of this game is wonderful. (Characters. Areas. Songs. Story.) I will not elaborate further. I am sure others have.I do have a terminology quibble: a transistor is a switch controlled by voltage. Yes, it is the basic unit of a digital processor. No, you can't stab people with it, much less stash their soul in it.Nor, taken literally, should you be able to proc stun / charm / slow / vuln / knocked-into-air on them. Gameplay-wise, these are your basic tools. By artfully arranging them - some being cheaper than others, some affecting more enemies at once, some merely being available at the time - into useful combos, a pleasing variety arises.Although the variety of (largely useful) abilities is remarkable, their tradeoffs won't particularly matter (due to some powerful, spammable late-game abilities) unless you up the difficulty. The system for doing so is remarkably flexible - rules of combat can be turned to the enemy's favor, or you can step outside the campaign (which you should be replaying at this point anyways) to pit a semi-fixed loadout against (yet )a(nother) set configuration of enemies.Cloaking enemies (temporarily untargetable) are annoying for how they drag out fights, later on. Others, that boot you out of turn-planning, violate the premise of the game - the few encounters they participate in become mere button-spamming, converting tension to panic. This is the worst quibble I have with the game. (Except maybe for the name of its titular artifact.)In summary: A fascinating post-mortem of a city that deserved to live. (Deserves, even. I'm imagining an art deco / cyberpunk life simulator. It would be a lot of work.) Coupled with the important, RPG-y business of blowing things up in increasingly efficient, then increasingly roundabout ways.

												I don't review many games, but Transistor, much like SuperGiant's previous title, Bastion, exceeded my expectations on all fronts.This game is a tremendously soulful piece of work, and from the very start to the very end, is first and foremost a work of art. Like bastion, difficulty is born of modifiers you can apply to enemies, which give you bonuses for being brave.+Storyline. 												Interesting story/setting.  Combat plays more like a puzzle, with the puzzle being as hard as you decide to make it using optional settings (limiters) you gain through the game.  Single playthrough took me 8 hours, but you get the option for a NG+ that also changes the dialogue you experience the second time through; which gives another perspective on the narrative.  As expected from Supergiant, the art and soundtrack are excellent.  The game at times can feel like walking through the work of Gustav Klimt.  The soundtrack is a largely ambient set of aucoutic guitars and subtle electronic puncutated by vocal hums.  The game also features a couple full tracks with lovely lyrics.The negatives for me were related to the amount of menu activity.  Pieces of backstory and character information are hidden in skills you use, and using the skills in different ways unlocks more of that information.  In order to change how your skills are arranged (to use them differently), you have to visit a menu and shuffle things around between most combat sequences.  It's not a big deal, but slows down the feel of progression and the pace of your play.  It feels tedius.  Granted, you could skip the unlocking of this information and stick to a skill arrangement your comfortable with.  Additionally, some skill arrangements work better for some fights than others, and you don't have any way to predict what the next fight will be, so you usually have to fail the combat sequence to go readjust for the fight.When you're out of the menu's and fighting, you do appreciate the maleability of the skills.  Using any single skill as either an active, augmenting, or passive ability and over a dozen skills, you can create what feels like an endlessly diverse series of offensive arrangments.  Really cool.Overall, a very positive experience.  Definitely worth the $19.99 price tag on release.

Posted: May 26, 2014
												Transistor is a big and yet a small step from Bastion.There are certain things, which remain similar to it, but for the most part it's completely different.The themed music and fitting art style  is definitely the most similar to Bastion as they were done by the same people.So are the Function Upgradesystem in Transistor and the Item Upgradesystem in Bastion very similar, as both offer a lot of possibilities.There are also modifications to yourself or the enemies in Transistor, very similar to the Gods.But this is also where the similarities in those two games end, which is what most people don't see.Bastion is a Hack and Slash game, there much easier to jump in.Transistor is a "semi turn-based" RPG and I am putting it into qoutations for the simple reason, that Transistor needs to be played as a turn-based game AND a realtime game and even though it tries this very weird idea for gameplay, it works beautifully, once you fully grasped the idea of what you need to do.Transistor is not a game which will guide you at your hand. It very much wants you to learn almost everything on your own. It only tells you how to fight, how to use Turn(), how to upgrade and how to use limiters. So how a Upgrade actually affects a Function is for you to find out yourself.For example, once you use a Function during Turn(), it won't be active during the realtime section unless you have a certain upgrade on it, aside from a few certain functions. If you don't have any active Functions for the recharge phase of Turn(), you're not going to be able to do much and have to run away. If you only have active functions during your recharge phase, you can fight more, but you won't do a lot of damage. The goal is finding the sweet spot between those two, which the game itself provides more than enough practice for in the challenges.The overall story of the game is confusing, if you don't go and actively search for every little bit of extra information or fully unlock all bios, but if you do, you'll see how it all fits together. It's sadly only 5 hours long, if you do all that with a few limiters on and you won't get a full gameover either, at least I didn't experience one. Though I myself aren't to sure wether what I saw at the end of the game actually is the ending of the game, since it wants you to do a second playthrough.So to sum it up:Music: 5/5Art: 4/5, because pure white screens are annoying.Gameplay: 4/5, because it requires a lot of getting used to and experimention with abilities.Story: 3.5/5, because it makes sense, but only when you spend to time to unlock almost everything.Bastion vs Transistor: It's not comparable, since they are already gernes wise completely different games. So, people, please stop comparing these games. They, of course, do not play the same.

												Transistor is an audio-visual masterpiece. Even if were to lack the the intriguing gameplay and narrative, I would still have loved this game sheerly for its look-and-feel. The art is just so good; I have never taken so many screenshots! The gameplay is fittingly unique: You obtain Functions, which can behave as an active skill, as an upgrade to another skill, or as a passive upgrade. Each Function is derived from a character in the narrative, and to learn all there is to learn about that person, you need to use the Function in all three ways. Posted: November 3, 2014
												The spiritual successor to Bastion, Transistor completely lives up to its predecessor. Being essentially, 'Sci-fi Bastion', Transistor retains the Action-RPG elements and the narrative storytelling. However, it does change it up, the narrator no longer being an omnipotent recollection of events, but rather an on-the-spot narration full of cheeky one-liners and references to the game's lore.You play as Red, a singer who has had her voice taken away, who wields a sword called the transistor. The transistor is essentially your all-knowing companion and weapon for the duration of the game. It houses 'traces' of other people which it then uses to generate 'functions', your attacks. With four slots for active functions, and each one having a base 'upgrade' slot of one, as well as general passive slots, the loadout customization is fairly extensive, and can lead to some fun, and very gimmicky builds, but ultimately gives you the freedom to build to your playstyle. Placing the functions and using them in different slots also reveals exposition and background regarding the original people that make up the function, inspiring the player to expermient and explore their options.The gameplay at first appears similar to Bastion's, an Isometric Action-RPG. However, they introduced a new concept that distinctly sets it apart. You can use a function called 'Turn()', where you go into a planning mode, and you can move around and plan a certain number of attacks, and then execute it, watching Red go into a frenzy and perform all of her planned tasks. This comes with its own risk/reward, as in doing so, it leaves you vulnerable and unable to attack for some time. You're given three extra chances until death, where each time your health runs out, a function is 'overloaded' and unavailable to be used for some time. This came as more of a drawback, as typically some highly valuable function was lost and I ended up just loading a previous save anyways. Either way, I found the combat to be intuitive and fun to experience, yet towards the end when I had my ideal build, easy and non-chalant.It's a game that can't help but be compared to Bastion, being almost so alike it in every way. Yet at the same time, it remains distant and evolved. Bastion pulled me along with its narration and its storyline, while Transistor had me exploring to pick up exposition and look for fights. Supergiant Games learned from Bastion, and they made a far superior game to a game that was already outstanding. What Bastion lacked, Transistor has.

												If ever you come across that common question of whether video games truly belong in the world of high art, along with the likes of time-immune paintings, masterpiece films and all-time hit singles, you only need to answer it with Transistor.To say that Transistor is a work of art is no exaggeration. The beautifully painted art style reminiscent of Supergiant Games' brilliant favourite, Bastion, go hand in hand with the lovely soundtrack by Darren Korb. Ashley Barrett lends her vocals to most of the soundtrack as the protagonist, Red's, singing voice while the gravelly voiced Logan Cunningham returns as Red's companion, a man stuck in a sword. Their story is one of hardship, as they fight a system off in the hopes of getting what was stolen from them back. This good story backs its visuals and audio to make it an attractive package.The drawback that most see in dedicating a game as art is the common mistake of letting the gameplay slide into abandon. Thankfully, Supergiant Games made sure that the game's mechanics is deep and enjoyful. The combat system is incredibly customizable and allows for versility. I was eager to try out as many combinations as possible to find one that suited my playstyle and I eventually found my favourite life-stealing spamming long shot laser that exploded upon contact. There is an alright amount of enemy variety, especially since enemies gain abilities as you progress through the story.In short, Transistor is not only brilliant to look at or listen to, its fun to play and has a story worth following. Sounds like the perfect package, right? Now, some have complained that the game is really short and not worth the full retail price. My first playthrough lasted 9 hours, since I took my time to explore both the wonderful science fiction world and the expansive combat options. One should know that the game comes with a New Game + option, known as Recursion where you retain your levels and combat options as you play through the story again. In this mode, the enemies are leveled according to yours to make this second playthrough a tough one. While this NG+ option is there to add to the game's worth, not many would want to play through a second round.I've been playing this for 15 hours so far and am halfway through my second playthrough, loving it all the same the second time. To me, this is a work of art, one I'll be recommending to many.

												Another excellent title by Supergiant Games. Ironically, this game is about as far from "supergiant" as you can get in size; if anyhing, it's a small but very flavorful morsel. The artwork and soundtrack are again, top-notch stuff, and make the experience enjoyable enough that some will find the game is carried well enough by those items alone. Transistor is again another isometric action platformer, following the design of Bastion. This time around, however, the weapons you collect can also be equipped as a passive self buff, or as an augment for another weapon. This effectively streamlines Bastion's way of doing things. I particularly enjoy the pseudocode trappings of it all, as that happens to be a part of my career (please take note, however, this is NOT a game in which you do anything remotely near actual coding; it is a game merely with coding references). Actual combat is particularly interesting for two reasons. The fist is you can effectively pause time, then queue up a string of movement and attacks, which will then be executed rapdily after exiting the "bullet time." This, however, is a gable, as you're unable to do naught but move while you wait for your action bar to recharge (using on ability you earn early on as an augment will allow you to use any one ability of your choosing even when your action bar is recharging, though). The other stand-out point in combat is that, instead of dying, what would initially be a game over will actually temporarily remove one of your four abilities from your weapon until you visit two different "access points" after combat has ended. This is a vaguely Dark Souls like feature, just instead of losing your xp, you lose a weapon you earn back after visiting two bonfires. While this does add challenge, it's more of a frustration than an unforgiving mechanic that simply punishes your own mistakes as a player.Still, I found it enjoyable, and it's short enough that you can quickly suck it up in an afternoon. As with Bastion, those who replay and perform every optional area will get the most out of the game, but it is by no means less complete is you simply play through once and enjoy. Excellent buy in my opinion.

Posted: January 31
												If you played Bastion, then you should know what you're in for and, as such, can expect the same experience and be happy that you'll get an arguably better one from Transistor. If you haven't played Bastion, then continue reading.Transistor is right up there with Bastion in "best games I've ever played" for many of the same reasons as well; I'll start by discussing the gameplay itself. I played through the game using an Xbox360 Afterglow controller, and the controls are very intuitive and remappable in the options menu. Of course, the game can be played without a controller. In terms of difficulty, it's that comfortable difficulty that isn't easy but isn't frustratingly impossible; it's sometimes challenging, but it's nothing an average player shouldn't be able to handle. There are unlockable and completely optional "limiters" that make the game harder and give greater rewards from battle as a result. As you progress through the game, you'll unlock several different abilities that can be equipped in various ways, allowing you to find out for yourself which abilities and combat styles you personally prefer; there's no punishment for not using a certain ability, and (outside of the challenge rooms) you have complete freedom as to how you wish to tackle the many battles in the game.If I were to attempt to describe the combat mechanics, it'd be a turn-based real-time hybrid; you can attack in real-time (which is rather difficult, as most attacks have short start-up and ending cooldown animations), or you could take advantage of the Turn() function, which is the game's core combat mechanic. By activating Turn(), you essentially freeze time and are able to move and perform actions; when time is frozen, you don't actually perform the actions until time is unfrozen, in which you then proceed to wreak havoc on the enemies. However, after you use this, there's a set cooldown period where you cannot use any actions except for running around and evading enemy attacks until you can use Turn() again. It takes a little bit of getting used to and the game provides helpful tips at the top of the screen, as well as the first battle.As for the non-gameplay aspects, the pacing of the story in tandem with the narrative serves to keep the game entertaining and flowing smoothly. The plot develops the more you play, and you can unlock more information about character backstories by using different abilities in combat. The soundtrack is dynamic as it changes depending on the stage of battle. The entire game can be played in one long sitting (4~6 hours), but it auto-saves at each in-game terminal or whenever you enter a new area, so it's fine to play in short intervals if you don't have the time.For the record, I shouldn't even be able to run this game, as I don't meet the minimum requirements; however, turning down the resolution and a few other settings, I was able to play the game with an acceptable framerate with little to no issues. Of course, doing such things isn't good for my processor (pun intended).

Posted: January 22, 2015
												Reviewing this game without spoiling too much is difficult. I suppose that already spoils some things about the game, namely the fact that the overall "feeling" is always changing. There is no status quo. No settling into things. Enemies get harder with time, everything keeps changing, and it all works within the game's atmosphere.Many keep mentioning that "if you liked Bastion, you'll like this game". Now, that is true, but don't go thinking that this is just "sci-fi Bastion". Yes you once again find yourself as a nameless protagonist in an isometric world that's suffering through a highly unusual catastrophe. Logan Cunningham returns as the narrator with a voice so enjoyable you could listen to it read the phonebook. And of course, the soundtrack is amazing yet again and you should buy it.But what's different from Bastion? Well its no longer a hack-n-slash, I'm honestly not sure what to call its combat system aside from an odd mix of turn based strategy and real time strategy. The new combat system also forces you to constantly improve. Its a rare time when you feel like you have things totally under control, there is always a feeling of needing to improve, of needing to improve your own skills to keep up with the evolving enemies. I don't mean this as a feeling of being constantly overwhelmed, but more a feeling of always being just on the edge. The RPG elements are also greater, as opposed to Bastion's "pick two weapons and a drink for your loadout", there is now a large amount of variance to what you walk into battle with.Supergiant games as also improved on storytelling, at least in regards to including more speaking characters, and you will feel things about all of them. Be it hatred or sorrow or whatever else, the writing is very well done. Without spoiling anything, I think I liked Bastion more based on tone. I still greatly enjoyed Transistor and I highly reccommend you buy it and buy the soundtrack too.

												Another good game from Bastion creators Supergiant. Not without flaws though, and not up to the high bar the group set previously with Bastion. Combat is weighted too heavily on use of Turn() movements, and it is straight up impossible to beat the game in only real time combat, unlike what Supergiant said during events like PAX. The game is far more linear than it should be, with almost no splitting off. Additionally, you are given a lot of customization with how you use your skills, but it will always boil down to what does the most burst damage at the time, since you can only effectively fight in Turn(). As such, it has very little replayability, since there is not going to be any variance in order of area completion or how you play the game, unlike Bastion. Lastly, enemies to far, far too much damage, the other reason open combat outside of Turn() isn't feasible. After the halfway point of game, most enemies will take well over half your HP in one attack or combo, and the AI is exceptionally aggressive and tracks movement during thier shots.Despite all this negatively, the game is still good. Art style is great, story is unusual but interesting, music is solid (though personally find it inferior to Bastion's western styling) and gameplay is mostly enjoyable. It may not be exceptional, but it's still above the average of most AAA releases these days.

												On its own, Transistor is a solid game with a great atmosphere and world, a very complicated and interesting story, and a very unique combat system. The game features narration by Logan Cunningham, who plays a voice trapped in the Transistor, leading to a lot of real-time commentary on your actions. It's odd but the terms 'action' and 'turn based' simultaneously need to be used to describe the game. The music as well is really good, and is a prominent element to the game.This is SuperGiant's second game, their first being Bastion (a must-play, btw). For those who HAVE played Bastion, it'll feel relatively familiar in many respects (such as how the story progresses, Jen Zee's artstyle, etc.), but still unique. Comparatively, both games featured Cunningham as a narrator, though IMO it worked a bit better for Bastion as he was more able to tell a story, almost omnipotent, rather than act as a lone character. This is probably part of why the story is a bit confusing for Transistor.While Bastion's strong point was its narration, where Transistor really excels is its combat system. As I've said, the combat system is very unique. It's a little hard to understand at first but it is incredibly deep and challenging, with multiple setups, perks, and moves that are all balanced very well. The only weak part is the interface used to synergize the skills: it's just as deep and complex as the fighting itself. A slightly clearer interface would greatly help, but you can also overcome this by just gradually memorizing the functions of the skills for when they're applied.Unfortunately a lot of the additional story elements are in the form of text-based profiles from traces and skills you've acquired, and while it expands the world, setting the time aside to read through the logs for each trace you acquire kinda feels tedious. That said, there's enough explained in the main storyline to understand the world as much as you need to (if you're paying attention), so the logs are more just for additional sustenance. The game also lacks some kind of central world hub: the one they have available is only available at certain times in the middle of missions, rather than a place you return to after each mission. There are some challenge modes available for additional content, and they're worth doing, though I personally am hoping SuperGiant will add in more challenge modes in the future.The main storyline isn't too long, will take about 6-8 hours to beat, but it's very rich and fulfilling, and leaves a New Game+ option to experience more of the combat, with a few subtle changes to the story. Overall a worthy second title out of SuperGiant Games.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												Transistor is the second game from Supergiant Games, the creators of the critically acclaimed Bastion. It is an Action-RPG set in a futuristic sci-fi world full of dangers and mysteries. Transistor features a gorgeous hand-drawn art-style, a brilliant soundtrack and great voice-over as well as a deeply satisfying combat system. You play as Red who has been rendered mute at the beginning of the game and found herself in the possession of a mysteries sword that talks to her during the course of the game. While you uncover the secrets behind the sword and the mysteries of Cloudwalk City, you battle tons of enemies in a mixture of real-time and turn-based combat. During a combat situation you can enter a turn-based mode which enables you to give Red specific commands which she will subsequently execute upon pushing the “activate” button. This will give you the upper hand in most situations as each individual enemy type requires its own strategy. However, after executing these commands, Red will remain vulnerable for a couple seconds and if she loses her health points during this period, she will lose one of her four abilities and continue the fight with less abilities and a higher difficulty until the next checkpoint. Therefore, you have to choose wisely how to tackle each encounter. The game features an extensive upgrade system with active and passive abilities which you can combine at will in order to match you preferable play style. Furthermore, you can apply specific limiters at any time which will make the game on the one hand more difficult, but on the other hand will give you a greater experience reward. There is not much negative to be said about the game, however, some might criticize the fact that there is no equipment in the game at all. Furthermore, the story can be a bit confusing at times and while each enemy requires a specific approach, there are not that many different enemy types. However, these are tiny issues which should not keep you from playing and enjoying this great game. Thumbs up! 9/10

Posted: July 15, 2016
												TL;DR: Everything is either excellent or above average. Get it.Ok, so here's the review. I love this game, and it's one of my favorites. I'm going to do a run down of each part of the game.POSSIBLY LIGHT SPOILERS WARNINGOverview:Like Supergiant's last game, Bastion, Transistor is an isometric hack-and slasher with a good story and narrator. Story can be a little bit pretentious, but the combat provides a solid core and everything else is either excellent or good enough that I can reccomend this.Combat:This is what you'll be doing most of the time. While it starts off relativley simple, it gains depth as you aquire more Functions (your skills) from corpses you find. The main "gimmick" (but it's not really a gimmick) is being able to freeze time and plan what moves you'll use. You can freeze time, jump behind an enemy, and get a backstab with a melee ability. The combat is a bit complex, but you'll get the hang of it. You (eventually) get four active Function slots, each which can be buffed with two more Functions, and on top of that you can have 2 (or possibly 4 but that's hard to do) passive Functions. The only way to get story documents about corpses which gave you functions is to use the functions as an active, equiping another skill with it, and using it as a passive. This encourages trying new things with the combat. There are also things called Limiters, which you unlock over time. Equiping one makes the game harder, and tells you about the enemy it corresponds with. Combat: 8.5/10Story:The story is really good if you can figure out what's going on. The characters are mostly given depth through their Functions, because the only characters that talk are three of the villains and your sword. Red, the main character, is a singer who lost her voice because of the villains, which is all I can say without spoiling anything. The sword, getting to talk the most, is the most developed character, but Red is still the favorite of most fans. The story is great, but very confusing without reading some of the community's threads. It regards the cyberpunk city of Cloudbank, where the citizens democratically control what the sky looks like, what the weather is, and what buildings are constructed. (Can't say how without spoilers.) But patterns develop, and the system designed to bring novelty results in nothing changing. This leads to a terrorist orginization of Cloudbank's administrators killing off artists and the people who change the city, and eventually they release an evil called the Process on Cloudbank. The ending of the story is a gut-punch moment. Story: 8/10Aesthetic: While the art is great, it's nothing compared tO THE MUSIC IT'S AMAZING. (There are people who bought this game for the soundtrack and still haven't played it.) Aesthetic: 10/10So if you're looking for a short, replayable story based (slightly pretentious) hack and slasher with the greatest soundtrack of any game ever (seriously), Transistor is the game for you.Overall: 8.83
