Posted: January 19, 2015
												4/4 thumbs upTransistor is the second game from SuperGiant Games, the makers of Bastion, and it shares much in common with their first game.  First, the visuals are quite stunning and appealing.  Second, the narration is excellent.  Third, the protagonist is mute.  Fourth, the story is always compelling you forward.  Last, the story is, sadly, on the short side (around 6 hours if you skip the optional trials), but it's still an excellent story; I'd much rather an amazing, compelling short game than a longer game that loses its direction, or my interest, along the way.  In addition to all of that, the game includes an excellent combat system and the voice acting overall is very well-done, and kudos to SuperGiant Games for doing what much larger studios fail at accomplishing - NPCs that drive the plot forward while talking just the right amount in well-acted voices.The story puts you in the role of Red, a singer who has lost her voice and wields The Transistor, a talking circuit sword.  Much like Bastion, its predecessor, you travel around the world battling bad guys while trying to figure out what happened and how to stop it.While fighting The Process, you get the pleasure of enjoying the battle system, which is quite well-done.First, you may have up to four abilities hotkeyed to your active ability bar.  Each ability has one power-up slot, which can be used to make the ability more powerful in various ways depending on which power-up ability you choose.  As you level up, you unlock more abilities, more power-up slots, and more passive slots.  You can then take all of the abilities you have at your disposal and mix and match them in a myriad of ways to make a style that is both fun for you and powerful enough to get the job done.  Your choices are only limited by the abilities you choose to unlock and how much memory you have available (which can also be increased as you level).Second, during combat you have the option of real-time or strategic combat.  You can run around the screen using your abilities live as they come off cooldown if that's your thing, or if the combat is especially easy, or you can choose to enter strategic combat and plan out an effective attack sequence and aim your abilities in the most advantageous ways.  However, the strategic combat option has a cooldown every time you use it, during which many of your abilities will be unavailable, so in between strategic rounds you'll need to become adept at evasion.Last, if you find things too easy, you will unlock limiters as you level.  You can activate these limiters to make combat more difficult, and also to earn more XP from each battle.If you enjoy RPGs, action-adventure, mystery, and/or strategic combat, then you have a reason to play this game, because it delivers all four in a well-balanced mix.

By artfully arranging them - some being cheaper than others, some affecting more enemies at once, some merely being available at the time - into useful combos, a pleasing variety arises.Although the variety of (largely useful) abilities is remarkable, their tradeoffs won't particularly matter (due to some powerful, spammable late-game abilities) unless you up the difficulty. The system for doing so is remarkably flexible - rules of combat can be turned to the enemy's favor, or you can step outside the campaign (which you should be replaying at this point anyways) to pit a semi-fixed loadout against (yet )a(nother) set configuration of enemies.Cloaking enemies (temporarily untargetable) are annoying for how they drag out fights, later on. Others, that boot you out of turn-planning, violate the premise of the game - the few encounters they participate in become mere button-spamming, converting tension to panic. This is the worst quibble I have with the game. (Except maybe for the name of its titular artifact.)In summary: A fascinating post-mortem of a city that deserved to live. (Deserves, even. I'm imagining an art deco / cyberpunk life simulator. It would be a lot of work.) Coupled with the important, RPG-y business of blowing things up in increasingly efficient, then increasingly roundabout ways.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												I don't review many games, but Transistor, much like SuperGiant's previous title, Bastion, exceeded my expectations on all fronts.This game is a tremendously soulful piece of work, and from the very start to the very end, is first and foremost a work of art. The music, narration, artistic style and presentation flow together in a way that I would probably say outclasses almost any other game i've played. Anyone with a quibble of curiousity and a penchant for great games, or even works of art, should immediately purchase Transistor (AND Bastion) and enjoy the ride.To touch on the gameplay itself, the combat is inventive and blends several previously done elements (pseudo-turn based combat, action queues, tactical-execution-based combat) into a pretty seamless and enjoyable experience. It is two parts arcade, one part strategic pause-and-think game. It remains fresh and has a lot of room for player creativity due to the openly configurable nature of abilities acquired throughout the game.What follows are some brief pros/cons:Pros:+Incredible Art. From music to artwork, this entire game is a masterpiece.+Gameplay. The combat remains fresh, enjoyable, and creative all the way through.+Difficulty.  Like bastion, difficulty is born of modifiers you can apply to enemies, which give you bonuses for being brave.+Storyline.  Again, this is a work of art and the storyline is rich, heartfelt, and incredibly immersive.+Soundtrack.  Incredible, as usual.Cons:-Length.   The game itself isn't that long, although there are excuses to re-play the game with new conditions and toy around with the combat some more.That's really all I can see anyone really griping about with this game.In total, I'd give Transistor a 9.5/10, as one of the most absolutely awesome pieces of work i've seen in terms of gaming. It isn't a triple-A 40 hour experience... but it's an incredibly rich, artistic romp through an engaging and incredibly envisioned city of Cloudbank.9.5/10-Colt

Posted: May 31, 2014
												Interesting story/setting.  Combat plays more like a puzzle, with the puzzle being as hard as you decide to make it using optional settings (limiters) you gain through the game.  Single playthrough took me 8 hours, but you get the option for a NG+ that also changes the dialogue you experience the second time through; which gives another perspective on the narrative.  As expected from Supergiant, the art and soundtrack are excellent.  The game at times can feel like walking through the work of Gustav Klimt.  The soundtrack is a largely ambient set of aucoutic guitars and subtle electronic puncutated by vocal hums.  The game also features a couple full tracks with lovely lyrics.The negatives for me were related to the amount of menu activity.  Pieces of backstory and character information are hidden in skills you use, and using the skills in different ways unlocks more of that information.  In order to change how your skills are arranged (to use them differently), you have to visit a menu and shuffle things around between most combat sequences.  It's not a big deal, but slows down the feel of progression and the pace of your play.  It feels tedius.  Granted, you could skip the unlocking of this information and stick to a skill arrangement your comfortable with.  Additionally, some skill arrangements work better for some fights than others, and you don't have any way to predict what the next fight will be, so you usually have to fail the combat sequence to go readjust for the fight.When you're out of the menu's and fighting, you do appreciate the maleability of the skills.  Using any single skill as either an active, augmenting, or passive ability and over a dozen skills, you can create what feels like an endlessly diverse series of offensive arrangments.  Really cool.Overall, a very positive experience.  Definitely worth the $19.99 price tag on release.

Posted: August 25, 2016
												Transistor follows the story of a mute young woman, Red, in her journey of discovery. Taking place shortly after losing her voice, she discovers a key like object known as the Transistor, which narrates and communicates with Red in an accustomed manor. Together, they explore a world which has been over-run with digital viruses, which plagues the worlds existence itself.From start up, I was astonished by the beautiful design. color and soundtrack this feature displays, it all fits splendidly together in a blend that can only impress. The game play is phenomenal, sporting a combination of classic mechanic systems, in a mix that I can only describe as Final Fantasy meets Zelda. The narration is a pleasure to listen too and pays homage to their previous game, Bastion, which was equally fantastic.The game length tends to be on the shorter side, supplying approximately 8 hours of overall game time. Don't be fooled though, once you've seen the ending you're given the option the restart the journey, allowing you to keep all the items and progression from your current file, which lends to some interesting replay ability.Overall, the game is a breathtaking experience, every aspect of the game works well together in a new and original concept. Supergiant Games, creators of Transistor and Bastion, deserve a congratulations for creating a masterpiece, this game will will certainly stand the test of time as one of the greatest games to hit the market. I rate Transistor a 9/10.

The way of combining functions (skills) allows for many different effective play styles without forcing the player into making permanent choices. It doesn't make much sense to compare Transistor and Bastion, since their concepts are quite different. I personally liked Transistor better, since it's art style and gameplay goes even further away from a usual fantasy setting.

												Jesus Christ, I don't have words enough to describe how perfect this game is.First off: looks. 10/10The minute I looked at this game, I knew I'd want to play it. Attractive, attention-drawing female lead character who turned out to be amazingly pretty and humble. Then, the art. Oh my God. Flawless, perfect, awesome. Everything drawn to its smallest detail, and all very thought-through for the whole gaming experience. The mixture of lights in-combat makes you want to play it nonstop.Gameplay: 10/10At first, I was a little concerned about it being a 2D game (not because 2D games are bad, but because I tend not to like them). Actually, I saw it be launched back in 2014, but was not caught in the moment to buy it. Then, I decided to give it a shot now. Best idea so far. I couldn't find a single bug ingame, not to mention how fluid the animations are. But the best part: ingame sound experience. Sweet Lord. Best game I've ever played, by far. Games are not about graphics or long stories, but how much they can make you dive into the atmosphere and really feel you're the character. And boy, does this game excel at this. I truly felt I was a red-haired woman with a talking technologic-sword in a city where everything'd been consumed by programs. One point I really liked was the fact that whenever she hums, it goes according to whatever song is currently playing in the background. It really shows the commitment the team had in doing this game, and planning it so the story would feel real. I cared for Red and her sword, I did. I felt like a child rooting for them when the sword got red and it seemed it'd be corrupted away from her. Very immersive.Art/Music/Story: 9.9/10Exerything perfect. You can't find one single image that says 'look how poorly drawn I was'. None. Very hard work applied into creating this world and the story. Everything makes sense, there aren't loose ends. All songs were very good, highlight on "In Circles", which is a favorite and definetly could be a pop singer' single. Red's voice is something unique, I don't know wheter because the effects or what, which also don't mind. The fact is you get goosebumps and shivers everything she hums to a song. The reason my grade isn't 10 is the ending, which I'd hoped would be the other way around. But, I must not spread spoilers. All in All: 10/10I don't recommend it. I command people to play it. :)

												Roblins Review:Transistor is a surreal and beautiful Sci-fi, Cyberpunk game with a great story, and has a soundtrack that might make your ears try to jump off your head and try to get into the game.~ The Combat is innovative in the fact that you can choose to use a turn based approach or take a direct approach (Although turns are a safer and more efficient way through the game). The game has a way of making you feel very powerful without it being too easy, and if it is too easy you can use Limiters to make the game even harder.~The Story is good, but you're left to figure out most of it yourself, which is something i like, but not everyone will agree on that. You play as a popular singer named Red, and you've just barely escaped death at the hands of the Camerata. A secret-ish Society in cloudbank (the city the game takes place in.) I don't want to say too much about the story. If you want to get every last detail on the characters you can use your combat functions in different ways to gain access to personal files. I liked this feature because it pushes you to try different play styles.~The Soundtrack is Visceral and well done. Most of the songs relating to the story so there is a deep sense of drive and emotion in every note. If you're into techno or anything of that sort you should love it.~The Art in this game is self explanatory. It's just amazing. The world of Cloudbank feels deep like it was once a bustling city full of people. Plus it has the best Flat bread Delivery around. It has a very Cyber-punk feel to it. It's just great.Overall I'd say this is the best game I've played in 2014. It has decent replayability as well. Only thing i have to complain about is that it was too short, and the only reason i say that is because i wanted more!  I highly recommend it. Amazing 9/10.

Posted: July 4, 2014
												I picked up this little jewel during the Summer Sale and I'd recommend it a thousand times if I could. I'll try and keep the review short and sweet and hopefully spoiler-free, though some gameplay mechanics may be explained.You begin your journey in the city of Cloudbank as the mute songstress, Red, wielding nothing but a talking sword which happens to be called the Transistor. Immediately, your companion tells you to move and you're soon running around the mysterious and towering city looking for answers to the events that have transpired, reading Function files and OVC terminals to find out what is causing the disappearance of the city and the people who had the most influence making the city into what it is.The overall design for this game is absolutely beautiful. The blend of art deco and cyberpunk makes the game vastly unique with beautiful artwork appearing during cutscenes and optional areas. There aren't many characters in the game but the interplay between Red and her talking companion makes it hard not to care about their situation and the surrounding events. Sound design also plays a huge part in becoming immersed in the game as it is very influential and relevant to the story and really reminds the player of Red's past life as a musician. Often times, I will let Red hum to the background music for minutes without realizing how long I've been doing it. Yeah, it's that good.As in traditional RPG fashion, the game involves a leveling system which unlock slots for upgrades to your basic arsenal of Functions. It also utilizes the ability to combine these Functions to upgrade your moves or give different effects depending on the slot they're in; giving the player quite a bit of options regarding how you choose to fight. Mechanics for the gameplay seem to try to expand on the typical RPG style and use a cross between real time and activating Turn() to strategically plan your next couple of moves without fear of retailiation from enemies. I personally enjoyed figuring out countless combinations to alter my playstyle, though some players may find the combat repetititve considering you will most likely use the most powerful combinations you can make and continue to use the same tactic to deal with every foe from about mid to end game. Fortunately, Limiters can keep the game from becoming too monotonous, allowing you to ramp up the difficulty at your own leisure and the Recursion playthrough will bring you back for more if you'd like 100% completion.In summary, the game can be completed in about 5-10 hours depending on your speed and while not very lengthy, you can go for a second playthrough if you want more. The combat is intelligent, though some players will be turned off by its repetition and may find certain combinations of Functions too powerful or easy and can burn through the game using only 2-3 moves. The interaction between Red and her Transistor makes for a compelling story hopefully enticing the player to find out the truth behind Cloudbank and the Process and where it leads our protagonists. The artwork and design of the game is astoundingly vivid and the soundtrack fits perfectly with the atmosphere of the game and I can't possibly stress enough how beautiful it all feels. I also highly recommend buying the soundtrack.Overall rating: 9/10

Posted: July 4, 2014
												The obvious strength in music and visuals makes it easy to treat Transistor as the gaming equivalent of a snack, but the more patience you invest into the game the greater the reward and the more engaging it becomes. It's beautiful in every way - sound, art, gameplay, plot, and the way they all mesh together to turn what could be a good game into a fantastic game.The music is tied closely to the plot and the art brings out the ethereal and ephemeral feeling of Cloudbank in an amazingly unique way, while reinforcing the overall atmosphere and excitement of the entire game. They underscore SuperGiant's (by now) trademark way of storytelling: letting the atmosphere speak for itself, with the narration more like a tour-guide than noisy friend. The battle system is a fun hybrid of action and turn based - you can play as purely one or the other, but utilizing both makes for an interesting blend of twitch and chess-like strategy. With plenty of skills, a staggering amount of ways to combine them, and variable difficulty - you can choose which limitations to use and how to power up enemies to make the perfect personal challenge - battles never feel like a grind, and are always exciting. Since "function file" plot and character information is unlocked by using skills in different ways, it encourages you to constantly change up your playstyle, try everything, and keeps things interesting. Even going through the game multiple times feels fresh since both you and enemies retain your strength upon "recursion". The battles grow with you every time through.However, to understand the game fully you need to play it through twice. If you love the game this is an easy plus, but requires investment. The depth of the plot doesn't really come out until right at the very end, and important details are in the ignorable function files. The ending might leave those expecting things to go a different way feeling unsatisfied, but I believe it fits the game perfectly, and suits the bittersweet inevitability hanging over the entire game.Overall, highly recommended. See you in the Country.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												Transistor is yet another masterpiece from SuperGiant Games. The story has players in control of Red, a widely beloved singer of the setting city, Cloudbank, where all voices are heard so to speak. When our Heroine finds herself trekking throughout the city without her voice after being attacked by a secret group that wishes to use her voice for their master plan for the city, Red must take use of the Transistor, a oddly sword that downloads the data of people in order to store them inside.Within the first fewminutes of the game, we see this in action as the swords main entity is Red's boyfriend, a figure unknown by not just the player but the also the city itself. With him guiding her along the way the game really opens up some interesting dailogue between them that range from comedic relief and worry. the Characters are all fairly written and the background data on the people you download into the sword keep you playing to find out more on why they were killed and the truth behind the Transistor.The Combat is great, and engaging; combining elements of strategy and action. You have a feature called turn which in essence allows the player to stop time, plan their next move, and then re-initiate time and watch your plan play out. THe best part about this feature is that it's mostly optional save for some bosses and puzzles. The most of the game can be played without ever activating Turn for the more hardy of players looking for a decent challenge. Not enough you say? well how about the added limiter that allow you so make the game harder in order to earn even more experience. Limiters are a great way to give that extra wager to your skills from making enemys immune to status effects to giving them more health and power to having them break your skills should you get hit with no health.Darren Knob Has outdone himself again with Transistors Soundtrack. This and Bastion are two example of just how good Game OST's are getting, and I'd recommend picking it up like I did. I could sit here all day trying to sweeten up music for you, but my moto on music is the only way I could get someone to like music is to have them hear it for themselves, and that's just what you need to do. Check some of it out on Youtube, and if you enjoy the jazzy/blues tunes of the game then you simply must purchase the soundtrack.All-in-all, Transistor is a great game for those that enjoy a great action game, with a few twist here and there, a interesting story, and great soundtrack. Overall i'd give the game a 8.5/10, and I'd reccomend it to anyone who does and doesn't hold interest in the title already. Trust me, it is a well worth buy.

Posted: July 15, 2016
												TL;DR: Everything is either excellent or above average. Get it.Ok, so here's the review. I love this game, and it's one of my favorites. I'm going to do a run down of each part of the game.POSSIBLY LIGHT SPOILERS WARNINGOverview:Like Supergiant's last game, Bastion, Transistor is an isometric hack-and slasher with a good story and narrator. Story can be a little bit pretentious, but the combat provides a solid core and everything else is either excellent or good enough that I can reccomend this.Combat:This is what you'll be doing most of the time. While it starts off relativley simple, it gains depth as you aquire more Functions (your skills) from corpses you find. The main "gimmick" (but it's not really a gimmick) is being able to freeze time and plan what moves you'll use. You can freeze time, jump behind an enemy, and get a backstab with a melee ability. The combat is a bit complex, but you'll get the hang of it. You (eventually) get four active Function slots, each which can be buffed with two more Functions, and on top of that you can have 2 (or possibly 4 but that's hard to do) passive Functions. The only way to get story documents about corpses which gave you functions is to use the functions as an active, equiping another skill with it, and using it as a passive. This encourages trying new things with the combat. There are also things called Limiters, which you unlock over time. Equiping one makes the game harder, and tells you about the enemy it corresponds with. Combat: 8.5/10Story:The story is really good if you can figure out what's going on. The characters are mostly given depth through their Functions, because the only characters that talk are three of the villains and your sword. Red, the main character, is a singer who lost her voice because of the villains, which is all I can say without spoiling anything. The sword, getting to talk the most, is the most developed character, but Red is still the favorite of most fans. The story is great, but very confusing without reading some of the community's threads. It regards the cyberpunk city of Cloudbank, where the citizens democratically control what the sky looks like, what the weather is, and what buildings are constructed. (Can't say how without spoilers.) But patterns develop, and the system designed to bring novelty results in nothing changing. This leads to a terrorist orginization of Cloudbank's administrators killing off artists and the people who change the city, and eventually they release an evil called the Process on Cloudbank. The ending of the story is a gut-punch moment. Story: 8/10Aesthetic: While the art is great, it's nothing compared tO THE MUSIC IT'S AMAZING. (There are people who bought this game for the soundtrack and still haven't played it.) Aesthetic: 10/10So if you're looking for a short, replayable story based (slightly pretentious) hack and slasher with the greatest soundtrack of any game ever (seriously), Transistor is the game for you.Overall: 8.83

Posted: May 21, 2014
												"Proper story's supposed to start at the beginning. Ain't so simple with this one."That was the first line said in Supergiant Games' debut RPG, Bastion. While the line was definitely fitting for the story of said game, I'd say that it's even more fitting for Transistor, the indie company's sophomore release. Transistor starts off with the protagonist, a famous singer named Red, standing over the silhouette of a man who had been impaled by a USB-stick sort of thing known as the Transistor. There is no information as to what lead up to this moment- the game starts here. For the next hour or two of my time in-game, I was constantly trying to imagine what exactly had happened. The game had me lost- in a good way. Transistor's story is, in some senses of the word, all over the place. But it was never too difficult to follow. I've yet to beat the game myself, but with the progress I've made, I'm definitely willing to say that it has one of the best stories out of any game I've played this year.And where there's a good story, Transistor also brings more good things. A lot of good things, really. For starters, the soundtrack is beautiful. Ashley Barrett, also known as Zia in Bastion, makes her return as the voice for Red- and the songs that she sings are better than ever. From the low humming that plays whenever you're in the Planning phase of combat, to the entirety of The Spine, Barrett is back, and better than ever.Speaking of the "Planning phase of combat," Transistor brings about a new combat system that has been done before, but never quite as well-implemented as it was in Transistor. You can play the game like it's Diablo, sure- but this is incredibly dangerous, difficult, and most of the time, uneffective. The game also features a Planning phase, in which the character is able to move freely about in a frozen world, planning their movements and attacks. Very turn-based in style. Along with this unique combat system, Transistor features countless upgrades, many difficulty mutators in the style of the Shrine from Bastion, and the ability to string attacks together for devastating results. All in all, I may be a bit biased towards Transistor, as Bastion is arguably one of the best games I've ever played, but I without a doubt recommend this game. The $20 pricetag stirred me up a bit at first, but I can guarantee that it was worth it. Transistor is definitely an unforgettable experience that I cannot recommend you to buy enough. And while you're at it, buy Bastion. You won't regret it.

Hard-crash bugs. This is a bad thing. It's not hitting everyone, and apparently it's better if you play it in Offline Mode on Steam. Posted: August 9, 2014
												Supergiant has made another innovative game with great art, and this time, with superb gameplay. Unlike their last game, Bastion, Transistor has a much more in-depth combat system that is cool to toy around with. Now for what everyone's waiting for: the story. The story of Transistor is very similar to the one that was in Bastion's. Supergiant brings back many of the things we've loved from Bastion and puts in it Transistor. The game drops you into a world that is being torn apart, and you have to try and fix it. There is a narrator in the game that serves to tell the story about how the world around you was, although he takes a more laid back seat in his role in that instead of narrating every single thing you're doing, here, he'll talk to you as a companion and friend. While the fact that the story between the two games is almost identical, the main difference between the two games is the world you're dropped in, and why the world is being destroyed.You start off in not so much as a world that Supergiant has made, but a city called Cloudbank that is part of that world. Cloudbank has a Tron kind of feel, where it is unsure whether the characters you are seeing are really alive, or just some programs living in a digital world. On the one hand, when they die, their souls or processes go into your Transistor, giving you extra powers. On the other hand, the characters are exactly the same as human characters except for that fact. The game tries really hard to demonstrate this idea that even though every character in the game is some kind of computer program, they still have all behave differently and have flaws like normal humans. Characters end up having tons of personality, except instead of forcing you to learn about them, Transistor does this more subtly by giving you the choice to read about the lore of the world or not.The storytelling in the game has also been improved from Bastion. Instead of the singlular path of find all the cores, find all the shards, then find the last core and the last shard to power up the bastion machine, Transistor's story is a lot less linear and way more subtle. As said before, much of the story lies in the background of the powers you gain, as well as the OVC stations (pretty much the newspaper) that are placed around Cloudbank. Transistor focuses mainly on telling a good story but because of that, it ends a little short. By no means is Bastion a bad story, but it was practically one big fetch quest for 70% of the game, which was good because it made the game longer, but the story was made weaker and the weakness in its gameplay was made much more obvious. If anything, I wish this game was longer but at least the story doesnt feel as forced as Bastion, forcing you to continuously retrieve things to power the bastion. Your playthrough could last anywhere from 4-5 hours on the first playthroughbut there is a new game+ mode called recursion in the game that lets you keep all your abilities and your level as you start the game over again.Other than the story, the gameplay is the most noticeable improvement in Transistor. Instead of dodge rolling and then spamming left or right click, this game relies on 4 active skills that you can add 2 passive skills to each, and 4 passive skills that buff your character. Each and every skill you have can go into any of these categories and its up to you to mix and match each skill to fit your playstle. You use these 4 actives in combat and when you are in a pinch, you can use the pause mechanic which allows you to plan your attack. With these mechanics,Transistor is a much more tactical and interesting game  since you get to carry most, if not all, of your skills into combat with you into a fight. In the end, Transistor has taken many of the things in Bastions, and improved on them. The story has been made less linear, the gameplay has been totally rehauled, and you'll fall in love with the art style, the crumbling world, and the characters all over again.

Posted: December 9, 2016
												SPECS:AMD-A6 5200 (3rd generation i3 equivalent) AMD Radeon HD8400 / R3 Series 512 MB4 gigs of RAM64-bit Windows 10What could be said for Transistor that hasn't been said before? Supergiant Games second game is a massive step forward from its previous title Bastion, and while gamers may argue over which is better; both are great. Where Transistor differs, is that Supergiant made a hybrid action RPG. Red has a "turn" function in the sense of traditional RPG battles; but by equipping Red's weapon with certain functions (they are found throughout the game) some will allow her to battle outside of her turn. Her weapon consists of four attacks that you slot functions into, these can then have up to 2 more functions attached increasing various attributes like damage or even combining skills.The tale of Transistor is one I don't want to spoil, and lasting only 6 hours even while searching every dark corner of the world, I was left pondering what would I do in the end. Some gamers may not enjoy the combat and originally I felt the same. Despite the game tutorials being pretty straightforward, once you find a basic setup for the functions you can nearly button mash your way to end.Transistors art design is brilliant, everything within the city and its characters seem inspired by the art deco / streamline era of the 1930's and Supergiant has never disappointed and I go so far as to say outdone and surpassed anyones expectation with the music in Transistor. I urge everyone that reads this to look up the soundtrack and give it listen.If Supergiant asked if there was anything I could change with Transistor, I would probably say to remove the Performance challenges. I know they are possible, but ultimately I feel that any type of challenges is unnecessary filler and the effort could have gone to adding additional areas and bosses or expanded story elements.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												Had this for a while, didn't get to finishing it until now.The game's shining feature is its artwork of course -- as usually what I feel gets Supergiant Games' awards 90% of the time.  You can delve into the game's "deep" story by Inspecting the abilities you gain at certain points of the game -- as the abilities you gain are from dead citizens of the city you're trying to save, which are absorbed into the Transistor.  This player kinda glossed over the story, because as usual I play games for the gameplay.  As I did enjoy the gameplay itself, I feel it has a few problems. The combat and core gameplay definitely has its merits, and can be quite enjoyable.  It touts the whole "player's choice gimmick" of either going for more Turn-based gameplay or real-time.   Unfortunately, the game can push you into one or the other, and it's a lot of trial-and-error to figure out which situation suits which playstyle -- and which techniques you should have equipped.  Then of course, you can be punished harshly by having to wait for your Turn meter to build back up in order to use any abilities (Jaunt discluded), getting Tech uninstalled (by getting your life drained all the way) or by dying and having to restart from the last Access (Save) point.  And pending on what you have after you've lost a certain ability in battle,  you might as well restore your save point anyway.I've found a lot of times towards the ending, and more challenging parts like some of the Tests you can do, there's really no point to do real-time combat, because the game can get very spammy, and almost every ability you have has a stop-wind-up, and cool-down animation which can really get you hurt.   And SPOILERS -- the final boss uses Turn, so pretty much forces you to do the same.Developers like Supergiant get super praised for a lot of their gameplay designs from Bastion and this very game, but I feel they give an ILLUSION of strategy and thought that a lot of players get fooled over.  This game barely has any strategy.  Yes, you have a wide variety of abilities to learn and tune to your liking, but in the end, there's really only 2 or 3 most effective set ups you'll find to use.  It's worth a playthrough, and I'll even say worth the $20. It's more fine-tuned than the cluster♥♥♥♥ that was Bastion -- though that one was fun too in certain ways.  Bastion had a lot of enemy hell spam, and this game can get to that point towards the end of the game.  7/10

												Great game with very beautiful presentation.Enjoyed it a great deal more than Bastion, since the combat in Transistor is more about planning and experimentation rather than quick reflexes.The only bummer is the campaign is quite short and the dificulty of the game is quite easy, even on Recursion mode with all the Limiters turned on. I wished the developers could have added a super hard secret hidden boss battle with 100k HP similar to the ones in JRPGs, since it is so much fun to toy around the different weapon combinations and dealing the most maximum damage output. Alas, you're stuck experimenting maximum damage on the Practice Room.However, I'd still recommend buying this game. It's a very well-crafted game from Supergiant Games, and I am very looking forward for their next project.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												I've never been moved to tears upon playing a video game until now. Despite the obvious flaws that the game has, (bugs, crashes, framerate issues) the game is carried by the weight of the story alone. While the gameplay was fantastic, it isn't the greatest video game I've ever played, but it's one of the greatest, if not the greatest, stories I've ever been told. The only thing that truly saddened me with Transistor was the mere fact that I didn't have more time to spend in Red's world. Without a doubt, I would recommened this game to anyone that cares for a story in video games. For anyone that claims that a video game can never truly be a work of art, this would be my go to game to show them.

Posted: August 1, 2014
												Transistor uses a simple, but fantastically deep combat system that is sure to indulge fans of customization and optional difficulty. Enemies are varied and interesting, each having a different optimal strategy to be defeated without feeling like a gimmick, and the tactical dimension of combat added by the Turn() system is not to be underestimated. The game-world of Transistor and atmosphere are exquisite, not the least because of the stunning visuals and bold sound track. The city of Cloudbank is beautiful and feels alive and ripe for exploration. My only complaints lie in the delivery of the game's plot line: Transistor errs a little too heavily on the side of the player filling in the blanks. While I love deducing things about a game's greater environment, the primary plot occasionally required a lot of out-of-game legwork to just feel coherent.All in all, I would certainly recommend Transistor. It's a delight to play and explore, and a very worthy successor to Bastion.

Posted: May 31, 2014
												Interesting story/setting.  Combat plays more like a puzzle, with the puzzle being as hard as you decide to make it using optional settings (limiters) you gain through the game.  Single playthrough took me 8 hours, but you get the option for a NG+ that also changes the dialogue you experience the second time through; which gives another perspective on the narrative.  As expected from Supergiant, the art and soundtrack are excellent.  The game at times can feel like walking through the work of Gustav Klimt.  The soundtrack is a largely ambient set of aucoutic guitars and subtle electronic puncutated by vocal hums.  The game also features a couple full tracks with lovely lyrics.The negatives for me were related to the amount of menu activity.  Pieces of backstory and character information are hidden in skills you use, and using the skills in different ways unlocks more of that information.  In order to change how your skills are arranged (to use them differently), you have to visit a menu and shuffle things around between most combat sequences.  It's not a big deal, but slows down the feel of progression and the pace of your play.  It feels tedius.  Granted, you could skip the unlocking of this information and stick to a skill arrangement your comfortable with.  Additionally, some skill arrangements work better for some fights than others, and you don't have any way to predict what the next fight will be, so you usually have to fail the combat sequence to go readjust for the fight.When you're out of the menu's and fighting, you do appreciate the maleability of the skills.  Using any single skill as either an active, augmenting, or passive ability and over a dozen skills, you can create what feels like an endlessly diverse series of offensive arrangments.  Really cool.Overall, a very positive experience.  Definitely worth the $19.99 price tag on release.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												I don't review many games, but Transistor, much like SuperGiant's previous title, Bastion, exceeded my expectations on all fronts.This game is a tremendously soulful piece of work, and from the very start to the very end, is first and foremost a work of art. The music, narration, artistic style and presentation flow together in a way that I would probably say outclasses almost any other game i've played. Anyone with a quibble of curiousity and a penchant for great games, or even works of art, should immediately purchase Transistor (AND Bastion) and enjoy the ride.To touch on the gameplay itself, the combat is inventive and blends several previously done elements (pseudo-turn based combat, action queues, tactical-execution-based combat) into a pretty seamless and enjoyable experience. It is two parts arcade, one part strategic pause-and-think game. It remains fresh and has a lot of room for player creativity due to the openly configurable nature of abilities acquired throughout the game.What follows are some brief pros/cons:Pros:+Incredible Art. From music to artwork, this entire game is a masterpiece.+Gameplay. The combat remains fresh, enjoyable, and creative all the way through.+Difficulty.  Like bastion, difficulty is born of modifiers you can apply to enemies, which give you bonuses for being brave.+Storyline.  Again, this is a work of art and the storyline is rich, heartfelt, and incredibly immersive.+Soundtrack.  Incredible, as usual.Cons:-Length.   The game itself isn't that long, although there are excuses to re-play the game with new conditions and toy around with the combat some more.That's really all I can see anyone really griping about with this game.In total, I'd give Transistor a 9.5/10, as one of the most absolutely awesome pieces of work i've seen in terms of gaming. It isn't a triple-A 40 hour experience... but it's an incredibly rich, artistic romp through an engaging and incredibly envisioned city of Cloudbank.9.5/10-Colt

Posted: December 3, 2016
												Honestly... I was expecting some game like a Bastion. And Transistor is like a Bastion... a very good game with interesting original story and excellent soundtrack; just press TAB in a game and haroine will start a humm : ) to the music!...and I can't forgot, this game have REALLY AWESOME fight system. Partly real-time, partly turn-based.Simply, You stop the time. Plan your moves, attacks, evasions, corruption of enemies, etc.Then You press a space and your turn is executed within a second. But... after that You have to wait for your turn again (but in the real time). It is like you combined chess, when your opponent have turn after You, but you can still move too.+ it is really good that every skill which You've found can have three functions:Main skill, support skill, passive skill = and its only up to You how you will mix themSo don't wait and try this game. It is really good!

Posted: June 10, 2014
												Absolutely brilliant. The soundtrack, story and characters(as few as there were) could have made a visual novel all on its own but Transistor tops it all off by having an amazing and permutable battle system. Not even counting the special Turn() based strategic battling, the sheer number of choices, combinations and OPTIONS you have to battle is insanely staggering.You can pick 4 actives, 2 upgrades per active, and 4 passive abilities. With a total of 16 different choices to slot into any of those. The numbers seem 'small' but doing a bit of math on this and I realize I can't properly account for all the situations and duplicate abilities you can also have later on. Not only that, but the order of the abilities even matters for some cases, amplifying or accidentally nullifying what you're trying to do.The amount of ways you can tailor your skills, number in the hundred thousands, if not the millions and that's not even including your own personal playstyle, timing and strategies. This is a game that rivals many others in sheer options of battle choices while maintaining a subtle yet engaging storyline. I can honestly say I felt this game was a true masterpiece, battle, story, art, soundtrack, replayability. God damn.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												If you're looking for a game that sets a mood, lets you escape, and has simple but challenging gameplay, you've found it.  If you're familiar with Bastion, you are likely to recognize Supergiant's atmospheric touch in this game.  This game is shorter and has a less fleshed out plot.  Like Bastion, mysteries are left to your imagination, unanswered.  However, the brevity of this game will leave you wishing there were more mysteries to boggle over.The combat is moderately strategic.  If your mood is too specific, you might be disappointed, whether you're looking for simple combat or serious strategy.  It has more of a balance between simplicity and strategy. It's fun for what it is.Replay value is mildly elevated by the New Game+ style recursion mode.   Overall, I'd recommend this game.Pros: -The music and other atmospheric elements are exceptional.  Supergiant sets a high standard for game atmosphere. -The main gameplay mechanic is fun and allows for experimentation with the various function (skill/upgrade) combos.Cons: -As stated above, the game is shorter than I'd like (needs more plot points).

Posted: November 23, 2016
												This is the only game I have ever reviewed on steam. And that's because it's this good. Back in the dark times of my piracy days I torrented this game and played through it and stopped after the end credits. And it's not like I didn't want to play again, actually it is one of the few games I ever wanted to play again, and the only one I wanted to start immediately after the first playthrough. The reason I stopped myself was that I knew right away I would buy that game and play through it at least two more times. And now, when my library is getting close to 500 and my days on the Torrent Seas are long past, it still holds true. It is my second favourite game of all time, the first place being held forever by WC III The Frozen Throne on the sole principle that I probably spent more time playing and talking about that game that I spent doing literally anything else. Transistor settled above FF VII, all three Bioshocks, entire Witcher trilogy, Planescape Torment, Dragon Age, Dark Souls and so many others exquisite games. And I can't even properly say why. The game is short, and even though the plot is easy to follow, if you want to get the full story it requires skill grinding. But the gameplay is so good, and said grinding made so much fun by the various ways you can put the skills together, that even I, being allergic to the idea of grinding ever since the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Golden Saucer (I still don't know if Omnislash was worth it...) wasn't bored even for a nanosecond. And, well, the story is so worth it, the picture of Cloudbank painted through the various character profiles fascinated me more than many worlds in other, more straightforward stories. And at the same time it is a complete experience on it's own, which, to be honest, could also be a minus. Those 12+ hours are two playthroughs, but after the first one the story was pretty much complete, only one or two character profiles to finish. There was very little to talk about with my friends. The reason this could be a minus comes from the fact that another game that forces you to look for the full story *ekhmDarkSoulsekhm* comes to mind, and that one resulted in hours of speculations. Still, this is no Dark Souls, and I can't say I feel this lack of ambiguity is a fault on games part. I was really satisfied with how the story unfolds, the resolution of that build-up towards confrontation with Camerata, and the ending. Yes, the ending was at the same time probably my favourite in all fiction I had ever come in contact with, and the reason I nominated this game for "I'm not crying..." Award. OK, I'm gonna stop myself now, before I write another two pages of a love letter to Supergiant Games for this masterpiece, I probably made myself clear. The gameplay is a surprising and surprisingly well executed mix of action and tactical RPG, the story is great, the "interactions" between two main characters are brilliant, the game is incredibly fun. Oh yeah, and the "Great Soundtrack" on those tags is definitely not just for show, but nothing I could write would do it justice. Suffice to say I've been listenin to it on the train  for most of the last two years. Damn, it's been two years... If the "hrs on record" on record is higher than 12,5 I probably replayed that again. And again in some not far future. But seriously, this game is awesome :D

Posted: December 9, 2016
												SPECS:AMD-A6 5200 (3rd generation i3 equivalent) AMD Radeon HD8400 / R3 Series 512 MB4 gigs of RAM64-bit Windows 10What could be said for Transistor that hasn't been said before? Supergiant Games second game is a massive step forward from its previous title Bastion, and while gamers may argue over which is better; both are great. Where Transistor differs, is that Supergiant made a hybrid action RPG. Red has a "turn" function in the sense of traditional RPG battles; but by equipping Red's weapon with certain functions (they are found throughout the game) some will allow her to battle outside of her turn. Her weapon consists of four attacks that you slot functions into, these can then have up to 2 more functions attached increasing various attributes like damage or even combining skills.The tale of Transistor is one I don't want to spoil, and lasting only 6 hours even while searching every dark corner of the world, I was left pondering what would I do in the end. Some gamers may not enjoy the combat and originally I felt the same. Despite the game tutorials being pretty straightforward, once you find a basic setup for the functions you can nearly button mash your way to end.Transistors art design is brilliant, everything within the city and its characters seem inspired by the art deco / streamline era of the 1930's and Supergiant has never disappointed and I go so far as to say outdone and surpassed anyones expectation with the music in Transistor. I urge everyone that reads this to look up the soundtrack and give it listen.If Supergiant asked if there was anything I could change with Transistor, I would probably say to remove the Performance challenges. I know they are possible, but ultimately I feel that any type of challenges is unnecessary filler and the effort could have gone to adding additional areas and bosses or expanded story elements.

Posted: July 4, 2014
												Another artsy game by the Supergiant Games, the makers of Bastion. The music and art are even better this time around. They are really excellent. The gameplay is pretty good and interesting with its stop, plan and excecute combat mechanics as well as the ability to mix the elements, which is encouraged by giving more backstory if you do it. Bit easy, but can be made harder by pretty dynamic difficulty levels. The storytelling is good too. It's very in media res. You are dropped in the world without as much as a start menu and left to figure out what's going on and how everything works. It's a simple enough game to pull that off. It's pretty short and fairly linear, though. Replayability value doesn't seem that great even with new game+, though I can imagine revisiting this at some point in the future.Superior to Bastion in almost every way, except maybe Logan Cunningham isn't quite as cool as the voice here as he was as the narrator in Bastion. Definitely worth getting, but I wouldn't pay the full price.

Posted: January 28
												Transistor and Bastion are probably two of the best games I've played for a long time. The amount of work the devs have placed into both of them is absolutely gigantic, creating a game that is polished from back to front. I usually have some nitpicks in every game I play, but Transistor is definitely an exception. The graphics are truly magnificent to the eye. There's detail to every little thing in every level, keeping your eyes in constant appreciation of the artwork in the game. It doesn't get boring not even in the slightest. I think if I ever did buy a soundtrack in my life, it'd be Transistor's soundtrack. The music is incredibly elegant, adding extra feeling to the visuals of the game. These two coupled with the fascinating gameplay clash together into a wonderful mix of "this game is the best thing I've ever played" kind of game. The gameplay keeps you on board the game nonstop, never getting you unattached. There's tons of upgrades you can get, lots of synergies with those upgrades, and a whole variety of attacks you can do. Voice acting, just like Bastion, is still at its best in Transistor. It doesn't feel cringey, doesn't feel forced, it's fluent and the remarks they make throughout the game keep you hooked up. Difficulty is a big thing in this game. It starts off simple but when you start progressing, it gradually increases and increases, up to a point where some battles do feel like a true challenge. Just like in Bastion, you can boost up the challenge with certain mechanics that stump some of your abilities, but you get rewarded with extra XP. On sale this game is at $3.99. You'll be missing a masterpiece if you don't get it at this price. Game lasts more than 12 hours and is also highly replayable. I recommend you to get this game for once.

Posted: November 19, 2015
												I think I came a little from Red's voice.....What do you mean, "That's not natural?"Don't knock it till you try it.No, but really. This game earns a   9.3/10  and is still one of the most audio-engaging games i've ever played to date, maybe only rivaled by Audio surf.Words can't even describe how utterly beautiful and magnificient this game is. This game is artistically a treat to your eyes. Seriously, sometimes just take a moment to "take it all in' This is a game meant to be a visual spectacle, and it clearly wants you to take a moment to look at it.  If we really judged games by aesthetics alone, then it easily earns a solid 10/10 for it's unique "Interactable Painting"-Esque world that just oozes style and personality like it's distance cousin: Bastion.However, in a world where we judge a game by multiple factors, I will give it a fair review.This easily earns a solid 10/10 for it's art style. Gameplay can be jagged sometimes, as there's ever only three real stages of the combat: 1. Plotting your Turn()2. Fleeing from enemies during Turn() Recovery.3. Psuedo-Combat in realtime, in which most enemies outright dodge your attacks unless you carefully plan. However, it's still engaging. The sheer amount of customizations done with your functions, and all the nifty and unique combinations that can be made from them is absoloutely stellar, and provides a deep "Play how you want to play" feeling to the game.The difficulty can be artificially tweaked by enabling "Limiters" which power up the enemies in exchange for more EXP. It's worth it, for the most part. However by late game some of the Limiter's are fairly hard to keep up with, so be careful.So as as such, the combat earns a 8.5/10, with a bit of room for improvement, mostly on some of the odd-looking animations that accompany Red's moves, and a lack of real in-between for the Turn() Planning period.The Story of the game is told through the functions you find, whether they be extracted from the data of people, or enemies you defeat, reading is essential. There is a post about the story of Transistor, and it is a decent story filled with some intrigue and computer-geek jokes that some people might not catch unless they're pretty saavy in the computer sciences.Lastly, and probably the second most important part of this game I feel, is the BGM. Oh lordy, probably my favorite part of this game, the OST is hands down one of the most ear-pleasing experiences known to man. It's hard to argue that this game doesn't just compell you to listen to the BGM, you grow an utter appreciation for the atmosphere it creates. The best part of the game is when you learn to simply "Hum" with Red by holding Tab. Try it out! Once you learn how to Flourish, you also learn how to Hum. I'd say I spent many a 20 minutes or so simply listening to red "Hum" songs at various points. Absoloutely amazing. Earns an easy 9.5/10, only deducting .5 because you aren't given the ability to "Hum' at the very start of the game. With that said, I'd say the game comes out to be a pretty solid 9.3/10 with a definite "Recommend This Game" from me. I hope you get to enjoy it too~

Great soundtrack! I liked it better than Bastion's, honestly. Great art! Again, better than Bastion's.Gameplay is greaaaaat! But that's a good thing because you only get that on NG+.)Story is meh. Bastion's was better. A lot of the things in the game are left unexplained, and by a lot, I mean, almost everything from what the hell the Transistor is to why the ♥♥♥♥ did the final boss battle happen in that place. A lot of it is left to the imagination of the player. Length is meh as well. The game is short. I only spent 11 and a half hours on the game to get all achievements.Replayability is nonexistent. After the first recursion (NG+), you shouldn't find any more reason to play it again, except probaly when you haven't gotten all achievements yet. I loved Transistor better than Bastion because unlike Bastion, Transistor felt less of the traditional RPG mainly due to its function system. 												SPECS:AMD-A6 5200 (3rd generation i3 equivalent) AMD Radeon HD8400 / R3 Series 512 MB4 gigs of RAM64-bit Windows 10What could be said for Transistor that hasn't been said before? Supergiant Games second game is a massive step forward from its previous title Bastion, and while gamers may argue over which is better; both are great. Where Transistor differs, is that Supergiant made a hybrid action RPG. Red has a "turn" function in the sense of traditional RPG battles; but by equipping Red's weapon with certain functions (they are found throughout the game) some will allow her to battle outside of her turn. Her weapon consists of four attacks that you slot functions into, these can then have up to 2 more functions attached increasing various attributes like damage or even combining skills.The tale of Transistor is one I don't want to spoil, and lasting only 6 hours even while searching every dark corner of the world, I was left pondering what would I do in the end. Some gamers may not enjoy the combat and originally I felt the same. Despite the game tutorials being pretty straightforward, once you find a basic setup for the functions you can nearly button mash your way to end.Transistors art design is brilliant, everything within the city and its characters seem inspired by the art deco / streamline era of the 1930's and Supergiant has never disappointed and I go so far as to say outdone and surpassed anyones expectation with the music in Transistor. I urge everyone that reads this to look up the soundtrack and give it listen.If Supergiant asked if there was anything I could change with Transistor, I would probably say to remove the Performance challenges. I know they are possible, but ultimately I feel that any type of challenges is unnecessary filler and the effort could have gone to adding additional areas and bosses or expanded story elements.

Even with fully exploring levels and listening to all the great and rather touching narrative, the story is pretty short and can be played through within 5 hours. But if anything, I think this game can get away with it because there's a good amount of replay value due to the 'function' mechanics. Not to mention, it does introduce a few new things in new game plus. NG+ / Recursion is a necessity for those seeking to 100% this game as well as playing around with all the different abilities, which I think is great because you may discovering awesome new combos and builds this way. For that matter, the content is built well enough to keep one occupied.For those who are not obsessed with achievements, the game offers more than enough in terms of story, visuals and sound. The artwork is drop dead gorgeous, it's like Bastion's except sci-fi to put it bluntly. If you break it down, the story isn't really unique or in any way complex, but it's the narration of it that makes it truly shine. ..also much like in Bastion. For me, I found the narrative in Transistor to be more stirring though I think it really depends on how susceptible you are to certain kinds of reading. Words can't describe on how beautiful and enthralling the music is, a more than fitting background that makes way for a remarkable and gorgeous experience for one and all.It goes without saying that every game's aspects are subject to personal opinion. But if you loved Bastion, you will love Transistor. In any other case, the game is a marvel on it's own and in my opinion, well worth it's price if not for the music alone.

												The main problem with Transistor is that it's almost, but not entirely, completely unlike Bastion.  The story is intriguing, the setting is enticing, and the combat is incredibly customizable, but every so often, I was struck by how similar to something in Bastion part of the game felt.  Supergiant did a good job distancing themselves from the ideas they had from their first game for the most part yet certain plot points and game aspects, like the narrator responding to the little things you do and telling the story that way made Transistor feel not quite as fresh as it could have been.  The similar art style and same voice actors certainly didn't help, but Supergiant is a small company, so that's understandable.  Besides, the game does look incredible.I want to mention the combat again, because it's stellar.  You enter a planning phase, stringing together attacks and movements and then executing them super fast in real time.  Afterwards, you have to dodge enemies' attacks and survive until you can enter your planning phase again.  I'm sure that's not unique, but the fact that your combat abilities are made up of various Functions(), each of which can serve as a primary attack, a secondary modifier, or a passive buff ability, allows you to modify your skill set in an unimaginable variety of ways.  You're even rewarded for switching up your playstyle, since using different Functions() in different ways unlocks backstory about aspects of the world.The enemies are refreshing, too, especially when they start to unlock more powerful abilities.  Fetch can go ♥♥♥♥ itself, though.  Those things is super overpowered and I hate fighting them.

												It took a while for Transistor to really hook me (about 2/3 of the way through my first playthrough), but at that point I went from mildly disappointed (I really loved Supergiant's previous game, Bastion), to entirely satisfied.  I think the reason for all this is that the combat system is really quite deep, and it took a lot of experimentation before I really started understanding the potential there.  I'm playing it through a second time now and really enjoying it.Aside from the mechanics, the game is beautiful and the soundtrack is excellent.  The story is really intriguing and told in a very minimal way.   A lot of it is told through short voice clips, but if you want to learn more about what is happening, you can also get snipets of story through interacting with the environment, from experimenting with the combat system or from reading message boards :)  Even the way the soundtrack is done complements the story.  I didn't play Bastion on new game+ because I felt like I experienced the whole thing and was satisfied at the end.  I think Transistor essentially requires a second playthrough because there's so much subtle detail packed in that you are bound to miss a lot of it the first time through.  Transistor is a really excellent game, but it is especially rewarding if you are willing to put some effort in.

												Hello world!Supergiant comes back with another installment, same narrator (or at least the same actor), world still falling apart, but this time, it's in the future!For Bastion fans, Transistor has all of the flavors of  Bastion, with a whole new story and significantly changed combat elements.Combat this time often time involves the usage of the "Turn()" ability.Turn() is essentially a planning phase where you can plan out your attacks, then when you execute, it happens instantaneously, then you have a recharge time before it can be used again.Being in the non-discript space future, there are a decent amount of programming references embedded into the game.As a programmer, I thought that was kinda cool, because I felt like I had a secret hand shake with the developers saying "Hey, I got that!"Even if you're not a programmer, those minor references don't really effect the story at all, so nothing will be missed by anyone that plays this game.So to break down the pieces, gameplay, I would say is equivalent to the level that Bastion output.Music, dare I say, better than Bastion. The song for the trailer, We All Become was fantastic. Old Friends was great as well.Combat, personally, I liked it. I've heard some friends that preferred Bastion's combat system to Transistor, but I'm definitely a fan of RPGs, and Transistor feels more like an RPG with its system.Story, I'm kind of mixed. Shortly in, it becomes apparent that there are elements of romance. My video game taste palate initially wasn't expected a romance, but grew to accept and even really like where it took the story.All of those elements combined, it makes this game one of my absolute favorites.I would absolutely recommend it.Gotta get that ten outta ten!System.exit(0) || return 0; //Whichever you prefer.

												Bastion was a massive success for Super Giant Games. Most people have played it and numerous gamers own it on at least two different machines. With that in mind it would have been easy for the studio to release a sequel or spiritual successor to it. We’d all have played it, loved it, and raved about it. Transistor is not like Bastion.Starting in a beautifully depicted futuristic city scape you pull an electronic sword from a body and you’re on your way. No explanation is given and no background about the world or yourself is forthcoming. The player, like the character you control is thrown in, as if awakening from some strange dream and this gives a wonderful sense of mystery and discovery as you progress.From the outside this may look to share some similarities with Bastion. The perspective is the same and there is also a narrator of sorts, although he is talking to the female protagonist as you go. Right at the start you begin to think this is going to be another hack and slash but then about five minutes in it asks you to hit the freeze button and everything changes.Here, you suddenly realise you are actually in a real time/turn based cross over style RPG. You can execute attacks in real time (and even boost them to activate almost instantly), but the real trick is mastering the freeze system. Hitting the button stops everything and you then have an action bar you can use up before the enemy moves again. It’s kind of like the V.A.T.S system in Fallout 3 or the system at work in Vagrant Story.During this time you can move around and stack up attacks. Pressing the button again sends you into action like a blur across the screen. The downside is that you then can’t use any attacks or special moves until the bar has regenerated in full. The more attacks you use, the longer the bar takes to recharge. This means you have to be extremely careful about what you are doing as you are often slower than the enemy robots sent to stop you. It’s essential to get in, attack and get back out to a place you can safely recharge as avoiding damage otherwise is almost impossible and you’ll be downed in no time.If your health bar depletes while you have charge time you’ll get a chance to move away from danger. If not, one of your powers will be damaged and unusable until you make it to two save points. This severely limits your attacking options and often leads to a daisy chain effect of you losing all your powers and flat lining. On the off chance you are finding things too easy you can also add a number of handicaps as you go which increase difficulty and the amount of experience you gain.The options you have to play around with are numerous and can be set up in a ton of different ways. This is one of Transistors strengths but we can see it easily overwhelming some players. When you gain a power you can do one of three things with it. Equipping it in an active slot will allow the player to use it via a button press. This could be a long range attack, a fast dodge, an area effect attack or something like summoning a creature to assist you. All attacks have different speeds in real time combat and few of them work fast enough to run through the game hacking away without the freeze system. Each active power can also be boosted by equipping powers as support. For instance, you could take the bouncing bomb power and add it to your long range attack, thus making the attack ricochet off enemies and into others.  You can add two boosters to each active attack which opens up all sorts of crazy possibilities. Finally, you can add powers to your passive support slots. This means they normally do things like boost player speed or increase resistance. Any power can be assigned to any slot on any other power so finding the perfect combination will require some thought and the possibilities are just about endless. The only limit on what you can do is that each power takes up a certain number of points and once that hits maximum nothing else can be equipped.While you are getting used to the combat you’ll be experiencing some absolutely beautiful visuals. The Neo Noir tone of the game is offset by stunning, neon tinged environments full of small details and snippets of information about the world you’re exploring. It reminded us of an isometric Deus Ex or the SNES version of Shadowrun if the rundown world had been replaced with some kind of semi-utopian society. There are also a few pretty big nods to Final fantasy VII in there as well. It’s gorgeous and the musical score and sound effects also help to build a picture of a once perfect, now lonely world where something seems to have gone wrong very quickly.Overall, Transistor is a triumph of both style and design. It takes some getting used to and you’ll need a PC running comfortably above the minimum specs to get a smooth experience but Super Giant Games have tried something a little different here and it works. There’s the odd pacing issue and players will need to spend some time getting used to how the combat works but it’s a rich and rewarding experience and something that you’ll likely return to long in the future.Overall 9/10

												This game is beautiful in so many ways, each of which is reason enough to play.The music is haunting and lovely, and the singer did a fantastic job capturing the character. The cyberpunk / art nouveau aesthetic works surprisingly well, and makes each new area gorgeous and memorable. The voice acting is evocative, drawing at the heartstrings in just the right way. And the plot is elegant and compelling, with the characters making reasonable decisions, trying to fix what's been done, but each solution makes the situation worse.The gameplay is similar to its predecessor, Bastion, but it adds a turn-based-strategy angle to the fighting. So instead of running around simply wailing on stuff, this time you get to plan out your moves. The game also deals with player death in a genius way; when you die, you get respawned but with one of your fighting moves broken (but you get it back a few fights later). The way it acknowledges player death, makes it meaningful, and forces the player to try new playstyles is devious and amazing.The feeling I came away with after playing (twice, for all the cheevos) was melancholy. It's sad, but the good kind, you know? The kind of sad you feel good for having experienced.That's what this game is. An experience - and a good one at that.

												This game is truly brilliant. At it's core, it's an action-RPG with the ability to stop time and plan out your next sequence of moves, then execute that sequence at hyper-speed. As you play, you will earn or find new abilities (functions), and each one can be equipped either as an active function (press a button and do a thing), an upgrade to another function, or as a passive bonus. The number of possible combinations is near-infinite, and the game really requires and rewards experimentation. The plot, setting and characters are wonderful. Despite the game's relatively short length (around 10-12 hours, probably), I would recommend taking it easy and letting the game breathe. The intracacies of the plot and gameplay can be subtle and vague, and if you try to burn through the game quickly, you will probably miss quite a bit. Take the time to explore, experiment and take in the world and story, and I guarantee you will love Transistor.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												A short, but inspired game. It literally walks the line between turn-based and action rpgs, and you must decide which one to use - executing a Turn() allows you to complete a string of commands much more quickly, but leaves you unable to act for a brief period of time. The beauty of it is enhanced by a handful of functions to use in one of sixteen slots. There are three types of slots:Primary - functions assigned to these slots have direct affect on the field.Secondary - functions assigned to these augment the primary it's attached to. Each Primary has two Secondaries.Support - functions assigned here have a perpetual or reoccuring effect.The story was a surprising joy; while it doesn't break any ground in its plot, it's still well told with clever plot devices and evokes a genuine feeling through Red's actions and Transistor's words. The soundtrack helps carry it along in ways that can only really be summarized thusly: You can find the moody soundtrack on youtube, but the studio recommends not listening until the game is finished - not as a dare, but because it's the soul of the story. As of this writing, I played through the game twice in 20 hours. I also unlocked every achievement offered in this time. They're definitely easy to acquire, but they draw your attention to the nuances of the story and the gameplay mechanics  in a masterful way. Despite how easy it is, the difficulty continues to ramp up on successive playthroughs as you unlock copies of functions you already have, creating even more strategic options. It's quick and chaotic, and without Turn(), you won't survive many encounters. This game reminds me of what I loved about my SNES days and allows me to relive a time when I wanted to understand what was going on in the character's head. For me, the shortness of it made for an awesome lazy weekend and left as quickly as it began.I bought it on sale, so it doesn't seem fair to discuss value. Would I buy it at full price? Yes, if it INCLUDED the soundtrack. Definitely worth putting on your wishlist, because any discount on it will make it a Goodbye().

												Had this for a while, didn't get to finishing it until now.The game's shining feature is its artwork of course -- as usually what I feel gets Supergiant Games' awards 90% of the time.  You can delve into the game's "deep" story by Inspecting the abilities you gain at certain points of the game -- as the abilities you gain are from dead citizens of the city you're trying to save, which are absorbed into the Transistor.  This player kinda glossed over the story, because as usual I play games for the gameplay.  As I did enjoy the gameplay itself, I feel it has a few problems. The combat and core gameplay definitely has its merits, and can be quite enjoyable.  It touts the whole "player's choice gimmick" of either going for more Turn-based gameplay or real-time.   Unfortunately, the game can push you into one or the other, and it's a lot of trial-and-error to figure out which situation suits which playstyle -- and which techniques you should have equipped.  Then of course, you can be punished harshly by having to wait for your Turn meter to build back up in order to use any abilities (Jaunt discluded), getting Tech uninstalled (by getting your life drained all the way) or by dying and having to restart from the last Access (Save) point.  And pending on what you have after you've lost a certain ability in battle,  you might as well restore your save point anyway.I've found a lot of times towards the ending, and more challenging parts like some of the Tests you can do, there's really no point to do real-time combat, because the game can get very spammy, and almost every ability you have has a stop-wind-up, and cool-down animation which can really get you hurt.   And SPOILERS -- the final boss uses Turn, so pretty much forces you to do the same.Developers like Supergiant get super praised for a lot of their gameplay designs from Bastion and this very game, but I feel they give an ILLUSION of strategy and thought that a lot of players get fooled over.  This game barely has any strategy.  Yes, you have a wide variety of abilities to learn and tune to your liking, but in the end, there's really only 2 or 3 most effective set ups you'll find to use.  It's worth a playthrough, and I'll even say worth the $20. It's more fine-tuned than the cluster♥♥♥♥ that was Bastion -- though that one was fun too in certain ways.  Bastion had a lot of enemy hell spam, and this game can get to that point towards the end of the game.  7/10
