Posted: July 5, 2014
												Transistor is a game about a girl and her sword against an all consuming enemy controlled by a shadow group with less than altruistic intentions. At first glance the combat system may seem simple with a Diablo like feel to it, that is until you begin to use the Turn() system making everything much more strategic giving you the ability to freeze time and carefully plan out your next move. While there are no talents or many lateral upgrades to choose from the game does have this intriguing upgrade system where you use one ability to augment another making it so you can tailor your ability set to best match your play style, or to better counter certain enemy types of which there are many. Logan Cunningham (Bastion) narrates the story from the point of view of the Transistor. What’s really nice is that they don’t try to hold your hand throughout the game, spoon feeding you the plot. No, instead the story unravels naturally letting you discover the plot for yourself which I really appreciated. 												This game is truly brilliant. At it's core, it's an action-RPG with the ability to stop time and plan out your next sequence of moves, then execute that sequence at hyper-speed. As you play, you will earn or find new abilities (functions), and each one can be equipped either as an active function (press a button and do a thing), an upgrade to another function, or as a passive bonus. The number of possible combinations is near-infinite, and the game really requires and rewards experimentation. The plot, setting and characters are wonderful. Despite the game's relatively short length (around 10-12 hours, probably), I would recommend taking it easy and letting the game breathe. The intracacies of the plot and gameplay can be subtle and vague, and if you try to burn through the game quickly, you will probably miss quite a bit. Take the time to explore, experiment and take in the world and story, and I guarantee you will love Transistor.

												I don't review many games, but Transistor, much like SuperGiant's previous title, Bastion, exceeded my expectations on all fronts.This game is a tremendously soulful piece of work, and from the very start to the very end, is first and foremost a work of art. The music, narration, artistic style and presentation flow together in a way that I would probably say outclasses almost any other game i've played. Anyone with a quibble of curiousity and a penchant for great games, or even works of art, should immediately purchase Transistor (AND Bastion) and enjoy the ride.To touch on the gameplay itself, the combat is inventive and blends several previously done elements (pseudo-turn based combat, action queues, tactical-execution-based combat) into a pretty seamless and enjoyable experience. It is two parts arcade, one part strategic pause-and-think game. It remains fresh and has a lot of room for player creativity due to the openly configurable nature of abilities acquired throughout the game.What follows are some brief pros/cons:Pros:+Incredible Art. From music to artwork, this entire game is a masterpiece.+Gameplay. The combat remains fresh, enjoyable, and creative all the way through.+Difficulty.  Like bastion, difficulty is born of modifiers you can apply to enemies, which give you bonuses for being brave.+Storyline.  Again, this is a work of art and the storyline is rich, heartfelt, and incredibly immersive.+Soundtrack.  Incredible, as usual.Cons:-Length.   The game itself isn't that long, although there are excuses to re-play the game with new conditions and toy around with the combat some more.That's really all I can see anyone really griping about with this game.In total, I'd give Transistor a 9.5/10, as one of the most absolutely awesome pieces of work i've seen in terms of gaming. It isn't a triple-A 40 hour experience... but it's an incredibly rich, artistic romp through an engaging and incredibly envisioned city of Cloudbank.9.5/10-Colt

Posted: May 31, 2014
												Interesting story/setting.  Combat plays more like a puzzle, with the puzzle being as hard as you decide to make it using optional settings (limiters) you gain through the game.  Single playthrough took me 8 hours, but you get the option for a NG+ that also changes the dialogue you experience the second time through; which gives another perspective on the narrative.  As expected from Supergiant, the art and soundtrack are excellent.  The game at times can feel like walking through the work of Gustav Klimt.  The soundtrack is a largely ambient set of aucoutic guitars and subtle electronic puncutated by vocal hums.  The game also features a couple full tracks with lovely lyrics.The negatives for me were related to the amount of menu activity.  Pieces of backstory and character information are hidden in skills you use, and using the skills in different ways unlocks more of that information.  In order to change how your skills are arranged (to use them differently), you have to visit a menu and shuffle things around between most combat sequences.  It's not a big deal, but slows down the feel of progression and the pace of your play.  It feels tedius.  Granted, you could skip the unlocking of this information and stick to a skill arrangement your comfortable with.  Additionally, some skill arrangements work better for some fights than others, and you don't have any way to predict what the next fight will be, so you usually have to fail the combat sequence to go readjust for the fight.When you're out of the menu's and fighting, you do appreciate the maleability of the skills.  Using any single skill as either an active, augmenting, or passive ability and over a dozen skills, you can create what feels like an endlessly diverse series of offensive arrangments.  Really cool.Overall, a very positive experience.  Definitely worth the $19.99 price tag on release.

Posted: August 25, 2016
												Transistor follows the story of a mute young woman, Red, in her journey of discovery. Taking place shortly after losing her voice, she discovers a key like object known as the Transistor, which narrates and communicates with Red in an accustomed manor. Together, they explore a world which has been over-run with digital viruses, which plagues the worlds existence itself.From start up, I was astonished by the beautiful design. color and soundtrack this feature displays, it all fits splendidly together in a blend that can only impress. The game play is phenomenal, sporting a combination of classic mechanic systems, in a mix that I can only describe as Final Fantasy meets Zelda. The narration is a pleasure to listen too and pays homage to their previous game, Bastion, which was equally fantastic.The game length tends to be on the shorter side, supplying approximately 8 hours of overall game time. Don't be fooled though, once you've seen the ending you're given the option the restart the journey, allowing you to keep all the items and progression from your current file, which lends to some interesting replay ability.Overall, the game is a breathtaking experience, every aspect of the game works well together in a new and original concept. Supergiant Games, creators of Transistor and Bastion, deserve a congratulations for creating a masterpiece, this game will will certainly stand the test of time as one of the greatest games to hit the market. I rate Transistor a 9/10.

Posted: February 1
												I picked up this little game because it happened to be on sale, and it has been my obsession for the past couple of days.  Everything about this game is gorgeous: the combat system, the art design, the storyline, the voice-over work, and the soundtrack... especially the soundtrack!What to expect: Well, it's a top-down action game with some light RPG elements set in a futuristic world that is quite different than the usual fare.  Combat seems straight-forward at the beginning, but as you begin to pick up more abilities, and learn how to combine them in new and differant ways, it has surprising depth and leaves a lot of room to develop your own unique style.  The game does very little hand-holding as far as the background story goes, only dropping little hints as to what is really going on, and leaving you to pick up the plot in pieces as you go all the way to the end.  Some may not enjoy the confusion that style of storytelling can cause, but I feel it was a great choice on the part of the writers.  The characters' journey as they make their way through the story together is very compelling at an emotional level - at least it was for me - and this in due in large part to the excellent voice-over work of your ever-present and yet unnamed compaion.Is Transistor worth getting?  It took me 18 hours to complete two runthroughs and get 100% of the acheivements.  For some, that might not be enough gameplay to justify the purchase, but for me, it absolutley was.  Even if I had paid full price, I still would feel that I got my money's worth on this one.

												I could write an entire essay/article on this game, I'm not going to for the sheer fact that I'm lazy and hope that whoever reads this will take my word and buy the game.NOTICE: *Although my steam record says that I have 4.6 hours played, I actually spent a total of about 9-10 hours playing the whole game itself. The reason for why is because I went offline for those good 6 or so other hours. I've played and beaten this game once already.*     Transistor...Oh what to say about this wonderful game that has kept my weekend more than entertaining for me. This game is something that I've been looking for a long time. With it's interesting combat system, the artful use of combining skills and attacks, Transistor and it's creator, Supergiant Games, shows off a more than polished interactive experience that'll be sure to glue your eyes to the screen for countless hours.      The combat system, to me at least, is something that you can compare to VATS from the fallout games, only in a sense that you're able to choose your attacks and inflict them to whoever you wish provided that you have the resources to do it. This system is a big plus for me in that it gives me the choice on a situation and how I'd like to tackle it. It left it to my decision and in doing so, kept me in my chair (may I add that it is an uncomfortable one) for hours at a time.      The storyline was confusing at first, but once I progressed through the story I found that it was a pretty good one. Nothing that blew my mind, but still was a little more than satisfactory.     In short, buy this game. You're not going to regret it, especially if you got it on sale.

Posted: January 31, 2016
												The city of Cloudbank is under attack by an organisation known as the Camerata. The protagonist, Red, a contemporary artist with a golden voice, gets caught up in the mess and is forced to figure out what is going on with the help of the newly acquired Transistor. A sword used by the Camerata that falls into the hands of our classy heroine. Red is guided through her journey by the voices of those who dwell inside the Transistor on an adventure that will leave you perplexed and wanting answers.The Story Is About What?The story in Transistor is quite convoluted, requiring you to pay pretty close attention to what is being said by the voices who dwell inside the sword appropriated by Red.In short Transistor is a science fiction action RPG where you will fight your way through the futuristic city of Cloudbank. Wielding the Transistor (a powerful sword of unknown origin), Red will piece together the mysteries of the Transistor by pursuing it’s former owners.During an attack by the Process (a robotic force controlled by an organisation known as the Camerata), Red loses her voice to the great-sword known as the Transistor. You come to find Red kneeling next to an unknown man who lies motionless beside her. This man’s consciousness has been absorbed into the sword which, while Red wields the weapon, can speak to her acting as the narrator of the story and Red’s guide.Red is now being hunted by the Camerata who want to track her down and retrieve the Transistor by using the Process to attack and kill her. Why they want the sword however, is still a mystery.Transistor logically combines strategy with a fast-paced action experience, resulting in a combination of reactive gameplay and rich, deep storytelling.CombatI must say, the combat in Transistor is incredibly enjoyable. You have the option to battle in real-time just like any action game, or freeze time to plan out a number of moves to take place during your turn, however each turn has a cost and you can only afford so many moves.Real-time combat allows you to use your abilities (or functions) on the go but they have a use-time and a cooldown.Turn-based combat gives you a gauge that is filled up depending on how much the functions you use cost. After your turn is executed you will be placed on a global cooldown of varying time depending on how much of your gauge you filled up. The more moves you use, the longer the global cooldown and vice versa, allowing for true strategic combat.You gain access to new functions by increasing Red’s level. You can only have four functions on your hot bar at a time but you can combine different functions to grant extra effects such as pulling your enemy right up close to you or switching the allegiance of your foe for a time. However, only a certain amount of functions can be equipped depending on how much memory Red has.Battles can sometimes be quite unforgiving and if your health bar completely empties you will lose access to a function until it is repaired by visiting functions terminals. If you have no functions left to sacrifice, you will die and restart from the last checkpoint.Value For MoneyFor all you completionists out there, you will be pleasantly surprised by how long you get to play Transistor for. Everyone else though, will only get around six to seven hours of play out of Transistor.There really is a lot to see and do in the city of Cloudbank and beyond, so if you really want to stick to it and unlock/read everything you can, expect to be sitting pretty for at least fourteen hours.I managed to snag Transistor during a sale on Steam for around $10AUD so in my opinion that is great value for money. And don’t forget all of the Steam achievements/PS Trophies that go along with it.Aesthetic CharmImmediately upon launching Transistor will you be impressed by the graphics and smooth animations. Personally I was surprisingly awed just by the way Red moves around the screen. The animation of her running with the Transistor dragging along the ground behind her looks really great. Incredibly simple but at the same time quite intricate.Enemies are fun to watch and discover. I especially like the Jerks which pummel the ground with their piston-flattening arms and the way they persistently pursue Red.Once again Darren Korb has composed the soundtrack for Supergiant, accompanied by the beautiful vocals of Ashley Barrett. Every song in this soundtrack is amazing to listen to and I must admit, I was hooked on the soundtrack before I even played Transistor. Each piece of music plays it’s role really well throughout the game, and if you’re also a bit of a Darren Korb fan, you can listen to the pieces of music in a place called the Sandbox which is accessed via ‘Backdoors’ that you gain access to once Red reaches level four.The Sandbox also acts almost like a home base where you can hone your battle strategies in mock battles or practice your planning in timed challenges. Very similar to the challenge levels found in Bastion.Final ThoughtsTransistor is a visually and aurally stunning piece of gaming that draws you into Red’s mysterious world. The voice of Logan Cunningham is thankfully quite pleasant to listen to which is quite a relief as you will be hearing his narration for what feels like the entire game.The story itself is fairly hard to get into which I find to be quite a let down, but once you start to weave your way around the intricacies of what happened and what is happening, you will find yourself wanting to keep going in the hopes of unraveling even more of the enigma that is the city of Cloudbank.If you love an engaging storyline with lots of questions to be answered, Transistor is right up your alley. But if you want a game that has a different type of strategic combat you haven’t experienced before, you will also be greatly impressed. Read the full review[gamereviewsau.com]

Posted: June 5, 2014
												Transistor has one of the most unique combat engines I've seen in a game, in a good way. It's got the basic hack/slash combat, but throws a spark into it by introducing a clever "turn-based" feature which might feel overpowered at first. However given the weight at which you're out numbered, the game definitely knows you've got a trick up your sleeve and feels compelled to ensure you're not allowed to run rampant with it - you will lose functions, you will be forced to strategize.Combat aside, the game has a deep, fleshed out story that, while not completely interwoven with the gameplay, convinces you to earn it through actively combining various functions in various roles. It further pushes you to do this by not simply killing you upon death, but allowing you to continue fight with heavily relied upon functions being removed from your arsenal. The result being a stronger emphasis on reworking your strategy and further opening up more backstory.In short: The game does a lot of new stuff while keeping fresh some of the more traditional concepts. I'd even go as far as to say that it's brilliant on everything it does new and nothing short of great on it's weaker areas, as far and few as they even are.

												I liked this game, but it was primarily due to the combat style.  It uses a combination of turn-based and real-time.  The player gets to decide how to handle combat.  Does the player use TB or RT?  Most of the time I used turn-based.  Sure, I could attempt to play it like Bastion, but playing by turn gives some added benefits.  The storyline leaves much to be desired.  I found it to be full of plot holes and towards the end, it seemed rush and slapped together.  Up to that point, I found it intriguing.  However, it really loses the player towards the end.  Additionally, the difficulty curve of the game was a bit uneven in spots.  From what I found, the player would be engaged with somewhat challenging opponents and then, suddenly, would have to take on a boss that was much, much more difficult than what the player had dealt with prior.  After that point, the level of challenge never really peaked beyond the difficulty of that boss - not even the last boss.  Should you get it?  Well, that depends.  Did you like the music in Bastion?  Do you like linear, but somewhat engaging storylines?  Will the better aspects of the game (e.g. combat, music) outweigh the not-so-great?The good:Great musicDifferent style of combatNice art styleMysterious storylineGreat narrationThe bad:Still a bit glitchy after a couple of dev patchesPredictable storylineUneven difficulty curve

Posted: November 1, 2014
												Only tossers write lengthy steam reviews so here's a quick list of the reasons you should buy this game.Playstyle is fluid: You get a bunch of abilities, four of which you can slot. The rest of your remaining abilities can be used to augment the slotted abilities, giving bonus effects or changing the ability altogether. You can swap them around, mix and match and change them as much as you want, to find a playstyle that suits you or just to experiment with new ways to play after every fight, keeping things fresh.Art style is beautiful: The city looks amazing and intricate. The cutscenes are minimalistic but still amazingly illustrated. It's a very pretty game to look at. Setting is cool: Futuristic, yet original. It's a city where everything is done by the numbers, to the point where even the sky is painted and the weather is voted on by the residents.  It feels three dimensional. Story is interesting: It's a game that tells you nothing, but leaves tidbits here and there for you to read so you can put together the bigger picture yourself. It's a little frustrating at times but it keeps you wanting more.The music is incredible: When people hark on about a game soundtrack, I usually dismiss it. How memorable can some background music be? Transistor's answer: Phenominal. It fits the game and setting, and like the art style, experiencing it is an absolute pleasure. I've never heard a soundtrack like this before. Short answer: Buy this game. It's bloody good.

Posted: October 12, 2014
My Rating - Beautiful and fun with a delicious soundtrack. Definitely worth getting - even if you have trouble running it (see bolded section below)Traditional Rating - 8/10I'll highlight the key words for you.There are mostly good things to say about this game. I love how customizable the difficulty level is (similar to Bastion in that way), the enemies are varied enough that it's more effective to change up your strategy once in a while, so there's no clear "right" strategy or set of skills, everything flowed smoothly for me. The art work is absolutely gorgeous; I stopped multiple times just to stare at what was on my screen and be impressed with how beautiful it was. In terms of story, there's a lot of depth, but you have to look for it very often. The game gives you a living, breathing world, and it's up to you how much you want to read in to what's there. The gameplay itself was very fun and different enough from Bastion to feel new to me; there's a big "coolness" factor to your actions during and outside of conflicts. It's not a super long game, but it has a similar replay value to Bastion. I definitely wouldn't have asked the game to be longer, as that would pad things out unnecessarily (looking at you, Dragon Age), but I also wouldn't want it to be any shorter. I never found myself thinking "when's this going to end?". I'm trying to say it is the perfect length.So there's the good; now what about the bad?The steam version of this game did not run on my computer. After attempting all the patches, work-arounds, suggestions, and anti-virus disabling I possibly could, there was nothing that got it running. I'd click Play (or Run as Admin from the .exe), then nothing would happen... or it would immediately say the game had stopped responding. If this sounds like what's happening to you, go grab a torrented version from your favourite sketchy website, replace the downloaded files with the one from the cracked version and launch like normal from steam. I figure that's a fair work-around if you've already payed for the game :) Hopefully the devs find a fix for this soon.Aside from that, I felt like there could have been a little more clarity to the story. They rely very heavily on the player to be capable of piecing bits of information together. I took me a while to figure out why The Camerata went kill-crazy, and I have no idea what Red's relationship with the guy in the transistor is; my best guess for that is that he's a (not a major spoiler by any means) bodyguard/boyfriend combination of sorts. Those are pretty minor issues though. You don't need to fully grasp the story to enjoy the game, but it certainly doesn't hurt to dig deeper. My best advice for that is to read what's on the OC terminals and the biographies of the characters. There's a lot of depth you can grasp from putting the puzzle together and filling in the holes with your imagination (or maybe I just dig too deep :p)

												Fun tactics-based RPG where you set-up combos and try to take on enemies with as little moves as possible. Posted: October 30, 2014
												Extremely solid game mechanics meet sublative storytelling, as to be expected from the makers of Bastion.Though the two games share some similarities, Transitor does not require as much twitch skills as Bastion because you do your best work in the paused strategic planning mode, Turn(), that has you just plotting out what you will do to perfection, then execute it and see it done.  Given that kind of power, Transistor is not too hard, but you can activate "Limiters" that boost xp rewards in exchange for raising the difficulty.  Things are kept interesting by a clever mixing of various "functions" that each can be slotted as one of your four activatable skills, a buff to a slotted activatable skill, or a passive benefit.Clocking in at about 7 1/2 hours to complete, Transistor is one game whose content does not outlast the appeal of its robust game mechanics.  However, there is a "recursion" mode which is basically "New Game+" (start over, with minor differences from the first run, retain everything you gathered during your first run, even gather doubles of the same "functions.")  Though, even with recursion mode, you'll eventually run out of challenges and level upgrades, and then there's not a whole lot of point to keep playing.  This is not necessarily a bad thing, Transistor keeps things short and sweet.

Posted: July 20, 2016
												Transistor is by far the best single-player experience I've had in a while. This game quickly immersed me in its unique world and original story. The soundtrack was stellar, Darren Korb did a wonderful job, not to mention Ashley Barret's vocals. The gameplay was very strategy-based but managed to stay well-paced enough to keep me interested. But what really made the game for me was Logan Cunningham's performance as the Transistor.The mere fact that the Transistor had a voice and personality was a great choice. Without him, the game would've felt lonely and fairly empty. The dynamic voice lines that made the Transistor react to situations made him feel a lot more real and I eventually fell infatuated with his and Red's relationship. The few other characters were also very well done, and the voice actors for them were all phenomenal.The gameplay, as said before, was unusual but fun. The "turn" mechanic I had not seen in a game before, but it was very well polished. I found myself trying out functions left and right for new effects which proved very useful, less I go through the entire game with Joust as an Active Function. Many of the fights were simple once I understood the core mechanics, so I added "Limits" in order to challenge myself. I found this to make some specific fights harder, while most stayed the same difficulty.The art and music added to the feel of the world's dystopian setting. I can't really describe this any better than it would be for you to just watch the trailer or pick up the game. Both are among the best that the video game industry has offered in this decade.If you are looking for a fairly short game with a lot of replayability, this is definitely the game for you. While not the most challenging game, it's definitely one worth playing through once or twice or five times. Between the breathtaking ambience, stunning performance, and astounding story and gameplay, Transistor is definitely one of my favorite games from the last few years.

Posted: November 2, 2014
												Supergiant Games, who're also behind Bastion, really know how to make games that shine through in my opinion.Games can sometimes seem bland and even unimportant and I play a lot of games that feel like that...When I encounter games like Transistor, I start thinking about why I even play the games that don't do thing as well. I held back with playing transistor for a very long time because people had been going into transistor to play another 'Bastion', and had been dissapointed. So I really wanted to forget the idea that this would be another 'Bastion' and I almost did, untill... I played the game.I didn't regard 'another Bastion' as something that would come in mechanical or storywise likeliness, but rather a game that did the same to me, that Bastion did.The game starts you off 'in medias res' and gives to few clues as to why you're here and what you're doing, the story unfolds at it's own pace and through the two-person monologue that takes place, with this time's narrarator. The game immediately striked me as a viual masterpiece, but that also leads me to one of my complaints... The only graphical option there is, is resolution. Now, I get it, most of the game is hand-drawn, which is really impresive, but it still wouldn't hurt to throw some graphical option in there, especially because there is a short part where Red, the main character, is really close to the screen and I noticed she was very, very blurry and was the one time I was taken out of the experience.Now that I've mentioned one critique, let's jusmp right into the next one... I want more, I mean I don't think there's anything wrong with the game being a 5-or-so hour experience but I have a hard time using the game's 'recourse' (NewGame+) because the game is so dependant on the narrative and the experience, that playing it a second time for challange seems like sacrificial butchering to me, with that said I understand that some people don't feel that way, It's just a bit short, so don't expect to be using 10+ hours on this game. ...This paragraph was me whining that I liked it so much that I want more.I must say, there are few things that capture me like this game, the whole of just work so damned well. I mean the atmosphere, the music, the visuals, the mechanical feel of the game, and the story clash toghether beautifully, and just make me feel the story so much, I even found myself answering on behalf of Red a few times. And not just that old "Oh you're gonna die."-type of stuff, but heartfelt replies to what happened in the world.The atmosphere is desolate and dystopian, you're alone and you're fighting against odds, in a world where help comes very indirectly. I ended feeling a longing for the people close to the main character, and I was afraid on her behalf not to see them again (Spoilers, someone you know is not with you at some part of the game). The visuals work very well with the atmosphere as the city to start is dark and empty while giving an urban-look which in it's whole is very unsetteling. Of course Darren Korb has done it again, and composed a masterpiece of a soundtrack which just hits the spot. I don't have much more to say about that, really. All of this of course compliments the story which I would characterize as beautiful, dystopian and tragic.The last thing I want to discuss are the mechanics. They strike me odd, but interesting,  and very appealing, but they feel heavy and a bit hard-maneuvarable. Surprisingly I don't have a problem with them though as I feel they reflect the position Red is in.In conclution:I love this game.I will soon be using this game to write a project, along with other similar games with narrators.

Posted: October 11, 2014
												Let me begin by saying Transistor had big shoes to fill after the indie gaming victory that was Bastion. Transistor's story is delivered in a fashion only slightly removed from Supergiant's trademark narrated style, and whilst not executed badly it does lack that breath of fresh air that Bastion delivered. The characters have their story fleshed out with unlockable text snippets, detailing their lives and events leading up to the start of your playthrough. The odd fallout from this is it almost seems the plot and intrigue has all already unfolded retrospetively; which, when coupled with mining oodles of text and only tenuous explanation of major plot progression, makes for reduced immersion and ephemeral characters.That said, you're probably dusting off your hands and thinking "well I guess that's a no to Transistor!". Actually Transistor brings a lot to the table regardless of its weaknesses, like many a classic game. The precise combat mechanics and endlessly customisable skill sets are what makes the title worthy of your valuable gamer hours. The difficulty ramps up at a steady pace, thanks to enemies that scale with your levels, wielding a variety of unique threats. One minute you're master of your art, the next a new contender appears and makes you rethink your style. The replay option keeping all your skill progress is a fantastic feature on top, do try this title if you liked Bastion.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												This game met the expectations beset by Bastion: better combat, the same great narration we have come to expect from the likes of Logan Cunningham, the amazing music provided by Ashely Barrett and Darren Korb, and a high-calliber story to boot.But, comparisons invited need adressing:-The story is different, but not in a bad way, because it is an entirely different story: Bastion was more of a world-focused, mini-epic, and Transistor is closer to a film noir. It is more of a personal journey of the titular character Red, and the voice trapped in the Transistor. I still feel that there are some themes(especially towards the end) that seem a bit similar to Bastion, but on the whole, it is a different story. It is still great, especially if you can enjoy something nuanced.-The combat is a bit heavy to begin with, but it is a joy to experiment with. It is built in such a way that you can employ any strategy you wish to, without making the game too easy or too hard: I often found myself using Jaunt(a dodge/dash move) as my primary damage output, and I wasn't punished for it, which is nice. I still think that whilst its preferrable to utilise the Turn() mechanic, it is entirely possible to use only the real time part of the combat. There are enough cooldown modifying abilities that you could unleash entire barrages at the enemy without having to go into Turn().Aside from that, well the music is a bit more cyber-punk, as goes with the setting, but it did satisfy me more than Bastion's soundtrack. However, that is due to my own preferences in music. The art style is still as gorgeous as it was before, and the enemy design and variation are also pretty good.Overall, it is definitely worth your time: it improved in Bastion in its gameplay, the story is brilliant, and everything else is of the same(if not greater) standard than the studio's previous title. It is well worth the asking price, because it is that damn good.

												Beautifully executed game. With it's interesting combat system, the artful use of combining skills and attacks, Transistor and it's creator, Supergiant Games, shows off a more than polished interactive experience that'll be sure to glue your eyes to the screen for countless hours. 												Transistor is a fascinating exercise and succeeds in much of what it sets out to do.Great soundtrack, unique art style, gorgeous animations - these seem to be the common threads between Bastion and this title that work exceptionally well.Transistor's voice actor, Rucks from the first game, doesn't work so well. 												From Supergaint Games (the same people who brought you Bastion), comes he Sci-FI Acton RPG Transistor, a game that feels like a more futuristic Bastion but with a futuristic setting and with a silent female protagonist named Red, with the narrator taking the form of the talking sword she carries with her (that has he conciousness of a man close to Red) as she peices together what happened to her as well as what is happening to the city of Cloudbank. The game's soundtrack fits in perfectly and is really quite amazing. The game gives the player the job of trying to peice together the stpry as it unravels through voice recordings, terminal messages, and exchanges between the characters. The game can be played with a gamepad but i found a mouse and key to suit better for gameplay. The combat system is complex in the sense that Red has the ability to stop time with ()turn and allow her to plan movements, attacks and combos with limitations of course. Take too much damage and a function you have equipped will short circuit, casuing you to return to another user terminal to try and recover it after a battle. Having all your functions destroyed ultimately cuases death. Each function can be equpided to the Transistor for a main attack, another function for an added effect, or to Red herself for a buff like extended health. The fuction system provides different styles of gameplay and different powerful combinations. The versitility of how these functuions are equipped add to the story becuase the functions, appart from being attacks and various buffs, are actually the essenses of some of cloudbank's finest. The more you use a function in a different slot, the more you'll discover about the person behind the function. The game does a great job of haing the player peice together what is going on, tagged along with a great soundtrack, gorgeous graphics and snazzy voice work make a great game. BUT the game feels just a tad short...that's what made me a little disapointed..so while the game is good, it is recomended to buy during a sale :p

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Transistor is probably one of my favourite games of all time, for a variety of reasons, which includes things such as masterfully crafted artwork and aesthetics, an amazing soundtrack by Darren Korb, and an incredible world-setting, characters and lore. This is, of course, a non-exhaustive list, and it has a surprising amount of replayability value for both the completionist and the non-completionist.Just like Bastion, it's a story-rich game that leaves a lot of the world to the player's interpretation and imagination, with only one constant voice to accompany you through the game: the Transistor's. The optional rooms found within the Backdoors are challenging but non-intensive and fun, and there's a certain charm in exploring all of the areas to find all of the interactive objects to hear the Transistor/narrator expound upon the world.The cons of this game would include things such as the combat system, which can be difficult to get used to at first (or be frustrating if you decide to use limiters), and the lack of obvious direction in-game (as you might end up progressing before you mean to), though these would only be a problem if you're a completionist. Luckily enough, you can go through this games as many times as you want in the NG+ mode, which basically eliminates these issues.It's definitely worth the full price, but grabbing this game during a sale only makes the entire experience better. ; )

Posted: January 8, 2015
												Supergiant is steadily becoming one of my favorite developers.  Bastion was amazing enough, but Transistor went even further with the strength of its art, music, sentimental narrative (Cunningham's voice is become quite iconic in its own right!), and more than anything, its mechanics with the customizable ability system, setting it apart from Bastion entirely.  Both of their games make me realize why I now prefer smaller companies in gaming: a smaller number of dedicated people making a smaller game seems much more likely to never lose sight of their creative focus, and the end product is often a more memorable and rewarding experience than an big budget pile of trendy mediocrity where things either drag on to the point of tedium, or abruptly end in unfulfilled disappointment.My only regret is that I can't SPECIFICALLY explain why I love Transistor so much without spoiling what makes it so memorable, so I'm stuck with being vague.  All I can say is that I was extremely happy to play this game, despite...well, if anyone's finished the game, they know.  After the emotional reaction I got from Bastion, I would expect no less from Transistor.  They delivered exactly what I was hoping for, and let's just say there's a very good reason why I refused to buy this game without the soundtrack bundled in.  I only wish I could get an artbook to go with it.I really wish I didn't have to be so cryptic, but this is one of those games that you just do not spoil.  It's just so refreshing to see a game like this.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												This game met the expectations beset by Bastion: better combat, the same great narration we have come to expect from the likes of Logan Cunningham, the amazing music provided by Ashely Barrett and Darren Korb, and a high-calliber story to boot.But, comparisons invited need adressing:-The story is different, but not in a bad way, because it is an entirely different story: Bastion was more of a world-focused, mini-epic, and Transistor is closer to a film noir. It is more of a personal journey of the titular character Red, and the voice trapped in the Transistor. I still feel that there are some themes(especially towards the end) that seem a bit similar to Bastion, but on the whole, it is a different story. It is still great, especially if you can enjoy something nuanced.-The combat is a bit heavy to begin with, but it is a joy to experiment with. It is built in such a way that you can employ any strategy you wish to, without making the game too easy or too hard: I often found myself using Jaunt(a dodge/dash move) as my primary damage output, and I wasn't punished for it, which is nice. I still think that whilst its preferrable to utilise the Turn() mechanic, it is entirely possible to use only the real time part of the combat. There are enough cooldown modifying abilities that you could unleash entire barrages at the enemy without having to go into Turn().Aside from that, well the music is a bit more cyber-punk, as goes with the setting, but it did satisfy me more than Bastion's soundtrack. However, that is due to my own preferences in music. The art style is still as gorgeous as it was before, and the enemy design and variation are also pretty good.Overall, it is definitely worth your time: it improved in Bastion in its gameplay, the story is brilliant, and everything else is of the same(if not greater) standard than the studio's previous title. It is well worth the asking price, because it is that damn good.

Posted: August 4, 2014
												I'm not an expert in genre definition, but I think this is what modern-day cyberpunk is like - less rainy undertown swarming with cyber-implanted punks and more cloud storage wrapped in a sleek casing and filled with the souls of hipsters.It's all about the mood - the humming, the colours, the spotlights, the show posters, the news terminals. The way Red writes comments and sometimes uses them to talk to her lover, who's right next to her, because that's the only way she CAN do it - that's a trifle (just one of many) that plays really well into the whole picture. It's a kind of melodic despair, a sweetly aching melancholy.Get the soundtrack. It's as much part of the story as anything else, Ashley Barrett's voice a flashback to just before the game begins, when Red still had hers.Combat... well, it's there. You can whack 'em in real-time, Diablo-style, or you can plan your moves for maximum tactical efficiency - the game has a built-in 'challenge mode' for all styles. The system where you use skills as upgrades for other skills, or as separate passive skills, is interesting. But again, it's all about the mood and the story here - because every skill is a person, and you learn their story by using the skill in various ways.The game is horribly short, but I get the feeling that it's exactly long enough. Sometimes a short story should be a short story. It shouldn't be sold for the price of a whole book, though.

												A beautiful game with an even more beautiful soundtrack. It sums up right about everything this game is.But what about the gameplay? Well, simply great. The game uses some new mecanics that give it a bit more dept. By example,the move turn() which gives you the ability to pause the game and plan your next moves. Transistor also gives you a verry satisfying skill system. It lets you combine every skill in the game. . .Yes! Every single one.So yeah, the gameplay is great. But do we get a good story? The answer is yes.Well, I'm not gonna say to much about the story, because I don't want to spoil anything. But it definitly won't let you down.When you start a series of events have happened. You, "Red", seek revenge. While playing the game you slowly find out what all happened before. The whole game gets supported by a "one of a kind" naration. The Transistor, your sword, is always holding a one sided converstation with you, Red, who has lost her voice. Making it a unike experience.The only downside I've found is that, however the game introduces some great mecanics, It doesn't realy explane them.Leaving you somewhat in the dark and leaving you somethimes in a situation where you don't know what happens or what you are doing.This however is a minor problem, as you learn verry quickly how everthing works.My final conclusion? Transistor is a must have!

Posted: November 5, 2014
												Transistor is a fascinating exercise and succeeds in much of what it sets out to do.Great soundtrack, unique art style, gorgeous animations - these seem to be the common threads between Bastion and this title that work exceptionally well.Transistor's voice actor, Rucks from the first game, doesn't work so well. The muddled storyline also isn't well presented - although I do love the clever Terminal interactions that you come across, as well as the story's overall themes.The combat mechanics, while interesting, don't offer as great a depth as it may first appear. Certain combinations are incredibly deadly while others simply don't work for many situations. The differences between using Turn and not using Turn are extreme - it would have been great to offer the possibility (and achievement!) of doing the whole game without using a single Turn. The best part here was learning the unique mechanics and interactions.It seems almost designed for multiplayer too - in a style as seen in the Agency tests? This is disappointing. Although I can see some of the combos would have to be rebalanced.There is a lot to like here, and I am glad that I waited until it dropped to 50% off, and I can recommended it - but it's a light recommendation. There is no doubt that Supergiant Games have built another incredible world that I am glad to have explored.

Posted: October 11, 2014
												Let me begin by saying Transistor had big shoes to fill after the indie gaming victory that was Bastion. Transistor's story is delivered in a fashion only slightly removed from Supergiant's trademark narrated style, and whilst not executed badly it does lack that breath of fresh air that Bastion delivered. The characters have their story fleshed out with unlockable text snippets, detailing their lives and events leading up to the start of your playthrough. The odd fallout from this is it almost seems the plot and intrigue has all already unfolded retrospetively; which, when coupled with mining oodles of text and only tenuous explanation of major plot progression, makes for reduced immersion and ephemeral characters.That said, you're probably dusting off your hands and thinking "well I guess that's a no to Transistor!". Actually Transistor brings a lot to the table regardless of its weaknesses, like many a classic game. The precise combat mechanics and endlessly customisable skill sets are what makes the title worthy of your valuable gamer hours. The difficulty ramps up at a steady pace, thanks to enemies that scale with your levels, wielding a variety of unique threats. One minute you're master of your art, the next a new contender appears and makes you rethink your style. The replay option keeping all your skill progress is a fantastic feature on top, do try this title if you liked Bastion.

Posted: August 15, 2014
												Transistor is the second game from Bastion developer Super Giant Games, and it is another exceptionally crafted artistic RPG.In Transistor you play the role of Red, a beautiful and talented musician who has seemingly lost her voice.  The game begins with Red pulling a sword like device known as the Transistor out of the chest of a dead man.  Immediately the Transistor begins talking to Red as if it knows her.  The voice of the Transistor is how we learn what's going on in this abandoned ghost town of a city called Cloudbank.   Much like the narrator in Bastion comments on the situation of Caelondia, the Transistor will talk to Red about things happening in Cloudbank.  It seems Super Giant Games really has a thing for mysterious apocalyptic events that wipe out flourishing cities.  Not only is the Transistor your talking guide through the game it's also a very powerful tool and weapon.   In the beginning the Transistor only has two functions loaded into it, thus giving you two different attack options.  As you level up you'll unlock   more functions, function upgrade slots, and passive function slots.  The function customization and use is incredibly deep and fun to experiment with as you explore combinations to fit your play style.  It really makes the combat an enjoyable sandbox of trial by fire.Every function in the game has 3 optional ways of using it in the Transistor.  The first use is an Active attack and used to directly afflict damage or other debuffs on the enemies.   The second use is an upgrade slot to an existing Active attack.  This will add extra abilities to your attacks.   The final use is a passive slot which will grant you various buffs or abilities that are always active.  With 16 different functions to unlock, and each having 3 ways to potentially use them, you can see the amount of customization gets exponential.  And even more in new game plus when it allows you to unlock another copy of an already used function.Using the functions in the variety of ways will also reward the story loving fanatics.  Each function you discover is linked to one pronounced citizen of Cloudbank, and as you use the functions in combat you'll unlock background information regarding their history.  It's a fun way to learn more about the story and reward players for trying new combinations of function loadouts.While the story of Transistor may seem eerily similar to Bastion the combat game play is quite different.  Arguably Transistor can be played in the same real time hack-n-slash style of Bastion, but in all likelihood you'll be using the strategic pause mode for most battles.  This mode feels like a turn based strategy game.   When combat is paused you are shown a progress bar of action points to spend.  Every movement, every function will use up action points until the bar is full.   This allows you to plan out your attack before committing to the plan.  Once you execute a plan you'll see all your attacks played out in real time.  You'll then need to fight in real time as you wait for the cool down timer on strategic mode.  It really is a good balance of real time and turn based combat.The thing I loved most about Bastion was it's story, soundtrack and art direction, and once again with Transistor they delivered.   A hauntingly desolate city again brought to life by beautiful landscapes and enchanting music you'll be humming along the way with Red.While it may be relatively short it has replay value in new game plus, just to try more function combos.  If you enjoyed Bastion then you'll find Transistor worthy of a play.

Posted: January 14
												If you're familiar with their other game, Bastion, then you have a good idea of what to expect.The game begins with the female main character, Red, pulling the sword named Transistor out of someone who has just been killed.  The rest of the game is essentially her seeking answers and battling with the fallout of that individual's death in this really unique and original world they've created. The game is extremely polished.  Like Bastion, they pair the visuals, music, and narration perfectly.  The game is absolutely dripping with style and attention to detail.  The combat system is really solid (and pretty challenging) as well.  You have four main abilities, or functions, that can be active at one time.  Each function you gain in the game contains the essence of a fallen individual of the city, whose lore you can read about once you possess it.  Each function has a main, secondary, and passive property.  Each one also requires a certain amount of memory, so which abilities you can run at the same time will depend on how much you have invested in increasing your max memory capacity.  The combat can be performed in real time or you can execute the turn() function and plan your moves ahead like a turn based game.  It's highly customizeable, albeit a little overwhelming at first (there is no tutorial but you do run have occasional access to a practice zone throughout).  I completed the playthrough without unlocking all of the passives or secondaries.  I guess that is supposed to draw you towards playing it again. My complaint is that the game is so compact.  It took me about 5 hours to complete.  I guess I played with minimum limiters (kind of like talents you pick to make certain aspects of the game more difficult in return for bonus xp), but if you need to have a multitude of these limiters to stretch out the experience of the game, then maybe somethings wrong.  Additionally, there are only a handful of enemy types (they get progressively more difficult as you advance in the game).  This leads to the combat getting a little repetitive in some combat filled areas.The game is very unique and well made, and I would absolutely recommend it.  However the $20 price-tag seems to have been made with the notion that the buyer would do multiple playthroughs.  I'd pick it up on sale instead.

												Okay, where do I begin...Overall, yes, I would recommend it, just because Supergiant made a unique experience with a definitive art style.That being said, the game to me is very flawed, especially when you compare it to its spiritual predecessor, Bastion:1) This game is incredibly short. There is a time and place for games as short as this (Journey, where replays are encouraged). 2) You spend half the game going through a few maps, get to a certain area, and lo and behold your final destination was JUST PAST where you started the game in the opposite direction. You spend the second half retracing your steps through a disfigured Cloudbank 3) Combat and customization are very limited. Combining your abilities in new, unique ways was actually rather satisfying, especially when you discover a new combination to trounce enemies ahead of you. Other than that, there is almost no character progression other than increasing your RAM (literally) and junctioning moves together.4) There were two voices (if you don't count Red's occasional humming), and I didn't feel an emotional connection to either of them because of how they were voiced. It was as if they took a page out of William Shatner's book of acting on pausing mid-sentence, coupled with very monotonous expressions. 5) Biggest complaint about the story though has to be how disconnected I was to all of it. I will say that the ending was well done, though. I can see the rationale behind it. 6) There was almost no tutorial to speak of. I had to figure out almost everything by myself. Any tutorial that was there was hidden behind technical lingo resembling computer code, which I suppose fits the game's style.6/10. Support your indie devs!

Posted: February 25
												Transistor is probably best described as a "tactical hack & slash." That odd combo of descriptors speaks to a set of game mechanics that is unique and, at times, complex. The "trials" they present you are especially challenging puzzles, as are boss fights. The game offers a wide array of stylistic capabilities, as well as "limiters" - options which you can turn on to enhance the difficulty (and your reward). The story is really nothing to speak of - the flimsiest outline of a plot, loosely carried along by vague, non-specific lines of dialogue uttered by cardboard characters with cool portraits but little personality. Don't get this expecting to find an engaging narrative - the gameplay is the real strength here.I paid this game the ultimate compliment and actually beat it. The game is satisfying, albeit frustrating at times - the "challenge puzzles" usually have a trick to figure out. Until you do it can feel like you're beating your head against a brick wall - sometimes unsure whether it's your tactics or your ability to execute that's at fault. That being said, the game is well worth it, especially if you enjoyed Bastion - and, frankly, I would recommend Bastion to anyone who's never played a SuperGiant game before I'd send them to Transistor.

I was surprised to find that I was often rushed from one battle to the next without too much of an intermission. Luckily, the combat is fun enough that this wasn't really a fualt. Posted: February 25
												This game is unique.The art, music, story and voice acting are all fantastic, and a lot of people talk about it a lot, so I'm going to go straight to the gameplay, because to me, that's what really makes this game stand out.The gameplay in transistor is an interesting and deep blend of strategy, tactics, and action RPG. It looks like an action RPG - one character, running around the game world in real time, trying to pull off attack combos. And you can play it like that, if you get good at the controls. But you can also stop time and program perfectly timed combos to occur.That alone sets this game apart. The balance between those two completely different mechanics - using your moves in real time, and planning out moves in a safe, stopped, environment - straddles two completely different genres, and thus two completely different play styles. Besides the real time action RPG style of gameplay, you can more or less impose a turn based style of game play - the mechanic for stopping time is even called /turn. On your /turn, you try to deal as much damage as possible to your opponents by planning out the right moves in the right order so that they don't get blocked or cancelled. Then, you can just run around the board, dodging attacks until the meter reloads and you can take your /turn again.Obviously, most of the time, you find yourself doing a bit of both. You figure out good move combinations to use in /turn, and then while turn is loading, you try to use those same combos in real time to deal more damage. Sometimes, you find yourself using Turn primarily to dodge or reposition yourself, and doing all your real damage in real time. You find the middle ground that best suits you.But the real complexity and beauty comes in the wealth of moves available. You end up learning a bunch of different moves, and the moves can be adapted to three forms - they can be moves, they can modify other moves, or they can modify your player character. You like explosions, but the explosion move is too slow for your playstyle? Slap it onto one of your faster attacks to give it an extra punch. Or, slap your fastest attack on it, to remove its drawbacks. The combinations and complexity available is staggering, and it makes the game more personal and more fun. When you discover a great synnergy between two moves, that was your discovery, and you can feel proud of it.All of this makes the death mechanic in the game hit even harder. You have a health bar in this game, but when it gets to zero, you lose one of your moves - usually the one that's been most modified, so probably your best move. If you built your playstyle around one synnergy, you effectively have one life. If you have a lot of moves, you live longer, but each hit still really hurts, as it takes away one of your tools, and probably one you designed a little yourself and are proud of. This makes the 'death' of your moves matter to you, and makes the tension of the game more real.Since you can only reinstall moves at a save point, and your ''dead' moves will be unavailable for the next new save point you find, this also changes how you use your save points. In an insane reversal of usual game logic, you might choose not to use the save point that's right in front of a hard battle or a boss, so that you can go to it after the battle, restock, and get back your main moves more quickly. All of this is to say, there isn't another game fully like Transistor. It has elements from several different genres, and playstyles or strategies that you have from those other games might apply to it. But as a whole, this game is a unique experience, and one that is unque all the way down its considerable depths.It's also a very fun, immersive, and beautiful experience, and it can be extremely challenging if that's what you want, but also extremely casual if that's not.

												Buyers guide to Transistor (as unbiased as possible).What you'll get from buying this game:-Story:An elaborated story that places the focus on the protagonist (and her talking ironing board/weapon/partner). The fully voiced narration is a mix of on-the-spot quips and exposition. Additionally to the narration you'll get text documents from the weapons menu and in-game billboards. You'll understand the setting and story as you progress through the game (warning: the text documents are in advanced English, which might be difficult for non-native English speakers).-Gameplay (action/puzzles):   -Action: In this action/rpg you'll be progressing through several locations in which you'll have several encounters with a group of enemies. There's no running away from or avoiding encounters. As you progress though the game you'll aquire several moves (called functions) which can be used as an active move, a booster to an active move or/and as a status booster. This system encourages you to experiment with all the moves to see which playstyle suits you best. During an encounter you can choose to fight directly (click-to-attack) or in a sequence of pre-planned moves (called a Turn). After a Turn, your weapon needs some time to recharge, during which you can't perform any moves (just run around to avoid damage). It's possible your Turn won't have the desired effect because the enemies are moving, are protected or because your aim was wrong. It's possible to artificially make encounters harder by activating boosters for enemies (called limiters). Activating limiters yields more EXP.  - Puzzles: the main campaign barely contains any puzzles. Yet similar to Supergiant Games Bastion there are locations which have nothing to do with the main campaign (called Backdoors) in which you'll find challenges. Some of these challenges are puzzles.-Graphics:The lay-out is hand drawn, the menus are all neon-like and there are many filters to add to the atmosphere of this game. Animation is fluid if your computer is strong enough.-Soundtrack:As far as I can place music in a genre, I would say it's a mix of Jazz and Alternative music. Some tracks are sung by Ash Barett, who also performed in the game Bastion. Most of time during the campaign, you can make your protagonist hum to the soundtrack with the voice of Ash Barett.-Unlockables (in-game/ additional to game):  -In-game: (See chapter Gameplay/action). While experimenting with your moves, you'll unlock the text documents which explain the setting of the story. As you progress through the game, the Backdoors will give you more challenges to complete. By completing these challenges, you'll unlock soundtracks which can be only heard in these Backdoors.  - Additional: After completing the game you'll unlock New-Game Plus (called Recursion). In Recursion, you keep your moves you previously have unlocked and the enemies are harder.-Tips for purchasing  - Check out other reviews (I personally always follow Zero Punctuation's Yahtzee's reviews because he points out the bad things in a game. Link to his review of Transistor :

												Transistor is probably one of my favourite games of all time, for a variety of reasons, which includes things such as masterfully crafted artwork and aesthetics, an amazing soundtrack by Darren Korb, and an incredible world-setting, characters and lore. This is, of course, a non-exhaustive list, and it has a surprising amount of replayability value for both the completionist and the non-completionist.Just like Bastion, it's a story-rich game that leaves a lot of the world to the player's interpretation and imagination, with only one constant voice to accompany you through the game: the Transistor's. The optional rooms found within the Backdoors are challenging but non-intensive and fun, and there's a certain charm in exploring all of the areas to find all of the interactive objects to hear the Transistor/narrator expound upon the world.The cons of this game would include things such as the combat system, which can be difficult to get used to at first (or be frustrating if you decide to use limiters), and the lack of obvious direction in-game (as you might end up progressing before you mean to), though these would only be a problem if you're a completionist. Luckily enough, you can go through this games as many times as you want in the NG+ mode, which basically eliminates these issues.It's definitely worth the full price, but grabbing this game during a sale only makes the entire experience better. ; )

												Transistor is probably best described as a "tactical hack & slash." That odd combo of descriptors speaks to a set of game mechanics that is unique and, at times, complex. The "trials" they present you are especially challenging puzzles, as are boss fights. The game offers a wide array of stylistic capabilities, as well as "limiters" - options which you can turn on to enhance the difficulty (and your reward). The story is really nothing to speak of - the flimsiest outline of a plot, loosely carried along by vague, non-specific lines of dialogue uttered by cardboard characters with cool portraits but little personality. Don't get this expecting to find an engaging narrative - the gameplay is the real strength here.I paid this game the ultimate compliment and actually beat it. The game is satisfying, albeit frustrating at times - the "challenge puzzles" usually have a trick to figure out. Until you do it can feel like you're beating your head against a brick wall - sometimes unsure whether it's your tactics or your ability to execute that's at fault. That being said, the game is well worth it, especially if you enjoyed Bastion - and, frankly, I would recommend Bastion to anyone who's never played a SuperGiant game before I'd send them to Transistor.

You can beat it in 3 hours, if not less. There is a time and place for games as short as this (Journey, where replays are encouraged). 2) You spend half the game going through a few maps, get to a certain area, and lo and behold your final destination was JUST PAST where you started the game in the opposite direction. You spend the second half retracing your steps through a disfigured Cloudbank 3) Combat and customization are very limited. Combining your abilities in new, unique ways was actually rather satisfying, especially when you discover a new combination to trounce enemies ahead of you. Other than that, there is almost no character progression other than increasing your RAM (literally) and junctioning moves together.4) There were two voices (if you don't count Red's occasional humming), and I didn't feel an emotional connection to either of them because of how they were voiced. It was as if they took a page out of William Shatner's book of acting on pausing mid-sentence, coupled with very monotonous expressions. 5) Biggest complaint about the story though has to be how disconnected I was to all of it. I will say that the ending was well done, though. I can see the rationale behind it. 6) There was almost no tutorial to speak of. I had to figure out almost everything by myself. Any tutorial that was there was hidden behind technical lingo resembling computer code, which I suppose fits the game's style.6/10. Support your indie devs!

												Supergiant is steadily becoming one of my favorite developers.  Bastion was amazing enough, but Transistor went even further with the strength of its art, music, sentimental narrative (Cunningham's voice is become quite iconic in its own right!), and more than anything, its mechanics with the customizable ability system, setting it apart from Bastion entirely.  Both of their games make me realize why I now prefer smaller companies in gaming: a smaller number of dedicated people making a smaller game seems much more likely to never lose sight of their creative focus, and the end product is often a more memorable and rewarding experience than an big budget pile of trendy mediocrity where things either drag on to the point of tedium, or abruptly end in unfulfilled disappointment.My only regret is that I can't SPECIFICALLY explain why I love Transistor so much without spoiling what makes it so memorable, so I'm stuck with being vague.  All I can say is that I was extremely happy to play this game, despite...well, if anyone's finished the game, they know.  After the emotional reaction I got from Bastion, I would expect no less from Transistor. 												Transistor is a fantastic game: great music, great visuals, great gameplay, and an interesting story.This one hit all the sweet spots, in my opinion. Good length, too - each play through (and it's very much worth recursing/game+'ing the game once) takes about 10 hours.Now, if you're looking for another Bastion, then you may be disappointed. Most of Transistor's combat takes place in a  turn-based mode, where you plan out your movement/attacks, then execute your plan and watch it play out. You can fight in real time (and some of the challenge trials are actually easier this way), but for the most part you'll end up taking too much damage and/or getting knocked out of your attacks to make it a very useful way to play.Difficulty is great, in that it scales wonderfully. By default, you'll have a fairly easy time killing the Process. However, there are 10 limiters that you can choose, which will make the Process stronger, in exchange for faster leveling up. I can honestly tell you that running with all 10 limiters will make for a very harrowing experience.Again, as I mentioned, you should totally play at least twice - first time around gives a good experience, but the second time around - when both you and the Process are leveled up, and you can start stacking functions for extra-brokeness and fun, is what really makes the game.Final word - this is the only game that I've gone out of my way to get 100% of the achievements.

Posted: May 30, 2014
												Transistor is developed from the people who did Bastion back in 2011. In my opinion, Transistor is one of the best indie game released in 2014.In Transistor you play as a singer named Red that wield a talking sword, the game is set in a scfi style future. The game start off without giving a clue on what really happen around the place other than something really bad happened which is similar to Bastion. As you progess through the game, the story will start piece together quite nicely and conversation between Red and the sword are done through text in kiosk machines. The story narrate by the sword, it warns you about hazards around you sometimes. The soundtracks of the game are beautifully made which I find it better than their previous game. The music suits the situation and it transition smoothly as the surrounding changes. As for the gameplay part, the combat allows you to pause the game and plan your move. The number of move and attack you could make is depends on the energy bar at the top on the screen, the longer distance you move, the more energy it will consume and as for attacks, every attack has a different consumption. When you done planning your move, you'll probably notice everything is moving in a slow pace as she attacks them.  The energy bar takes a couple of seconds to recharge before next use. The only weapon you use in the game is the sword, unlike Bastion which provide a nice arsenal of weapon which ranges from spears to mortar. Having one weapon doesnt make the game boring, there are lot of attack that you can choose from, if I'm correct they are called Functions in the game. You can choose up to 4 types of active Function, there some longer range ones like Breach or some which are able to change enemy to be your ally for a couple of seconds but it has to be done in a close range or calling an ally to help you and many more. The active function can be upgrade by merging them to makes thing more interesting, for example merging the long range attack and the ability to change your enemy to ally, whenever you attack using this function it will changes your enemy to be your ally while taking damage and attacking from a long range. There are other combination such as merging a bounce attack with the long range breach, that will produce a long range attack that could bounce off your enemy and attacks other enemy around the area. Each function could merge with additional 2 attacks but it start with 1 open upgrade slot, the second slot comes as an unlock. If you chose not to use it as an upgrade or active function, it can be use as a passive skill. For example, choosing bounce attack as passive skills will give Red a shield to absorb damage. You could put up to 4 passive skill at 1 time but it starts with 1 passive skill slot while the others are unlocks. There is a limit of functions, upgrades and passive skill you can use at a single time, it is all depends on the number of energy bar (cant remember what they call it in game). Certain function takes up more bar than others, at most a single function could take it up to 4 bars. I believe the limit they include is to balance the game and to avoid having full set of overpowerd combination. The enemy variety is pretty good, different enemy may require different approach on attacking them. There are a couple boss fights which are interesting (especially the last one). Overall, I'll say Transistor is one of the best game release on 2014. It has great gameplay mechanics, awesome soundtrack and a rather interesting way of telling a story. If you are a fan of their previous game, you will definitely enjoy Transistor. The game is about 7 to 8 hours long, I complete mine in 8 hours and I remember there are people manage to finish it in 5 hours.
