												A Indie Game that has a creative Battle System, a large variety of Attacks, a beautifull Soundtrack, awesome writting, interesting Characterdevelopment, visuals that will let your Eyeballs Explode, a great Replay Ability and is totally worth its Money ?Here it is Ladies and Gentlemen : Transistor !Made by the people who brought you Bastion (which is a game you totally should have played) this Masterpiece was letting my Heart Beating 7000 times in a Minute !Basic Stuff: The Game is not Hard but it also is not Easy.You probably wont find yourself dying that much in this game but that doesnt mean that the game isnt challenging !Story : As mentioned the writting is great, the Story is entertaining, beautifull and well presented.The Story is not really that long (My Playthrough took about 7 Hours) which is the only lil minus point i can give this game but it is full of Fun and DramaCharacters: The Game doesnt have many actuall Characters which is not a minus point.Each Character is full of emotion eventhough it seems like someone spoke like he was bored as hell while recording, that is what makes some of those characters great eventhough they can speak totally emotionless it fills the impact of their voice for You (The Player) with a lot of Drama and Emotion. The Characters are as interesting as the World they live in.Visuals: Speaking of the World, as i mentioned it will blow away your Eyeballs, the Sci-Fi style that the developers present you is full of interesting Places, Buildings and so on. The Animations are also a Blast ! Soundtrack: The Soundtrack is the Nuke !!! If you buy the game you just need to buy the Soundtrack eventhough its totally unessecary because you can even Unlock the Songs ingame. The Music is themed and emotional and : YOUR HEART WILL♥♥♥♥♥♥BRICKS WHEN THE VOCALS ROLL IN.The Vocals of Ashley Barret are realy fantastic, she is a amazing Musician and when she manages to raise her voice inside the game your ears will bleed Jelly, why will they bleed jelly, you ask ? The Heck i know ! I dont know what you had for Lunch.Actual Gameplay: The Game is a Typical "Action Role-Playing Hack and Slash", but it has some nice little Features for example: The CustomizationAs you progress you will receive Abilities through some Events or through LVL Ups.You can use up to 4 Abilities as "Action-Ability".The Action Ability can be Upgraded by other Abilities.For example i take the first 2 AttacksCrash: A Normal Melee Hit that can Stun enemies for a Short DurationBreach: A Typical Ranged AttackAt Acess Points that are placed throughout the game you can Upgrade and Manage your "Loadout".Upgrading basicly is : You add one Ability into Another Ability, when you add a Ability into another one this Ability wont be able to be placed into other Abilities or as a Action Ability.For Example: If we add the Attack Breach into the Crash Ability Crash will gain the Ability to become a Ranged attack but we cant have Breach as a second attack tho.With later Variety of Attacks you will earn, you can create your own Unique Playstyle !!!Combat: Combat is realy Strategic and Exciting at the same time. You can either fight in the typical Hack and Slash Style or you can switch to the "Turn" Mode at every time. The Turn mode will stop time and will allow you to plan Actions against your Incoming Enemy (Your Enemies wont move until the Actions that you selected in Turn will be Executed), many people think that this just slows down the Game entirely but i think that it totally doesnt slow down the game it just gives the Game a Strategic Touch and its not like you are Invincible because of this Ability. While the Turn is active you can only use a certain amount of Attacks/Abilities but without Turn you can repeatly use the attacks all over again and after your Turn ended it needs to Recharge, while recharging you cant use any other Ability and need to wait until its fully Recharged to perform your Actions. By using a lower amount of Abilities the Cooldown of Turn will take accordingly less time.Enemies: Your enemies are "The Process" a very special kind of AI that is able to develop itself all over again.There is a Large Variety of Enemies that will Upgrade itself throughout the Game.For Example : The FetchThe Fetch is a Process that looks similar to a Dog and it is realy fast and will catch up easily with you if you dont develop a good tactic against it. However : Later in the Game this Enemy will gain a Hunting Cloak Ability making it a deadly Predator and can change the Fight against this Enemytype a lot.Replay Ability : One this is 100% Sure, you will never get all the stuff in your First Playthrough means, you got to do the Story again to see EVERYTHING Transistor has to offer. The Challenges that you can do to Unlock Music, the Variety of Abilities and all their Combinations.The Game can also be Advanced by Adding Features called "Limiters" you can add as much as you like !What do they do ? : The Limiters will make your Game more challenging but this will also reward you with Bonus XP !For Example Doubeling the Enemy Attack Damage but increasing the XP you gain by 4%.Those Effects can be stacked to give you a Big XP Boost or if your just looking for a Challenge then they are also going to help you ^^.I give Transistor a 10/10 it may not be the best game ever made but it still is a wonderfull Experience that you should have played.I hope this Review will help you with your Decision to buy it because this Game is MORE worth then its price !

Posted: August 2, 2015
												If you are looking for Bastion 2, this is not it. Sorry. A lot of the design decisions are similar, but the combat system could not be more different, it's much more linear (you can't advance without killing all enemies, can't backtrack, and the number of fights you can skip are countable using fingers), and the wonderful narrator character has been replaced by one that's merely passable.That said, the game is pretty good if you're willing to accept it for what it is: Its own game.* The combat system has good depth (even if some abilities are woefully over/underpowered compared to the rest, and important hints are only displayed once in a way that you can easily miss them).* The story is ok (though you're left to fill in a lot of blanks on your own). It borrows a lot of cues from Bastion on presentation.* It has an equivalent of Bastion's Gods that lets you scale up the difficulty to whatever level you want at any save point (in fact I like this game's selection better than Bastion's, since it doesn't favor some weapons over others the same way).* New Game + keeps the difficulty scaling and your leveling going from the same point it was at the end of the game (good thing since the story is shorter), as if there were no interruption.* The way the lore unlocking is implemented encourages you to try out every ability in all three possible slots, which is a plus in my opinion.* It is pretty and has good music.Combat is a mix of real-time and turn-based, with the time between your "turns" scaling with how much you did during the last turn (though attacking without going into turn mode is a valid strategy and a few abilities are always available). It veers wildly between frantic, fun, methodical, tedious and everywhere inbetween, depending on the enemies and your skill loadout; but usually hovers near "frantic and fun". Instead of Bastion's variety of balanced weapons, you mix an match abilities an upgrades. Some are blatantly better than others but there's certainly no "one good build".

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Story: 5/5The storytelling to Transistor is told through the interactions between Red, the mute singer protagonist, and her weapon possessed by her lover as well as various messages on computers you find throughout the 5-hour campaign. Plenty of blanks are left for you to fill, and the ending, although a bit confusing, is extremely open to interpretation.Visual: 5/5The game looks like a painting that is gradually losing its colors. At the beginning everything is colorful and brushed with bright colors but as the game progresses colors become darker and by the end there is almost no bright color. This beautiful take on artstyle really adds to the mood of the story and its themes. The city of Cloudbank is a beautiful piece of art that you will want to learn about and explore.Sound: 5/5The soundtrack for this game is amazing, especially the songs with lyrics. Every song felt perfectly attached to the mood of what was going on in the story at the time of whatever exploring or fighting being done at the time. The voice acting is brilliant, especially the voice of Red's lover. Sound effects for your attacks and enemy attacks fit perfectly.Gameplay: 4/5The combat system takes a while to get used to due to a lack of handholding, but after the learning curve it's one-of-a-kind. Abilities are obtained that can be used to experiment with various combinations of equipping some abilities to others or using them as passive effects. At death instead of returning to the last check point immediately an ability is lost until 2 checkpoints later and health is restored to max, forcing you to use the abilities you have left in new innovative ways. Time can be slowed down to make strategic decisions on what abilities to use. Limiters can be used to add challenge to the game while allowing you to level up faster. Replayability: N/AWill edit after I replay the game on its "new game plus" that allows replay with past unlocked abilities.Verdict:Transistor is an experience I have never had with any other game I have ever played. You will grow to care about the main characters, Cloudbank, and its inhabitants. The presentation value is extremely high with beautiful visuals, amazing sound design, and fantastic storytelling. The gameplay has a learning curve and can take getting used to, but once it clicks it's extremely addicting. Transistor is proof that video games can be art. If Transistor is on sale, you owe it to yourself to buy it.

												The game is a little gem aesthetically: art nouveau meets cyberpunk plus awesome soundtrack. Combat mechanics is interesting and the story is engaging - though if you got confused/disappointed at the end of Ghost in the Shell (the movie), then probably the story is not for you. The ending is nice, though slightly predictable - or I'm simply an old geezer who has seen and read too much.The game is not without flaws. Some skills are unbalanced. Sure, I haven't used all limiters, only three, but I have discovered a good build sometime around mid game and ended all late fights in first attempts without more than few scratches - I know, I could have cranked up the difficulty, but didn't feel like. Last 20-30 minutes of the game were a bit stretched and I hoped the thing resolved quickly. Finally, the game is short: 8 hours to complete is not much.Still, I'm recommending it, as it stands out in the crowd. All in all, the story, the style and music, make it worth the money and time spent.

												There are a lot of flaws to this game, difficulty being one of them: There's a save before and after every single monster-encounter. And even if you die, you'd need to die four times at the same battle to have to actually load. The story is short and not as deep. So why am I recommending it?Because it is breathtakingly beautiful. It's a story about love and revenge, and saving the world. It has an ending I really didn't see coming and albeit I said the story wasn't deep, it spoke to me. Throughout the entire story, the voice, the story it told, it was heartbreaking. And slowly, piece by piece, it told a story that touched me.So it isn't long. It isn't deep. If I were to compare it to litterature; I'd call it a short story and not a roman. But if you're a reader, you probably know that short stories often have the most to say, and often have the goal of making the reader think and reflect upon something.10/10

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Possibly the best game I've ever played. Everything is perfectly designed and executed; the passion the creators have for every aspect of their craft shows throughout. I didn't think it would have been possible for them to have done better than Bastion (and some of the reviews I've seen don't rate it as highly) but in my eyes it's far superior, and I rate Bastion extremely highly.Two of the things I wasn't a big fan of in Bastion have been fixed in Transistor. Firstly, the narrator: he was great, but I'm not a big fan of voiceovers as a way of revealing the plot. In Transistor the commentary is provided by a companion, albeit a rather unconventional one.Second, the combat. In Bastion I found that once I got a weapon combination I really liked, I stuck with it and neglected the others, and fighting seemed to be a bit hack-and-slash. You can still play this way if you so wish, but the combat system has been expanded in the most incredible way to encourage you to try other things. Attacks can now be combined and stacked, and the effects of each combination are radically different and fantastically awesome. The sheer variety of possible attacks is mind-boggling, and they're all badass -- none is definitively 'the best'. There's also a very clever 'attack planning' mechanic available, which looks a bit like turn-based combat but really isn't. The combat system is quite unlike anything I've seen anywhere else, and I loved it.The art, music and story are so good it's impossible to do them justice in a review. The plot is revealed gently and subtly, and there are moments where a certain realisation dawned on me that required me to sit back and take a few minutes to process it.I didn't just enjoy playing Transistor; I feel genuinely privalged to have done so. This is a short, beautiful game that amply repays the time and cost.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												A flawed masterpiece that doesn't live up to its potential. Transistor as game is similar to Bastion(made bysame company) in that Transistoris a singleplayer *topdown isometric RPG - but now there is a pseudo turn based system. You can pause the game to queue up abilties that are then executed in hyper speed (at the cost of cooldown - so not always the best idea). A keyboard and mouse is recommend but a gamepad might be more suitable for some.The GoodAbsolutely gorgeous. Wonderful use of special effects, stunning backdrops of a surreal world, and all art in general is amazing. This focus on the aesthetic also means there is a button for your character to "hum" to the soundtrack and to a useless flourish with your sword. You can't get lost in this world because of how the world is designed (it doesn't feel like a corridor game which is good but you may disagree).As an isometric RPG the turn based system is wonderful addition. Your "abilities" can be combined or used as passive buffs which is fascinating gives welcome variety.The BadThe biggest problem is that Transistor is allergic to proper story telling. After you start playing Transistor you may be left asking "why should I complete this story", and the answer is "unintelligible gibberish" which is a tragedy. The story is not inherently bad: there is attempted intrigue and allegory. The supporting cast are all waifish emo characters leaving behind whiny recorded messages, but the biggest annoyance is your own companion sword: courtesy the droning of Logan Cunningham. Yes, the talented voice actor in Bastion is now an annoying sword using every opportunity to say something useless (i seriously want a "mute the transistor" option). And if I don't explain the story now you will play the entire game without knowing or caring(which is ok): the world can be recreated on a whim by "the process" using the transistor - but this has been somehow corrupted - there is a group of rebels resisting this - you fighting stuff for no reason - The end.The "it depends"I liked the soundtrack - but I didn't love it. You may hate the lack of enemy variety - but it is not a big issue because the enemy change/upgrade their abilities. Also the game isn't very long at 6 or so hours so grinding is never a problem - but there is definite replayabilty in Transistor using "limiters" to make the game harder & because the array of ability combinations.The ConclusionI can recommended Transistor solely on the unmatched visual splendor, the RPG game behind it is pretty good too.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016



YouTube™ Video: MOB Review: Transistor 

			Views: 67		

			The world of Transistor, is a sci-fi-themed action slasher from the creators of Bastion.Available Here: Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/237930/ HomePage:...		

Transistor is  a sci-fi-themed action slasher with a post apocalyptic feel from the creators of Bastion. The music in the game, though well done, it isn't woven into the experience of the game and it's mechanics as well as it could have been. Graphically the game runs to a more abstract simplistic feel, though it does carry it's own unique beauty.CombatThe combat can be confusing at first, because it has a hack and slash feel combined with a turn based regenerative time style. This is mostly due to the abilities. You can use four active abilities, but beyond that, the abilities have additional properties that you can integrate into your primary four abilities to augment them. Your choice of what properties you combine determine the new ability that you create. You have 16 different augments to choose from to tweak and synergize  each ability. The game provides a safe area for you to experiment and practice new abilities and traits to find what works for you. While I like this availability to combine traits and create a build that works for you, it has been my experience as I went through the game that in boss battles, you have to go for a more obvious dps build rather than something you have created in order to generate the damage you need to defeat them. I go into more detail about this in my video, which I encourage you to watch if you want further explanation.The story is a bit confusing, and hard to get into at first. There is a lot of information coming at you at once, and little relate-ability and emotional involvement to your character and their actions. The main character doesn't talk during the adventure, but her weapon/companion does. It's been my experience that the companion talks way too much, and is off-putting. Overall I have found that there are some faults to the game, such as a confusing ability interface, having to fall back to traditional dps builds to defeat bosses, and an abstract storyline. Even with these shortcomings, the game is still enjoyable. The story is not a detriment to the game, and the ability to customize your characters abilities makes it intriguing to play, along with the play + mode for longer experiences. I can easily recommend this game.Thanks for your viewership and support; for more videos click here. https://www.youtube.com/c/SocioPsycho

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game is a work of art. It has been quite some time since I last played a game that was so capitivating or moving.For what it's worth, I have never played Bastion so I won't be able to compare Transistor to it. That said, the game's aesthetics are astounding, both in terms of sights and sounds. The game's story is also very good. It essentially dumps you into the middle of events and you have to unpack it from there, tying most of it up at the end. The game's gameplay is also tied into the narrative in a nice and tight manner. The game mechanics involve using various modules that can be equipped either in active, passive, or upgraded slots. The game encourages experimentation as each module contains lore involving a particular character that can only be unlocked by using it in each of these slots. It incentivizes player experimentation in a keen way, rather than finding one tried-and-true attack. Additionally, if your health depletes in a battle it doesn't seem to outright fail you (at least as far as I've experienced). Instead, it disables one of your abilities and recharges your health. As Two Best Friends put it, it's essentially telling you that whatever you're doing currently isn't working. It's another incentive to experiment.We're only halfway through the year, but this might honestly get my choice as the best game of 2014. I look forward to the replays ahead of me.UPDATE 06/28So I thought about this game some more and I want to add another reason why I like this game so much: Red seems like an actual, living person.This is done masterfully through small things in the story. The two that stand out for me are the fact that we see her eat pizza and we see her go to use a bathroom. And I mean use *use* a bathroom, not like Silent Hill *use* a bathroom where you stick your arm down the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to pull out a wallet. We see her walk into a bathroom, a fade to black with a flush, and the game returns.This was endearing to me. Emotions and whatnot go a long way into making a fictional character appear human, but I honestly think it's the small minutiae that ultimately make fictional characters pop to life more. It's not as exciting as drama, but to me it pulses with the true blood of life: the banality of existence. I apprecaited it a lot.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												10/10This is the first game from supergiant done completely on their own (Warner Bros. published Bastion) and it is a testament to what indie studios can accomplish when they aren't fettered by a large studio. I wasn't exactly sure what to expect with Transistor and while it is the spiritual successor to Bastion a lot of it is very different and everything that it borrows from Bastion is improved.The art style, music, and narration are all in the same vein as Bastion, which is to say they are a masterpiece. The artwork is very beautiful especially during cutscenes and found myself taking screen shots constantly for desktop backgrounds, etc. The music is a big part of the experience as well, and just as in Bastion, both the music and the artwork set the scene. I would not say they improved on Bastion because that would be saying Bastion was flawed in those aspects. And Bastion is more of a western feel while Transistor is very much a cyber-punk game. However, the artwork is more detailed, rich, and beautiful, probably due to the fact that this is a newer game. I also feel that the music is a bit more developed and varied. The narration is also wonderful.The gameplay has changed significantly from Bastion, so if you're expecting the fun but rather simple gameplay of Bastion, you will be pleasantly surprised. In Transistor, you only have one weapon, if you can call it that. Your weapon looks like a sword, but it is more like a computer that you can upload programs to. Those programs are your powers and you pick them up as you progress through the game. The awesome thing about these programs is that they have three different uses. You can use them as active powers, passive powers, or you can use them to alter other active powers. For example, you have an area of effect attack, and an attack that gets enemies to fight for you. You can alter the AOE attack with the conversion attack and you have an AOE attack that converts enemies. This obviously gives you an immense amount of flexibility in combat and very different gameplay styles and approaches to defeating your enemies.These programs/abilities are then socketed onto your sword, which is the Transistor of the games title. In keeping with the cyberpunk theme, your Transistor has a limited amount of RAM...each program uses different levels of RAM...some only take up one space of RAM, others take up more. Another cool thing about your Transistor is that it is the narrator for your game...I don't want to say too much because I don't want to give away the story, but it all makes sense a little while into the game.Another thing that makes the gameplay very fun is that you can pause time on the battlefield. While paused, you can move around the battlefield, and choose which powers you want to use and which enemies you want to target. This allows you to escape when surrounded, or flank your enemies (since attacks from behind do more damage). This gives the game a turn-based feel to it. It does not really feel like a hack and slash at all...you can use your powers in real-time as well, but when facing very powerful enemies, you will die very quickly when using that tactic.I have not actually died yet while playing but I have discovered another thing about the gameplay in almost doing so. When you're health bar gets to zero, you don't immediately die, you simply lose one of the programs you have socketed into your Transistor. My assumption is that you will die after you lose all four programs. This also requires you to carefully plan which programs you use and how you have them modified, etc. Just another thing that makes this game awesome.Finally, the story is very intriguing. You play as Red who is a famous artist and singer. Apparently, there's a group called the Camerati (sounds kind of Mafia-ish) who is angry at you for some reason and they try to kill you. They have also killed the other important people in the city you live in (called Cloudbank). That is all I can say since I haven't played it completely yet, and I don't want to give anything important away. But I can say that the story is very intriguing and every aspect of the game helps tell it.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												In the years after "Bastion" was released, fans were left to wonder: What if Bastion was a girl?  With the new sequel "Transistor," Super Giantgames answers this question with a resounding "yes!"In it, you play as an unnamed red-haired girl known only as "R," a professional singer who is forced to turn to professional humming after her voice is stolen by the Yakuza.  The object of the game is to thwart the evil robot gang that is trying to take over the city.Bastion's dad, who has been uploaded into a USB drive, helps her fight crime with powerful magic spells.  "Dungeons and Dragons" players will be delighted to see familiar faces such as Lightning Bolt and Charm Monster.  His USB enclosure leaves a trail of circuitry behind as you walk, reminiscent of the Disney cyberpunk film "Tran" (hence the title, a portmanteau of "Tran" and "sister").Veteran Bastion players will notice two things right away: First, that the loading times have improved a great deal.  Gone are the days of waiting for the ground to load at the last second as you're walking toward it; it is now all preloaded when you enter the level.  Second, that the difficulty curve picks up where Bastion let off and ramps sharply upward from the get-go, offering a great deal of additional challenge, and requiring almost inhuman reflexes and quick-thinking strategy to survive even the earlier encounters.There is, however, an unfortunate glitch where pressing [RT] causes the world textures to glitch out and the whole game to lock up.  I presume this is because it was the "special move" button in Bastion's engine, but this game doesn't have any special moves to assign to it.  This can be a frustrating experience when it happens in the heat of combat.  Hopefully this can be fixed in an update patch.In the end, we are left with many new questions: What if Transistor could talk?  What if Transistor was a guy (a ”Tranbrothor," if you will)?  Perhaps these will be left open to interpretation, but maybe we will be lucky enough to see the developer round out the trilogy and tie up all the loose ends.★★★★★

Transistor, transits the world剧情简单来讲就是红发黑丝萌妹与一支大宝剑的虐狗故事。与前作不同的赛博朋客和相同的 “啊出发点是好的，结果不小心搞砸了结果世界毁灭” 的灭世设定，结局非常感人：妹子拯救了世界却选择自杀，为什么呢？Transistor, transits the world.战斗方面非常有新意，即时+回合策略合理运用可以事半功倍。节奏比较适中，上手了速通三小时也可以完成。技能方面非常有新意，大宝剑可以吸收各种NPC的意识（灵魂），每个灵魂可以分别作为主动技手动释放，或者被动技与其它意识组合出新效果，亦或者作为属性技能直接装备。画面的话光影和色彩的运用更好了，和前作不同这次基色调偏冷，并更多地使用了3D效果。。相同的是依然可以随手截图就是一张壁纸~哈哈。高潮部分和结局的手绘CG配合剧情效果很震撼。音乐保持了Supergiant Games一贯的高水准，空灵优雅，很符合主角失声歌手的气质和灾难过后空城里忧伤的氛围，个人觉得比Bastion更加好，推荐入OST。总之独立游戏这是第一个能让我二周目的作品，期待今年发布的第三部新作。Gameplay: 9/10Control: 8.5/10Story: 11/10 Salute!Music: 10/10Graphic: 9/1010/10 Would be Penetra-nsis-ted again lol.刚才翻了下YouTube有关这游戏结局的评论，发现不少人不喜欢这个ending,前作是有两个不同的结局可以选择的，而这作只有一个结局。然而多了一个细思恐极的看似是NG+的mode。个人觉得，这是制作组对在前作自己抛出的问题 Do you try and go back to the old world, or try and make it in the new? 给出的一个明确的答案。

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Transistor is a rare game that combines sleek, smart combat, an incredible soundtrack, gorgeous level design, interesting gameplay, a captivating story with great pacing, and some of the best voice acting I've ever heard in a game to become something so much more than its individual parts. The functions, upgrades, passives and limiters work together seamlessly, and Transistor trusts that you're capable of figuring out the best combinations on your own. It's just intuitive enough without being condescending like many games recently.For me, the story is what really shone. The writing is consistently fantastic and draws you in right from the beginning of the game. I really felt like I was watching the destruction of a city I used to live in. I experienced a wide range of emotions from hope to anger to a huge sense of loss. The ending caught me off-guard; it's tragic, beautiful and heart-wrenching. It's not a terribly long game (~9 hours before NG+) but that doesn't matter. It's exactly as long as it needs to be.tl;dr buy Transistor it's really good

												I quite enjoyed playing Bastion a few years ago and I bought this expecting a similarly engaging though brief experience. That was not to be however because when you take away the haunting soundtrack and the wonderful aesthetic, you have a very short, simple and repetitive game. The hybrid real-time/turn-based combat is interesting and the progression system is somewhat unique. I'm sure as some critics have said, that a second playthrough fleshes out the combat but my playthrough leaves me with no desire to go through it again. Even the short time I spent with it was padded out with backtracking and vague, pretentious monologues. I bought Transistor at a significant discount and I still absolutely regret buying it. It is tough given the positive reception the game has received to give it a definite thumbs down so just do your research before you decide either way. This will be the last time I take some respected critics at their word.

												Wow.The english language fails me, at times like these. But yet, I will take on this challenge, a review of Transistor.To say that this game is pretty is a collossal understatement. To the point of lying through your teeth. This game is not pretty, it is a masterpiece, worth a spot in a museum and sold for quite the pretty penny. Alright, down to the actual game. If you are a fan of the company's previous work, you might think this a remake of Bastion-style gameplay, with a fantastic narrator and combat mechanics. In a way, you'd be right. There is a sort of narrator in this game, but it is not a fatherly figure, looking down on you with hilarious commentary. This pseudo-commentator is a part of your character, it holds a relationship that seems incredibly intimate. As you go through the game, you and your commentor go through changes and plot development, some seemingly unimportant and some huge vast gaps of shocking drama. The environment you're placed in is beautifully matched with both the combat style and the way you move throughout the game.  If you have ever played a game called "Shadowrun", also on steam here, you might feel a similarity betwixt the two. I sure did. Oh, almost forgot. The soundtrack to this game is to the tier that I actually bought it on steam. BOUGHT. MUSIC. ON STEAM.Do I recommend this game? Hell ♥♥♥♥ing yes.
